PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

We the undersigned citizens of Australia concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown, convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened, Humbly Petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to
(1) Reject any moves towards divorce by post
(2) Restore the former prohibition of marriages between close relatives by blood or by marriage
(3) Project the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will
(4) Ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage
(6) Restore objective tests of irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of: i. intolerable behaviour; ii. desertion for two years; iii. separation for three years.
We pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs whether Australian support for the British attempt to regain possession of the Falkland Islands was conditional on the observance of a declared 200-mile zone around the Falkland Islands area. I ask, in search of information I might say by way of explanation: Was the Argentine cruiser General Belgrano within that 200- mile limit at the time it was sunk? Secondly, was it in fact positioned between the 200-mile zone or the perimeter of that zone and the Argentine coast? Thirdly , has the Government any information on whether there is truth in the allegation , and indeed the boast, by some representatives of the British Government that the United Kingdom forces had been seeking to entice the General Belgrano into the 200-mile zone for several days but that the vessel had failed to succumb to those enticements at the time it was sunk?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — A number of very detailed matters have been raised by Senator Button. I will seek a response on those matters from the Minister for Foreign Affairs as soon as possible.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Communications to the installation of Telesat outback television receiving systems in some Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory. I understand representations have been made to the Government by agents for Telesat for a relaxation in licensing regulations to permit communities easier access to licences without suffering the usual delays. Will the Minister advise the Senate of the Government's reaction to such a request and whether the Government is in full support of such units being installed in Aboriginal communities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is of the view that Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory are citizens of the Territory and therefore are entitled to the same access to services as anyone else. The fact is that because of their remote location they have difficulty in obtaining television and radio receptions. Representations have been made as to ways in which they can receive these services more readily. Some of the communities are aware that the introduction of modern communications would pose threats within the communities to the maintenance of their traditional culture and way of life. But yes, representations have been made. There are proposals that might involve terrestrial transmission and proposals that might involve the use of satellites when these become available. I understand more work has to be done on them all but I think it is inappropriate to try to give any more details other than to say to Senator Kilgariff that proposals are being considered and the methods still have to be finally decided.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. With the escalating crisis in the Falkland Islands tragically causing hundreds of deaths of both Argentinians and Britons, does the Government recognise that the conflict has entered a new and dangerous phase which could result in very heavy loss of life and limb? Will the Government take urgent steps to bring the present hostilities to an end and intensify the diplomatic search for a solution which will first and foremost take into account the human rights of the Falkland Islanders?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government has made clear its attitude to the Argentine invasion of the Falkland Islands for a number of days now. It has condemned the Argentine action and has expressed support for the British Government. As I said earlier, I am not in possession of the detailed response required by the question raised by Senator Button, but I will seek it. However, I have said before in this place that Australia expressed its support for United Nations Security Council resolution 502 of 3 April which demanded an immediate withdrawal of Argentine forces and called on the governments of the United Kingdom and Argentina to seek a diplomatic solution. The views of the Australian Government has been made known most recently in the Foreign Minister 's letter to the Argentine Foreign Minister which was delivered last week and has since been released. The Government has been in close and constant communication with the British Government since the Argentine invasion. In response to requests from the British Government we recalled our Ambassador to Argentina, Mr Malcolm Dan, for urgent consultations and we imposed a ban on all imports from Argentina.

ANSWER.PARA: On 25 April the British conducted an operation to recapture South Georgia and since then there has been military action in the region of the Falklands. The Foreign Minister regrets that military action has increased and that significant casualties are reported, particularly in association with the sinking of the General Belgrano and the loss of HMS Sheffield. However, as the Prime Minister said in a statement on 26 April, Britain's decision to use force was a natural consequence of Argentina's failure to comply with the provisions of United Nations Security Council resolution 502 by not withdrawing its forces . The latest developments have emphasised the need for even greater efforts to find a peaceful solution to this dispute. The British Foreign Secretary restated on 4 May in the House of Commons his Government's continued wish to seek a peaceful and negotiated settlement. The Australian Government hopes that a peaceful settlement can be achieved and welcomes reports that avenues continue to be open which could lead to negotiations.

That is the extent of the response I am able to make at this stage. I noted Senator McIntosh's concern for the human rights of the people in the Falklands. I think that from what I have said it will be seen that we are concerned about this very grave situation. We all hope that a peaceful and negotiated settlement to the dispute can be achieved. That is the wish of the Australian Government. I am sure that if at any time it is appropriate for further steps to be taken by the Australian Government this will be given attention. I will see that the Senate is kept informed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Can I take it from the Minister's answer that the Prime Minister is completely satisfied that every avenue has been pursued to try to get a diplomatic solution to this problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I think that we are all aware that the efforts that have been made, both by the United States of America in the role it has played and by the British Government, to seek that sort of solution to the problem have been constant and continued. As I said, we hope that will be the solution, the final outcome, of the present dispute. I am not in a position to state whether we are satisfied that every effort has been made to obtain a diplomatic solution to the problem. We simply are following closely what is occurring. It is our hope that a peaceful solution to the problem will be achieved as soon as possible and without further serious loss of life such as we have seen in more recent days. As I said, if there is any further information from the Foreign Minister, I will see that the Senate is advised.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Rae has asked a series of very important questions relating to the Launceston Airport. It is a matter which I know has been raised from time to time. —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate or the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs a question along the lines of that asked by Senator McIntosh concerning the Falkland Islands. Is it true that members of the junta governing the Argentine have established a remarkable record of being torturers, murderers and gaolers without trial-violators of civil liberties? Is it also true that, in an attempt to take pressure off them for the massive corruption in which they have been involved and the mess in which they have rendered the economy, they have engaged in a military operation in the Falkland Islands? Is it true that the Falkland Islands is a virtually useless piece of territory? However, is it also true that the incident can no longer be called a toy war because at least 600, or probably nearer 1,000, innocent young men have died and in a desperate situation such men as I have described tend to use desperate measures? In that context, I ask either Minister : Is there any evidence that Argentina has nuclear weapons or has the ability to make such a weapon in a short time? Secondly, I suggest with great respect that Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's reply to Senator McIntosh that we support the British Government and that the Australian Government hopes that avenues can be opened is no longer good enough and that there must be other avenues, such as using the good offices that Australia enjoys with the honest broker in this deal , the United States, to make urgent intercessions to halt this killing in this tragic affair.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question, which is a long one, overlaps the responsibilities of Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and myself. It is a tragic fact that over recent years the Argentine nation has had unstable government. There have been strongly supported claims from time to time of it having governments with non-democratic ways and, indeed, governments commiting severe violations of human rights. Unfortunately that has been so. Indeed, there had been some hope that this present regime may have mitigated some of those habits of the past. I am unable to referee that situation at all. Equally, it is claimed by some commentators that, faced with a very heavy economic disability at the moment and with an economy declining badly, the regime has created an incident off-shore to divert the attention of the people from their homes. That is not a matter on which I can adjudicate. I can simply report that that has been suggested as a reason for this confrontation as it has been for other confrontations created over history. It is, of course, tragic that it should have escalated into a shooting war, that there should have been aggression and that no way had been found, other than by British intervention, to overcome the first situation of aggression.
—Who fired the first shot?

—Aggression is determined by who makes the first act of aggression. I think it comes unkindly from an Opposition senator to try to suggest that any aggression did not come from the Argentine. The fact of history is that the invasion of the Falkland Islands was by the Argentine and that, therefore, was the first aggressive shot. It is pathetically true that there has been a serious loss of life and that there is a danger of an escalation of that. Australia is in constant contact with both the United States of America and with the United Kingdom and, through our Ambassador, with the United Nations seeking hourly ways in which some solution may be found. Aggression cannot be allowed to go unhindered. If it goes unhindered many nations around this world will be under threat. Senator Chipp asked whether the Argentine had a nuclear facility or capacity. My understanding at the moment is that the answer to both those questions is no.
—But it has a huge nuclear program.

—As I understand it, the Argentine does not possess nuclear weapons. Whether it has the technical capacity is a matter of judgment. My understanding at the moment is that it does not have nuclear weapons. Nevertheless, it is demonstrable that its military forces have some of the latest weaponry, particularly some of the latest guided missiles. That in itself , of course, puts it in a situation to inflict serious combat damage. I can only stress, as my colleague Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has stressed, that the Australian Government deplores all aggression and that it is using its--
—Not in Timor.
—I do not think the Labor Party should mention the name of Timor in deploring aggression, because it was in power at the time.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. We are debating at length a very serious matter during Question Time. Senator Chipp asked a very lengthy question, one which you allowed because of the importance of the matter. But we now have the Leader of the Government engaging in lengthy debate, accepting those interjections--
—Order! There is no point of order.

—The Leader of the Government is responding to those interjections. I believe, with respect, that this is in conflict with decisions which you have made in the past. The questions are too long and the answers are too long. This matter is far too important to be badgered around at Question Time.

—Order! There is no point of order. I ask honourable senators to cease interjecting when a Minister is giving an answer on a matter such as this and that the Minister deal with the question asked by Senator Chipp.

—I assure the Senate, as indeed has the Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, that the Australian Government, deploring all acts of aggression, is taking every step within its ability to use its good offices to bring about a solution other than by military means.

—I ask a supplementary question arising from the Minister's answer . I specifically asked whether the Government would intercede and use its good offices with the United States of America to make representations to both sides on this question? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My clear understanding is that the Government has been in close contact with the United States of America. Indeed, the Australian Ambassador, who has gone back to Argentina, has been in contact with the Argentine authorities. If there is more to be added to that as a result of the honourable senator's supplementary question, I will seek the information and let the honourable senator know.

—I draw to the attention of honourable senators the presence in the President's Gallery of three very worthy gentlemen, the Honourable Justin O' Byrne, the Honourable Reg Bishop and Mr Don Cameron. —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, refers to the changes to the income tax zone allowances. By way of preface I state that, under the terms of the Treasurer's statement of 15 November 1981, a taxpayer living in excess of 250 kilometres from a population centre of 2,500 would be entitled to a special rebate of $750. Unfortunately, the conditions of distance from population centres preclude most remote area residents from receiving any benefit from these changes as very few areas in Queensland are situated more than 250 kilometres from a town of 2,500 or more. I use as an example the small western township of Adavale which is not on a rail line, has poor road access and lacks most facilities that the majority of taxpayers take for granted. Yet because Adavale is less than 250 kilometres from the population centre of Charleville it does not qualify for a special rebate. Can the Minister advise whether any efforts are being made to establish a more equitable taxation system, both in terms of the size of population centres and the distance from them, so that remote area residents are justly able to claim a rebate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Government, in introducing the special basic rebate of $750 for people residing or spending the required period in a place in excess of 250 kilometres by the shortest practical surface route from the heart of the nearest population centre of 2,500 people or more, implemented one of the recommendations of the main report of the public inquiry into income zone allowances which reported last year. It will be remembered that during the period of deliberations-I think a period of some seven months-the inquiry received a large number of submissions, held public hearings and made visits to a large number of cities and zones throughout Australia. The committee of inquiry took the opportunity to hear at first hand from a wide cross-section of people the difficulties that people face in living and working in remote communities. The recommendations of the main report have largely been implemented by the Government. As a result, those living in particularly isolated areas and taxpayers maintaining dependants in isolated areas are to receive a significant increase in their zone allowances.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Bjelke-Petersen raised the point that whenever boundaries of any sort are drawn there will always be individuals falling just outside those boundaries . In particular it can be seen that in Queensland, with the large number of decentralised towns in that State, there would be difficulties of this kind. However, the Treasurer advises that it is not practicable to try to shift the boundaries on any ad hoc basis. I have to say that the Government has no plans before it at the moment that would lead it to change the arrangements which have so recently been adopted as a result of the recommendations of the committee of inquiry. However, I will draw the question to the attention of the Treasurer to see whether he has any comments that he wishes to make. In particular, I will ask that he have a look at the position regarding the town that was mentioned by Senator Bjelke-Petersen. As I think will be understood, there will be people living just outside any boundaries that are drawn. It is very difficult to overcome that sort of situation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware of an article which appeared in the Australian on 19 April 1982 which claimed that 'at least six Vietnam veterans have committed suicide in the past four months'-a rate more than double the national average? Is there any truth in this claim? Can this be statistically sound? The article went on to claim:

QUESTION.PARA: There is also a phenomenally high rate of other deaths among veterans. In February the Department of Veterans' Affairs told the Senate inquiry into pesticides and herbicides and their effects on veterans, that 66 veterans had died of malignant cancer since the end of the war in 1972.
Will the Minister clarify these matters? What is the evidence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The particular article to which Senator Teague referred was brought to my attention. Indeed, it is a collection of a great number of various untruths and misstatements of fact. I understand that there was a reference to some 470 Vietnam veterans who had suicided in the period since 1972. I think the original evidence for that statement emanated from a newspaper banner headline in the Truth in January 1981 which appeared to have absolutely no foundation whatsoever and to have been a figment of the imagination of the journalist writing it. As to the particular numbers which Senator Teague has brought to our attention-he mentioned six deaths in the last four months-I am unable to confirm whether that information, in fact, is accurate. But if one looks at the figures across the board for national averages of suicides, that figure seems to be extremely high. Indeed, the numbers which have resulted unfortunately in suicide do not substantiate that figure at all. The information available to my Department is not complete in this regard. We have no way of knowing precisely what kind of information is available in the community on these matters. Nevertheless the figure appears to be substantially incorrect.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Teague drew our attention also to some evidence that was alleged to have recently been provided by the Department of Veterans' Affairs to the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment wherein it was claimed that there had been some 66 deaths from cancer. It seems as though the journalist has misunderstood that piece of information. In fact the figure of 66 was used in reference to the number of disability claims in respect of cancer which have been lodged with the Department of Veterans' Affairs and in no way had any reference to deaths as a result of that disease.

On many occasions in this place I have made reference to the point that this kind of sensational reporting tends to heighten the difficulties faced in this community by veterans who are suffering problems as a result of the Vietnam war. It might be said that this applies to certain other statements in regard to the conduct of the Vietnam war generally. I deplore such statements. They continue to raise problems in the minds of Vietnam veterans and cause them more difficulty in seeking rehabilitation in this community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction to the fact that interest rates are set to rise again next month, pushing even more Australian home buyers closer to the breadline. Is the Minister aware of claims made by some of Australia's leading economists that the Fraser Government's tight monetary policies are largely to blame for the present high level of interest rates? What level of hardship will have to be endured by Australian home buyers and how high will interest rates have to go before this Government has the courage to admit that its economic policies are failing and need to be overhauled?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that Senator Foreman referred in his question to certain eminent economists but failed to mention their names. Therefore I have no basis for confirming the claims which he made. It is certainly true that the Fraser Government's policies in respect of interest rates and, in particular , the provision of housing finance have behind them the very real desire to bear down on the expansion of the money supply in order to keep the deficit under control and thereby keep interest rates as low as humanly possible. That kind of statement stands up very well in comparison to the international situation which does not need reiteration on this occasion. It is clear that Australia has done particularly well in the area of real interest rates relative to other nations. To accept the kind of criticism which is implicit in Senator Foreman's question is to deny the very real efforts that have gone on in this country to reduce inflation and to improve the house owning potential of the Australian community which is demonstrated by a continuing level of home ownership in this country of some 72 per cent and which has not declined significantly in recent times. These kinds of things need to be made known to the Australian people generally.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the final point, that is, the question of the level of hardship, all honourable senators on this side of the Senate recognise-it is apparently ignored by those on the other side-the very real contribution made to alleviating the problems of those on lower incomes. I refer to the recent announcement of the housing policy, the provision through the banking system of some $400m for housing finance for people generally, the provision of special benefits to the States for low income earners and, of course, the general contribution by way of taxation and the housing grant which has been well discussed in this place on previous occasions. The kind of nonsense perpetrated by Senator Foreman in this regard is baseless. The facts stand for themselves. The Fraser Government is doing all that it can to contribute to the welfare of home owners and to ensure that interest rates in the community are kept as low as possible in the current economic circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I return to the important issue of the crisis in the Falkland Islands. I am sure that honourable senators on both sides of the chamber would like to see a diplomatic solution to the crisis without further loss of life. But in any such solution the status of the Islands and the wishes of the inhabitants are obviously key factors. I ask: Are the Falkland Islands regarded by the United Nations as a colonial territory? Are they subject to decolonisation procedures? What are the political wishes of the inhabitants, as far as they can be ascertained? Is there any difference between the status of the Falkland Islands and South Georgia? Finally, could it be regarded as a process of decolonisation to change the status of the Falkland Islands from that of a colony of Great Britain to that of a colony of the Argentine? Surely a mere statement that the Falklands are part of the Argentine would carry no credibility. Are there any Argentinians, other than occupying troops, there now? Did not many European countries have overseas colonies which were technically part of the metropolitan country but which were known to be entreated as colonies just the same?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have some information on the question asked by Senator Hamer, but I will also need to seek some from the Foreign Minister. The Falkland Islands are on the list of non-self-governing territories considered by the Decolonisation Committee of twenty-four under section 73 (E) of the charter of the United Nations. The people of the Territory have the right to self-determination. On 7 January 1981 the islanders' legislative council asked the United Kingdom Government to continue discussions with Argentina with a view to reaching agreement to freeze the dispute over sovereignty for a determined period. Also, on 26 April the British Prime Minister said that the Falkland Islands' council representatives had been happy with an Argentine proposal, agreed to by British negotiators in the month before the invasion, for the establishment of a negotiating commission. This proposal was to have been referred to the islanders.

ANSWER.PARA: South Georgia is one of the Falkland Islands' dependencies. The dependencies are British dependent territories which for convenience are administered by the Falkland Islands Government. That Government is also empowered to legislate for them. The process of decolonisation involves an exercise by the inhabitants of their right to self-determination. The Argentine authorities do not claim the Falkland Islands as their colony but as an integral part of Argentina. As I said , I will need to seek information on some of the last points that were made in Senator Hamer's question. I will see what information can be provided as soon as possible.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for National Development and Energy and refer him to his answer to me on Tuesday, 27 April, recorded on page 1514 in the Senate Hansard, in which he said that the Esso company was committed:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . to a minimum expenditure of $A30m over the next three years to carry out a technical and economic feasibility study of the project.

He was referring to the Rundle project. How much of this $A30m will be spent in Australia? How much will be spent in the United States of America? How much has already been spent? Did any of the $A30m include expenditure undertaken or committed in the Exxon Corporation's Colony shale oil project in Colorado, which it has just pulled out of?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My response to that question was based on information which, in the last day or so, was given to me directly by the Esso company. The understanding I have before me is that under the Rundle joint venture contractual arrangements which became effective in March 1982 Esso is committed to expenditure of at least $A30m at Rundle over the first three years of a technical investigation program to establish improved mining plans and to carry out work on the retort technologies. I was asked whether I could indicate how much of that will be spent in Australia and how much will be spent in the United States of America. I am not aware that part of it will be spent in the United States of America. I will seek out that information and let Senator McLaren know as soon as I can.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. It is about the budgeted expenditure on defence. I refer to an article in the Australian yesterday by William Pinwill in which he said that Department of Defence explanatory notes showed that spending on capital equipment this year was to be $101.009m less than budgeted while defence facilities had been cut by $20.554m; and that, instead of the promised 25 per cent of the Budget going to equipment, only 13.2 per cent was now to go to equipment. I ask the Minister: Is this so? If so, how does the Prime Minister claim that there has been an increase this year of 19 per cent in defence expenditure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister, in his statement, was referring to total defence expenditure. That is based on the defence outlay figure in the previous financial year, 1980-81, of $3,537m. In this financial year, 1981-82, it is estimated that $4,211m will be spent-an increase of $674m or just over 19 per cent. It appears that what Mr Pinwill was referring to in the article to which Senator Lewis referred was expenditure on capital equipment and on defence facilities, which is, of course, part of the total defence budget. An adjustment to expenditure on capital equipment this year has been announced. As a proportion of total defence expenditure, expenditure on capital equipment is expected to be 13.7 per cent this financial year. However, the Government's announced objective of expenditure on capital equipment amounting to 25 per cent of total defence expenditure by 1984-85 remains the Government's policy.
—I ask that the document quoted from by the Minister be tabled.
—I table the document.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Is it a fact, as reported by the Australian Financial Review yesterday, that a meeting of Commonwealth and State officials was held recently to facilitate legislation that would permit a uranium enrichment industry in Australia? Is it a fact that the Government is contemplating legislation which would allow this industry to operate under a mantle of secrecy? Can the Minister give an undertaking that the Government would never permit or require such an industry to enrich U235 to weapons grade material or potential weapons grade material and that a monitoring system open to Opposition members of Parliament will be provided to police this? If the Minister cannot give this undertaking would he not agree that this would be placing Australia in breach of obligations for nuclear non-proliferation into which we have already entered?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a very considerable misunderstanding about this whole matter. That is implicit in the series of questions. It is a fact that a number of officers of various departments and of the States have been meeting now for, I think, the best part of a year. They have been working together to try to see what form a revision of the Atomic Energy Act should take . The old Atomic Energy Act is basically a defence Act. They have been considering also how the various responsibilities for nuclear and radioactive matters should be shared and co-ordinated between the States and the Commonwealth. That is the picture of the meeting of the officers. It is a not a fact that they have met to discuss uranium enrichment. The background of that is that a business body called the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia has been set up by the Government to ascertain the feasibility of an enrichment industry in Australia and also the nature of the technology and marketing. That body is proceeding well with its work. It is hoped that in the months ahead it may reach definitive recommendations as to technology and markets.

ANSWER.PARA: I can give an unequivocal assurance that in Australia we will respect fully the Treaty on Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and all its implications. There would be no way that we would upgrade the uranium to the point of weapons standard in any uranium enrichment industry in Australia. There would be no way at all. I am quite emphatic about that. That is also very easy to police. Incidentally, a uranium enrichment industry is not secret in itself. It is not an industry that is radioactive. It is essentially a chemical industry. In fact, it is an industry which seeks, by a knowledge of the differing atomic weights, to separate the two different ions out of the material. It is an industry which has commercial secrets as to the nature of the technology, be it diffusion, centrifuge or chemex. A high degree of secrecy is involved in that. But the International Atomic Energy Agency would supervise any such industry and would examine whether the material was weapons grade, as would the Australian Safeguards Office in Australia. I have no difficulty at all in giving an assurance that if we do embark upon a uranium enrichment industry, which is a part of the normal industry flowing from the mining and milling of uranium, it would be subject rigidly to all the safeguards and there would be nothing to fear from that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I am delighted at the Minister's unequivocal assurance, which I think is of great importance to this country. There is one point in my question that I want to press and that is whether the monitoring system-if there were such an industry- would be open to Opposition members of parliament and senators to police.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —A monitoring system will be available which would be open to the International Atomic Energy Agency and, indeed, to the Australian Safeguards Office. As to the ability of any member of parliament to monitor, the matter is one of very high scientific technology and detail as well as commercial secrecy. It would be quite beyond the technical expertise of any member of parliament to monitor it. It is for that reason that this Parliament has set up the Australian Safeguards Office. It is for that reason that this Parliament, being a group of people with broad general knowledge, employs experts to advise and to report objectively. Those people with the expertise would advise and report objectively to Parliament. So a monitoring system would be fully available to this Parliament.

—I ask the Minister for National Development and Energy whether he will confirm the announcement yesterday by the Minister for Education that a limit of 1,000 tonnes a year is to be placed on the present $80 a tonne subsidy for liquefied petroleum gas. If so, is this, as reported in the media, the first step in a government plan to scrap the subsidy altogether? If that happens, is the Minister aware of the problems that this will create in rural communities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the subsidy of $80 a tonne was begun early in 1980 at a time when the price of LPG, which had been in parallel with the price of crude oil, soared well beyond that price. That subsidy brought the price back to about $147 or $150 a tonne. The current legislation indicates that that subsidy will expire in March 1983. The Government is in the process of looking at this matter and has made no decision at all yet. However, quite some time ago the Government observed that there were a number of apparent breaches in the use of LPG under its energy policy. Basically the situation is that the Government took the view taken by all nations of the free world that LPG is a prime fuel and should be used essentially in priority for automotive purposes and for petrochemicals and not used where unnecessary, for burning for heating fuel purposes. It recognised, however, that many country districts had no alternative sources, and the Government therefore provided the fuel with a subsidy while no alternative such as natural gas was available.

ANSWER.PARA: However, it never intended that there should be wide usage of it by large industries or an expansion of its use in industries, and therefore some time ago some upper limitations were placed on industries in regard to its use so that it would not be used in a non-priority way. This policy has been known to industry for quite some time. In due course it will be necessary by way of ratification, as happens in these matters, for legislation to be brought before this Parliament, but because the matter has not been considered and finalised by Cabinet in terms of any future subsidy no inferences at all should be drawn as to the future.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of my correspondence with the Treasurer seeking amendments to the Australian Capital Territory payroll tax legislation? Is the Minister aware that in the past Australian Capital Territory payroll tax has always been brought into line with New South Wales changes? Is the Minister aware that in New South Wales on 26 August 1981 the limit to which the full exemption applied was raised from $80, 400 to $120,000 and the partial exemption limit was raised from $201,000 to $300 ,000? Does the Minister recall reading the Budget Speech in August of 1981? With respect to stamp duty and the Australian Capital Territory it stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Accordingly, we have decided to bring the range and levels of Australian Capital Territory stamp duties more into line with those of the States.
How much longer will it be before the Australian Capital Territory legislation with respect to payroll tax will be amended? Can we expect it to operate from 26 August 1981?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I understand that the Treasurer is aware that the New South Wales exemption level for payroll tax has been increased and he expects to raise the increasing of the level in the Australian Capital Territory with his ministerial colleagues. I am not in a position to say what may be the outcome of any discussions that the Treasurer may hold, nor can I predict on what date any change may become effective. But I will draw the matter to his attention again and see whether there is any further advance on the information of which I am aware, and that is that the matter is to be raised and no outcome is known at this stage.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to Senator Guilfoyle as the Minister for Finance and as a member of the so-called razor gang, refers to what is called a Government decision on international commodity organisations contained in the Review of Commonwealth Functions report. With respect to international commodity organisations the report states:

QUESTION.PARA: membership to be withdrawn where the industries are not prepared to meet these costs.

Does the Minister know that Senate Estimates Committee H was told on 23 April that more Government money is being paid into international commodity organisations, that industry is not meeting the cost and that Australia has not withdrawn from any ICO and has no intention of doing so? In other words, it seems the decision was phoney. Will she, as a member of the Committee, tell the Senate how many more of these bogus decisions have been furtively scuttled?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — As far as the last part of the question is concerned, the very great majority of the decisions of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions have become effective and have been reflected in the budgeting. I will need to check the accuracy of what was said and the up-to-date position of international commodity organisations and the reference to Senate Estimates Committee H. Many of the decisions that were taken in the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions were to be introduced at the appropriate time, perhaps not mid-year or in any particular Budget year. I will look at which commodity organisations are in the position that was reflected in the comments of Senate Estimates Committee H. I will provide further information on this matter.

—I ask a supplementary question. While the Minister is checking the record, will she also check the statement from representatives of the Department of Trade and Resources that the Government not only has not acted upon but also has no intention of acting upon that so-called decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — If that is the reference that was made earlier with regard to Senate Estimates Committee H, I will check the matter, as I have said, to see what statement was made and where that lies with the decision of the Review of Commonwealth Functions. If the officer made a statement with regard to the Government's intention, I will see on what basis that statement was made. If there is anything for the appropriate Minister to advise the Senate I will see that that is done.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I ask: Does the Department of Social Security ever pay family allowances to mothers for children who do not reside or who have not resided in Australia? If the Department does pay family allowances in these circumstances, how much is paid annually?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Family allowance is normally paid to the mother or the person who has the care and control of the child. It is not invariably paid to the mother. The circumstances where a child is overseas could vary. It could be a child who was Australian born, had resided in Australia and was temporarily away. I have little doubt that the payment would continue to be paid to the mother in those circumstances. I have little doubt that from time to time children go temporarily overseas leaving the care of their parents. If the child, however, was permanently no longer the responsibility of the mother or of the other parent, I think the position would be that the parent would not be entitled to receive a family allowance. I will check what the practice has been . It would be my reasonably confident expectation that family allowance would be paid only in those circumstances where the care and control of the child remained the responsibility of the parent in Australia.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It follows his response to Senator Chipp's earlier question in which Senator Sir John Carrick said that 'aggression must be resisted'. Is it not a fact that civilised nations have tried to set moral limits to their response to unjust aggression according to the just war doctrine so that the response has to be both proportionate to the injuries suffered and a last resort? Will the Government, in formulating its policy concerning the Falkland Islands crisis, not only take into account that part of the United Nations Security Council resolution calling on Argentina to withdraw its armed forces, but also give regard to and convey to the British Government the view that, firstly, the type of armed conflict being pursued by the United Kingdom with the destruction of human lives involved is out of all proportion to the injury to its sovereign interests said to be at stake and thus offends that aspect of the just war doctrine and, secondly, that such armed conflict was premature in that the steaming time for the war fleet set the time limits for a negotiated settlement rather than allowing the full exhaustion of non-violent means of resolving the conflict? Will the Government convey the view that the British Government has failed to justify the use of armed force at this time; that is, it has failed to demonstrate the necessity for the destruction of human life as a last resort?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether Senator Tate is expressing the policy of the Australian Labor Party on this matter, because he is applying judgmental values. Of course, it is true that one should strive to achieve and maintain peace by all civilised methods, and by non-military methods if one can. But peace is not an end in itself if, indeed, peace denies to people freedom and human dignity and imposes punishment on them. The true goal is the free person and the dignity of the free person. There is no doubt at all that within the Falkland Islands there was a total breach of peace and a severe act of aggression by the Argentinians. If Senator Tate makes such judgments on the British actions, presumably he knows all the details that he drew them from. I certainly would not make such judgments, nor I think would the British people or the great bulk of the Australian people. They are subjective judgments and I think that at the moment they are certainly untimely. I am sorry that members of the Australian Labor Party, by interjection and otherwise, are taking these severely critical viewpoints. Of course, in all these matters, the Australian Government would seek to pursue its ends by peaceful methods. But it fully understands that aggression must not be allowed to persist-otherwise minor acts of aggression blow up into major ones-and the whole history of this world is of the escalation of such things.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. Because of a great deal of effort and co-operation between employers and government, 14,226 unemployed disabled people found work during 1981. I ask: How many more disabled people could have been employed? Further, will the Government continue actively to promote the employment of disabled people in 1982 and subsequent years at similar or increased levels?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not able to say on behalf of the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs how many more disabled people may have been able to gain employment. I know that the Minister drew attention to those who were able to gain employment and who, as implied by the question, had found work during the past year. My colleague Senator Chaney would also have knowledge of some statistics that may be of interest to Senator Watson. Mr N. A. Brown, the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, said late last month in a statement on this subject that it was true that one of the major problems facing disabled people in obtaining work experience and training is the fact that they first have to find the employment opportunity and then have to keep it to take part in full, normal community life. I think that would be the objective of all of us. It was particularly stressed during the International Year of Disabled Persons, when the right to work was also stressed very strenuously by disabled people and by those who sought to assist them.

ANSWER.PARA: Programs of assistance can be given through a range of voluntary bodies and through the Commonwealth Employment Service. I understand that that has improved the employment opportunities of many disabled people. I think what the Minister drew attention to was the fact that so many of those who found their first employment opportunities were able to find permanent employment. This, of course , is what we wish to see. The Minister said that in Queensland last year more than 5,000 people were placed in employment under programs through the Commonwealth Employment Service. A response that he gave on 28 April to a question on this subject contains some interesting statistics. It may be of interest to Senator Watson. I will draw to the attention of the Minister the interest shown in the active promotion of employment opportunities for disabled people to continue what may have been commenced during the International Year of Disabled Persons and to encourage what we hope will be efforts at least at a similar level or at an improved level in future years. If I can find any other statistics that are readily available from the Minister for Employment I will see that Senator Watson is given those statistics.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek your guidance under Standing Orders . Am I entitled to place a question on the Notice Paper if I asked that question without notice in this chamber and received a response which shows that the Minister responsible has entirely misunderstood the question and probably needs to read it?

—The honourable senator is entitled to proceed further with any question he desires to ask. If he feels that a question has not been satisfactorily answered he can ask the same question again the next day, or place it on the Notice Paper.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senator Georges-Mr President, I take a point of order. I raise a matter which I consider to be serious. During Question Time the Leader of the Government, when answering questions, implied that honourable senators on the Opposition side of the Senate who asked questions about the Falkland Islands situation and who were critical of certain actions that had taken place were disloyal.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the honourable senator wishing to make a personal explanation or does he seek leave to make a statement on this matter?

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Georges-I wish to do both but I will formalise the matter by seeking leave to make a brief statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —If leave had not been granted I would have proceeded by way of personal explanation concerning misrepresentation. During Question Time today a considerable amount of discussion and debate took place on the Falkland Islands situation. The Opposition, by way of question, was critical of what was happening in the Falkland Islands. The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) responded to those questions by implying that those honourable senators who asked questions critical of the actions of the United Kingdom were in some way disloyal. That is how I understood the answer given by the Leader of the Government. That is how he responded to questions and interjections from the Opposition. The Leader of the Government failed to recognise the serious situation that exists now in the Falkland Islands area. Hundreds of young men on both sides have lost their lives. Instead of this matter being the subject of exchanges at Question Time it should be-I hope it will be-the subject of a statement in this place so that the Opposition can clearly put its point of view. I strongly protest against the obvious implications by the Leader of the Government and other Ministers on the Government side that those Opposition senators who have been critical of the actions of the United Kingdom are disloyal.
—And the Argentinians.

—And the Argentinians. We have always been critical of their initial occupation of the Falkland Islands. That seems to have been lost. Now we are critical of the manner in which action has developed, leading to heavy loss of life. I resent what the Leader of the Senate did during Question Time. He implied that those Opposition senators who questioned the position of the United Kingdom were disloyal. If the debate is to descend to that level the Leader of the Government should accept responsibility. We are concerned about a peaceful resolution of the situation obtaining in the Falkland Islands. What Senator Tate said by way of question is a clear indication of the position of the Opposition. The Leader of the Government misunderstood Senator Tate's question. He did not realise the depth of Senator Tate's question. He answered in a superficial and shallow way and, in so doing, he questioned Senator Tate's integrity and the integrity of other Opposition senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Any perusal of Hansard or of the pinks of this debate will show that under no circumstances did I say what Senator Georges has inferred I said. I neither used the word 'disloyalty' nor implied disloyalty. Let me make that perfectly clear. I criticised what I believed to be the attitudes being taken- what I called the subjective value judgments. They were my words. I was very careful in doing that. Let me make that clear. I repeat: Neither did I claim disloyalty, nor do I claim disloyalty. In responding to questions I have every right to refer to what I believe are the subjective value judgments of individuals. That is all that I did. Let nobody suggest that the Government does not have a real understanding and a real horror of what is happening in the Argentine. If there is a search of today's Hansard it will be found that a number of Ministers, including the Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, and me, have expressed our abhorrence at what is happening and our need for a peaceful solution. Words which were not said should not be put into our mouths.
—Mr President, I take a point of order in clarification of this matter.
—Order! Senator, if you are taking a point of order and making a reference in broad terms to your party, I suggest that you seek leave.
—I seek leave to make a statement.

—Mr President, the clarification that I seek following your advice to Senator Tate in his dilemma concerns the Falkland Islands saga. In addition to the advice that you gave to Senator Tate I take it that you would confirm my opinion that the honourable senator would be equally able to use that long-standing device of the adjournment debate, if necessary, to follow up on a Minister's answer. Am I right?
—Senator Mulvihill, on all occasions the Senate Standing Orders have always been applied so as to give the maximum opportunity for honourable senators to express their views in this chamber.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Grimes proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The increasing number of citizens needing emergency relief because of inadequate income and services.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no need, I believe, to explain why this matter of public importance is raised today. In the last two weeks reports of the Victorian emergency relief project have been released. If we add to those reports subsequent Press reports amplifying and increasing the coverage of those two initial reports of the committee, and if we take into account the personal experiences, I believe, of many senators and members in this Parliament, we will know the seriousness of the situation which faces many of the disadvantaged people in this country and the organisations which are trying to assist them. We have seen in recent times the unusual situation of organisations like the Salvation Army, which are normally reticent in making what may be construed by some as political comment, speaking out loudly about the increasing needs they see, about the inadequacies of the social and economic system which is supposed to alleviate and prevent those needs and the difficulties that they are facing in trying to assist people.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had for several years now a concerted attack on the welfare system-the welfare state, if you like-as it exists in this country in which misleading propaganda has been distributed. We have seen the traditional attempt to denigrate the poor and disadvantaged, to blame them for their state-so-called ' blaming the victim'-and at times to question their worthiness to receive support . We have seen all this despite the fact that since 1977, according to figures released by the parliamentary statistics group-figures which I think most people have seen-outlays on social security as a percentage of gross domestic product in this country have been dropping. However, it is in times of economic strife such as this that the usual attempt is made to blame the disadvantaged and those on welfare in the community for our economic ills. The Opposition deplores these attacks and denies their validity.

I believe that the other side of the coin needs to be presented and it has been presented partly in the reports to which I referred which were published in the last couple of weeks. The Government needs to be given the opportunity to make a statement on the situation as it exists and as it is reported by those who are close to the scene and not as it is imagined by those who are comfortably off and completely separate from the scene or as it is portrayed by editorialists, politicians and others in the community who may not wish to recognise the problems which exist. People who are poor, who have insufficient goods, services and income to provide them with a minimum acceptable standard of living, exist in our society-which, after all, is one of the richest societies in the world-in disturbing and increasing numbers. Our attention has been drawn to this phenomenon by the increasing unemployment figures and by the evidence reported in the media and given to Senate committees recently by those caring for the homeless, particularly the youth homeless, and, as I said last week, in the report of the Victorian Emergency Relief Committee, which described the increasing demand for emergency relief and the decreasing capacity to cope with this need.

These reports show that an increasing number of our citizens, some 50,000 in Victoria, have to beg-there is no other word for it-for money, food, clothing and all sorts of assistance, and they must do so in increasing numbers. The high incidence of unemployment, the increasing phenomenon of underemployment, continuing high inflation levels eroding the standard of living of those on fixed incomes, and the high cost of land, building and finance in general all add to the burden of those on low incomes, pensioners and those on benefits. The nature of unemployment, which is now longer in duration-periods of over 12 months are now not at all uncommon-means more long term poor and this group is added to by the increasing number of supporting parents. Yet these two groups are most frequently the targets of conservatives and reactionaries who are only too willing, as I said earlier, to blame the victims for their plight. This problem, I suggest, is worrying and should be worrying to us all because the plight of the poor and the disadvantaged tends to be self-perpetuating. The poor have worse health, worse education and worse housing and are treated less fairly by our systems of justice. Those suffering from ill health or poor education, those who get into difficulties with the law, tend to have less opportunity to work and thus have less adequate housing. This leads to ill health and all the other problems associated with it. This vicious cycle is seen more and more by members of parliament and welfare workers and is generally reflected in the reports which inspired us to bring forward this matter of public importance.

Despite a social security system which has developed over many years we still have poverty and we still have disadvantages which are unacceptable in what should be an equitable and egalitarian society. At the same time this system is continually under attack for being too generous. By international standards Australia is not a generous country in its care of the disadvantaged, yet, like so many other countries, it has had a so-called welfare backlash. As Professor Peter Wilenski said some time ago in a lecture in Adelaide, Australia is probably the first country to suffer a welfare backlash before its citizens get the welfare. It is in the light of this general attack on the system, such as it is in this country, that it is worth taking a close look at the picture which is presented in the reports from the Victorian group. It shows only one aspect of the problem, but it is an important aspect which reflects the general situation. I do not have time in this short debate to repeat the exercise of comparing our expenditure on welfare with other comparable countries. That has been done many times before. But it is clear that the system which many would make more harsh is not coping at all well and is leaving too many people in trouble.

The Victorian Emergency Relief Project defined emergency relief as 'the provision of one off assistance and, with increasing frequency, on-going assistance to people experiencing continual or recurring crises'. I point out that this varies with the traditional definition and the definition previously used by similar groups which was usually to describe emergency relief as temporary or one off assistance to assist people to cope with a financial crisis . This changing definition is the result of the changing nature of the assistance which has had to be given by agencies such as the Salvation Army, the various city missions and the Society of St Vincent de Paul which have found themselves coping with the more recurrent crises and an increasing number of crises and which doubt their capacity to cope with the increasing numbers in the future. They are unable to give as much assistance as they would like. They have to spread their resources over far more people. They estimate that the amount given in emergency relief in Victoria has increased from $1.9m to $4.6m since the report of the Department of Social Security and the Australian Council of Social Service on the same subject in 1978.

The examination which was made of the people who need such relief is disturbing . Eighty per cent or more are people already on social security pensions and benefits; 27 per cent are single parent families; 53.3 per cent are families with children; 28.2 per cent are on unemployment benefit-a proportion 22 times the percentage of the Victorian population-16.5 per cent are on supporting parents' benefit; and about 15 per cent are on invalid pensions. That approximately 80 per cent of those people are pensioners and beneficiaries points up the inadequacy of our social security payments, particularly for the three most frequent client groups reported in this examination-unemployment beneficiaries, supporting parent beneficiaries or pensioners and invalid pensioners. Those groups make up 60 per cent of the total contacts. Twelve per cent of the people who sought emergency relief had no income when they sought assistance. Most of them were waiting for a payment from the Department of Social Security.

Compared with a similar report in 1978 produced by the Department and the Australian Council of Social Service, the recent examination shows an increase in certain groups particularly the single unemployed. Supporting parents remain the single most over-represented group of the social security claimants. The report provides overwhelming evidence from the figures and case studies of individual agencies and from aggregate figures of all the participating agencies of a vastly increased demand, coupled with a reduced ability to give worthwhile aid. The social worker from the Salvation Army's Spring Street centre in Melbourne, Captain Colin Berris, claimed that there was an increase of 135 per cent in interviews between 1979 and 1981 while available funds for that organisation had increased by only 40 per cent. In the same period the average value of a food voucher had dropped from $16.25 to $10 for a family and $5 for an individual. I quote from an article in the Age of 16 April which stated:

Captain Berris denies that people's problems are caused by imprudent financial management, rather than inadequate benefit levels. 'I sit here day after day trying to balance people's budgets and I see they cannot survive on the benefits . It would probably be all right if they did not have to pay gas, electricity bonds, and buy shoes and clothing for their children . . . Senator Chaney should ask himself how much does it cost to feed, clothe, and house three children.'

We have demonstrated in the Parliament many times, in fact, every time we debate a social services amendment Bill, the number of people receiving payments which have left them below the poverty line. We know that, on March 1982 figures, a single invalid pensioner receives a pension which is $8.60 below the poverty line; a supporting parent beneficiary with three children receives a benefit which is $35.03 below the poverty line; an unemployed breadwinner with a dependent spouse and three children is $42.07 below the poverty line; a single unemployed person over 18 years is $20.20 below the poverty line; and a single unemployed person under 18 years is $42.30 below the poverty line. Those are and always have been disturbing figures. Indexing the pensions and benefits only closes the gap. It does not do much about decreasing the number of people who will require benefits. I turn to a report called 'Advance Australia-on a Food Voucher?' which was produced by the Victorian Emergency Relief Committee. On page 5 the following statement appears:

Although begging in the streets is forbidden, tens of thousands of people are forced every year to beg for the necessities of life. They beg for cash, food, clothing, household goods and accommodation from charitable agencies like the Salvation Army and the Society of St Vincent de Paul.

The absolute degradation felt by people who have to swallow their pride and go to an agency and beg for assistance is something most of us in this country know nothing about. Having to tell your story to strangers, and then be offered a totally inadequate amount of assistance, because the agency is low on resources, is a cruel irony when leaders presently boast of prosperity and growth rates ahead of other Western countries.

There is a world of difference between the rhetoric of a lucky, prosperous country in which all of us can flourish, which we hear so often in this place, and the reality of the situation as described by the welfare agencies. Lieutenant Colonel Fischer of the Salvation Army's Spring Street centre invited politicians, especially the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) who is at the table, to share the shattering experience of interviewing people forced into the indignity of begging for emergency aid. We should briefly look at where these people have to go and what they have to do. First of all they go to friends and relatives for help, because of pride. Then they go to welfare agencies who operate on a shoestring, whose aid is increasingly limited and who must make agonising decisions about giving people a small amount of money, food vouchers, used clothing, toys, et cetera. In Victoria they may have to go to the clerk of the court for a handout from the poor box-that relic of a bygone era-and confront people who vary in their sympathy and experience. They almost always have no training in social work and they require, through no fault of their own, demeaning details of people's poverty. The situation does not exist only in Victoria. In Tasmania there is a similar problem. An article in the Hobart Mercury stated:
The unprecedented demand for food, blankets, electric radiators, clothes and linen has eroded the stocks in Hobart--
That is, the stocks of the various agencies-
and an urgent plea has gone out for more donations.
Record unemployment has altered the role of welfare organisations to one of helping people in peculiar circumstances to providing support for a host of young families in dire straits.

Both the Salvation Army and the Hobart City Mission point out the difficulties and the problems they are facing. Other agencies, of course, have expressed concern. In the report of the Victorian Committee, Captain Berris from the Salvation Army said:

But while we continue to spend approximately $4,600 per month on food vouchers at $5 or $10 a time, I cannot help but become extremely depressed about the lot of our fellow Australians who lose their health, jobs or partners, and who have to try to survive on inadequate pensions or benefits.
The President of the Society of St Vincent de Paul, Mr Thomas, said:

. . . the levels of benefits and pensions are too low initially and do not keep in step with the escalating economy . . . For any-one remote from the disadvantaged areas of life, it is reasonable to assume that those acknowledged as being recipients of pensions and benefits will, of course, always be the major identifiable components who require essential primary or secondary assistance from non-government organisations . . . That is an unfortunate fact of life today. However, the increasing gap between the 'haves' and 'have nots' must be a major concern for each one of us.

I suggest that it must be of major concern to this Parliament. We must get over this situation in which people are becoming, as a Melbourne Age editorial this month said, 'beggars, but not by choice'. The Government has taken a certain interest in emergency relief in recent years, but it has been an inadequate interest. It has allocated $500,000 in each of the last two years, but there the matter has stopped.

We have had unfortunate lengthy discussions about who is, in fact, responsible for funding emergency relief. We have had a government which, at best, questions whether it is responsible and, at worst, denies that it has a role. As 80 per cent of the recipients are the Commonwealth's responsibility we suggest that the Government has two roles: Firstly, to fund, through responsible agencies, an adequate level of relief; and, secondly, to initiate policies which prevent such catastrophic situations occurring. Of course, in the brief time allotted for this debate one cannot go into the details of such policies, but they certainly involve increasing employment opportunities, the great cause of people in need in this area, instead of relying on market forces. In this long awaited economic recovery we must have positive action. We must have income support. We must improve the level of pensions and benefits, particularly those paid to children of pensioners and those on other social security benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an easy generalisation.

—I have no time to speak longer on that, but we can do it; we can afford it. We can afford it by doing something about taxation avoidance and evasion. We can do it by providing a national superannuation scheme to take some of the burden off general welfare expenditure. We can do it by looking at the direction of the investment allowance. We can do it by looking at benefits from the resources of this country. If we do not do it, both Senator Teague and I will pay the penalty.
