SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to have some debate in the Senate this afternoon on matters which touch on the operation of social security and the welfare of some of the most needy citizens of Australia. I think it would be fair to say that not a great deal of debating time in the Parliament is devoted to those people. It is, perhaps, desirable that they should get more time than they do. Senator Grimes, who led for the Opposition in this debate, suggested that the reason for this matter of public importance coming forward was a series of reports which have been issued in Victoria over recent weeks and the newspaper publicity which has flowed from them, as well as the experience of individual senators.

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge the value of reports which attempt to put before the public the reality of the situation of more needy Australians. The value of reports and examinations of this sort, I think, can be very simply demonstrated. In 1978 my Department co-operated with much the same group of people in Victoria as has produced the recent spate of reports. The initial inquiry at that time suggested that a very significant proportion of those seeking emergency relief-some 30 per cent, I think, at that time-were seeking relief because of delays in the administrative procedures of my Department. As a result, the administrative procedures for getting quicker payments from the Department were attended to. It is encouraging to find that in the material which has been issued over recent weeks we are told that of those people seeking emergency relief the percentage has dropped to between 7 and 8 per cent who would attribute their need to problems or delays in my Department. I simply point to that as an indication that there is value in having those things drawn out. It is possible to expose things which need attention, which can be given attention and which will ease the situation of people who are in need.

I point out to the Senate also that the production of the report on emergency relief is not something that was done against the wishes of either the Government or my Department. Indeed, we supported to the extent of some $57,000 the study which produced the report on emergency relief. The monitoring project which was put in place was put in place with the active collaboration, support and assistance of the Government. I noticed in the acknowledgments the acknowledgment of at least one officer who was seconded from my Department to work with the agency. Again, I mention that merely to show that there is a genuine concern on the part of the Government to see issues such as this exposed so that they more readily can be given attention.

Also if there has been any attack on welfare of the sort which concerns Senator Grimes, it has certainly been no part of the Government's role to mount an attack on welfare. For my part, any denigration of the poor would be a particularly reprehensible activity and something of which I would have no part. There are some very difficult areas in the welfare field. I think there is sometimes some very confused thinking about the nature of the debate which ought to take place. I think it is a pity that this debate today probably will not provide a vehicle for the examination of some of the broad and difficult issues which will face Australia if we are to try to ensure a more equal and more just society.

As Senator Grimes managed only at the very end of his speech to address himself to some of the possible solutions to the problems about which he expressed concern, I do not think that we will get a wide-ranging debate on the correct economic and other policies which will do something to ensure that Australians are as well off as possible. There are very difficult questions in the taxation field. There are questions of reliance on direct or indirect taxation and of whether we should have capital gains and wealth taxes in this country. They are matters which, we are told by the Sydney Morning Herald, have been wiped from the political agenda because neither the Australian Labor Party nor the Liberal Party of Australia embraces the idea of taxes on capital. Reasons for that were explored by that newspaper recently in a way which I think made a very good contribution to the debate about inequality of incomes and so on in Australia. Apparently all of those matters are off the agenda, both for this debate and, indeed, for debates in the foreseeable future.

Other matters which perhaps need attention, if we are to direct this question, include the question of whether we would better achieve our social objectives by the provision of universal benefits or by directive measures; that is, by means or income-tested measures. Again, these are very difficult questions. There are a variety of views, even among those who, I think, would identify themselves as the welfare lobby. The recent reports from Victoria suggest, for example, that there are problems in income or means-tested benefits which are best avoided. Some of the problems were explored in an intelligent way by Mr Forell in the Melbourne Age, I think this morning or yesterday morning.

There are difficulties with respect to the means or income testing of benefits. Those difficulties can be got round by providing universal benefits. But there are very large questions about whether Australia or Australians are prepared to contribute the levels of either taxation or contributions called by a name other than taxation, if we get into the field of national superannuation, which will support a level of universal benefits that will be adequate to remove any traces of poverty from this community. They are genuine and difficult questions which would face any government in this country. They are questions which do not admit to easy answers and do not admit to absolutely right answers; rather, they admit to possible differences of approach which need to be explored, tested and drawn out so that the people of Australia can, along with their governments, make sensible choices for the future.

I was pleased to hear Senator Grimes's acknowledgment, towards the end of his speech, that the matters of employment and unemployment are basic to these questions that are raised in the debate today. That means that we are entitled to ask what sorts of policies are likely to affect that key factor in terms of who is likely to be poor in Australia and who is not? Is it a fact, for example, that more taxation will encourage employment, or will more taxation tend to increase unemployment and, hence, social need and difficulty? Is greater government spending likely to be helpful or unhelpful? Some history within the last 10 years in this country suggests that a mere expansion of government spending may not, of itself, be helpful to creating employment but may, indeed, create the conditions for disemployment. I refer to 1974 in particular.

There are serious questions about whether a larger deficit or an easier money supply would in the short term or in the long term produce more or less employment. These are serious questions for government and I would address them in this debate in the short time which is available merely by saying that the economic policies of this Government have always been directed to achieving the maximum sustainable levels of employment in Australia because we accept that that is a matter which goes very centrally to the welfare of Australians.

Another important question which is raised in this area is: What are the causes of the claimed increased need in this community? I think it is instructive to look at what the reports state, whether they be reports from the groups in Victoria which have recently published reports from the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat which published a report on poverty measurement recently or reports from Professor Henderson's group. I think it is instructive that all of those indicators point to the same thing, namely, that increased unemployment and an increasing number of single parent families are very significant factors in increasing the hardship within the community. I have just addressed the matter of economic policy and the policies which are most likely to reduce unemployment and to keep employment as high as possible. But I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that we have a situation in which there is an ever-increasing number of sole parent families. Those sole parent families are the result of personal choices by members of the Australian community. Those choices are creating real hardship for the families involved. That is a matter which is giving rise to greatly increased government expenditure and taxpayer contribution. There appears to be no end to that in sight.

I want to refer to a couple of matters concerning the report on emergency relief in Victoria. That report, along with the other reports which have been issued, has been put to study in my Department because, of course, we are anxious to learn what those reports can tell us. My advice, which is very preliminary advice, is that the report on emergency relief does not actually quantify changes in the size of the population needing relief. What it does is infer an increase based on the premise that agency expenditures increased by nearly 100 per cent between 1978 and 1981 with the actual units of payment being made dropping. Of course, it also draws upon the experience of people in the field such as Captain Berris, who was quoted by Senator Grimes. But I think we can accept that the agencies which are in the field are having increasing demands made upon them and that they are having increasing difficulty in meeting those demands.

Despite the conclusion that frequency of requests is increasing the report does not adduce substantial evidence of that. If honourable senators look at table 10 of the report-I suggest that honourable senators who are interested do that-they will find that, rather than it demonstrating that there has been an increase in the frequency with which people are seeking emergency relief, it demonstrates that the position was relatively stable between the period when the previous study was done in 1978 and the period when the studies whose results were recently released were done. We find that in the 1978 study 55 per cent of those who sought emergency relief had previously had emergency relief. The figure in the more recent reports is 55.9 per cent. In the 1978 study-to complete those figures-45 per cent had not had previous assistance. The figure was 44.1 per cent in 1981.

A relative stability has been shown in the actual figures which have been produced. We rely on oral evidence, apparently, to draw a different conclusion. The analysis of the peak December-January period shows that 85 per cent of recipients emergency relief were going to an agency for the first time. So during that period a great number of the people were simply first time seekers of emergency relief. In that sense the report does not offer firm evidence to support the contention that the role of emergency relief agencies has changed in relation to the frequency with which they make relief payments to the same clients.

Another fairly important point from the point of view of determining what is the best approach to meeting the problems that the claims for emergency relief evidence is the fact that, whilst a great majority of claimants are recipients of pensions and benefits from my Department, the figures indicate that some 94 per cent of the clients of my Department do not seek additional assistance. In other words, the figure disclose that approximately 6 per cent of recipients of benefits from the Department of Social Security seek emergency relief, if the figures, such as they are, are reliable. The significance of that is that, if one is concerned about that group of people in the community who are unable to manage or who are requiring additional assistance from their fellow citizens, to approach the problems of a minority of pensioners and beneficiaries on the basis that all pensions and benefits should be substantially increased is to approach them in a very expensive way. I think that is a matter which needs very careful consideration, given that the overall approach is likely to be extremely expensive.

Many welfare groups come to me and put propositions that various levels of average weekly earnings are the appropriate targets for which the Government should aim. Currently, for example, it is suggested that we should increase pensions and benefits to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings with a long term aim of increasing them to 30 per cent of average weekly earnings. I proffer the comment that that is a very expensive way of trying to meet the problem of that minority of people who are unable to live on present pensions and benefits. The cost of going to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings would be $870m. That would be an additional $870m at current prices. To go to 30 per cent of average weekly earnings would cost $2.7 billion. I very much doubt whether a government, be it a government in which the Minister for Social Security was Senator Grimes or in which I was the Minister for Social Security, would see its way clear to increase those payments by an amount which would add to personal income tax at the rate of about $10 per week per taxpayer.

I suggest that the figures disclosed by the report-that a relatively small proportion seek that additional assistance-suggest that we should be approaching the problem in a way which tries to define the people who are in that difficult situation and directing assistance to them rather than universally increasing levels of assistance at very much greatly increased cost to all taxpayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that on the basis that we are 23 per cent now?

—It is on the basis that we are something under 23 per cent now. It is calculated on the basis of recent figures. A point was also raised concerning where responsibility lies in this area. That is a matter which I find distasteful to debate for obvious reasons because it is distasteful to be arguing about who is responsible while there are areas of real need. But it is a fact that the Commonwealth accepts the very broad responsibility for income maintenance. Presently my Department is spending about $10 billion a year. Next year I have little doubt that, with no change at all, the bill will go up well in excess of $1 billion. We have accepted very broad responsibilities to literally millions of Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: Traditionally, meeting the short term or emergency needs of people who are in difficulty has been the responsibility of State and private agencies. That had always been so in Australia until a couple of years ago when this Government took the initiative of making a limited amount of money-just under half a million dollars-available to agencies in that field. I think it is important that the responsibilities of the Commonwealth should be met by the Commonwealth and that we should avoid the Commonwealth seeking to pick up the responsibilities of States in these areas and thus reducing its ability to do its own work well. The more widely we spread our effort the less effectively can we do the job. I am, therefore, against a substantial shift of responsibility from the States to the Commonwealth in any area in which traditionally States had responsibility. The shifts tend to be in the other direction.

For example, in 1980, at their instance, the States ceased having responsibility for the maintenance of deserted wives for the first six months of desertion. Prior to that time the State welfare departments had the responsibility of looking after the income maintenance of women who had been deserted and left without support. The Commonwealth picked up that responsibility. Indeed there was a period when we shared that expense with the States. The States chose to pass that full responsibility to the Commonwealth in 1980. That meant a saving to the States of about $32m. There was an immediate assumption of new cost responsibility by the Commonwealth, a lifting of responsibility from the States and, I would have thought, a freeing up of welfare resources which should have made it easier for the States to meet their welfare obligations.

I suggest to the Senate that in considering where responsibility lies, whether it is for the relief of poverty or for the conduct of services generally, it is reasonable to expect the States to meet their traditional responsibilities and the Commonwealth to meet its responsibilities. The $500,000 which we pay to voluntary agencies is a very small proportion of assistance in this field. I do not believe that that very small amount should be used as a lever to suggest that all other agencies, be they State or private, have thereby given up their responsibility in this area.

The Commonwealth has a continuing commitment to an adequate income maintenance system. I take this debate to be an important debate on areas in which we might find inadequacies. I point to our continuing major commitment to indexation, which is a needs-based policy which Professor Henderson said was basic to the maintenance of the welfare system. That is costing the Australian taxpayer between $700m and $800m a year, and is an important part of our commitment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The matter of public importance under consideration today concerns the increasing number of citizens needing emergency relief because of inadequate income and services. This was a concern which lay behind Notice of Motion No. 45 in the name of Senator Don Chipp which was introduced into the Senate last week. This notice of motion, in part, states:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the Government is failing in its responsibility to provide adequate income support for Australian families and single people in need and that the Government should consider the following measures as a matter of urgency, but no later than in the Budget for the year 1982-83 . . .

At the moment I do not want to go into what those following measures were but I will do so a little later because I have never been one who likes to disappoint the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney)-heaven knows. A little later in the debate I want to specify not only where the measures should be taken but also how they can be paid for. The rest of Senator Chipp's notice of motion went on to identify the Australian Democrats' list of priorities, together with certain taxation reforms designed to ensure that the additional funds necessary would be made available. I do not think anybody in this country is not aware of the fact that there is an alarming increase in the number of people seeking emergency relief from voluntary agencies. There are plenty of statistics to show that that is so. The Salvation Army, for instance, has seen the number of its interviews for emergency aid per month jump by 235 per cent since September 1979 .

According to the report of the Victorian Council of Social Service 80 per cent of people seeking emergency relief did so while receiving government pensions or benefits. A further 12 per cent had no income at the time of applying for relief , and most of those were awaiting a Department of Social Security payment. The proportion of those seeking relief while in receipt of the unemployment benefit has increased from 17.2 per cent in 1978 to 28.2 per cent in 1982, or almost one -third. If those are the available statistics on those who in fact are seeking relief, one wonders just what exactly the situation is with regard to people who have not yet, for one reason or another, been forced formally to seek relief from a voluntary agency, as happened in the case of the invalid pensioner I saw in my office last Friday.

This man was dressed as well as he could afford to be, although his attire was rather shabby. He was a quiet man who still retained a certain semblance of his dignity. He has a wife who is also an invalid pensioner. He said-I believe him when he gave me some written evidence a little later in the interview-that he budgeted strictly each year allowing for, as much as his crystal ball gazing would let him, whatever inflationary trends were likely to eat away at his income. Yet, as he pointed out to me, increased charges for electricity, interest, oil heating, gas, telephone and water rates et cetera in the past 12 months have resulted in his being almost $400 over budget, even allowing for increases in his pension. He gave me a letter in support of his claims. It stated:
. . . I am including a figure of what all these extra costs are estimated to be this coming year.

He estimates increases of $108 in his electricity charges, $90 in his gas charge , $30 increase in his telephone costs, and $30 in water rates. His cost of living has gone up, he said, by $600 and his interest rates have gone up by $130 , and that is assuming that there are no further interest rate increases this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is he buying a house?

—That is not a sin. A lot of people are trying to buy a house. Yes, he is buying a house, but even assuming he were not he would still have to pay for rental, and that is increasing as interest rates go up. In his letter he goes on to state:

SPEECH.PARA: These are just six articles to give you an idea and this is not being extravagant as we budget very carefully.

Our debit in extra costs just on these six articles is $998.00 compared with Pension increases of $640.00 a full year, this means we will have to find $348. 00 some other way, the only way Senator is to cut down on food costs. Already we are struggling to have one good meal a day.

He was not begging; he simply came to see me to see whether there was some way I could get him out of the hole in which he appears to be. The point is that he as yet has not gone to an agency looking for assistance. He has not had to do that yet because he is fortunate enough to live in a neighbourhood in which people who can give do so when they can. If their pea crop is particularly good they hand some over. If they have stripped their apricot trees and made jam they hand over some bottles. If there is a glut of tomatoes he gets a few jars of chutney. That is the sort of thing that neighbours and friends do for neighbours and friends. It does not diminish the dignity of those people to the same extent as formally approaching an agency does, but it helps them along with their budget. I am not knocking that in any way at all. I think it is great to see that Australians still practise this form of economic mateship.

The man went on to say that he could no longer afford to insure or register his car. He did not see this car as a luxury, particularly as he and his wife are invalid pensioners and they find moving around in any other way rather difficult . He said that he and his wife were looking for other areas in which to save money. He made the point that he is a State superannuant and that this means that he and his wife get only part of a social security pension. He is considering asking that his cost of living allowance on his superannuation not be increased in order to retain the very essential concessions he gets with his part pension. I stress again that this man and his wife are not among the increasing number of unemployed people, single parents, pensioners or struggling families who are placing a heavy burden on all voluntary welfare agencies in this country. He is a hidden statistic.

The Age editorial of 20 April, on the other hand, had some very telling remarks to make about government income support schemes and their inadequacy and the need for this situation to be reversed. The editorial was terse, to the point of being rude, in some of the comments it made on a government which could allow this condition to develop. I am in no way questioning the Minister's commitment to supplying the needy with the services and income support that they need; I am questioning the whole Government's commitment to supplying these sorts of services and income support. I have said before-I will repeat it now-that I firmly believe that the Minister is a man of infinite compassion and understanding who is doing all he can to correct an invidious situation. Nevertheless, the Age editorial was prepared to say--

The document read as follows-
BEGGARS, BUT NOT BY CHOICE

In 1978 a report on emergency relief prepared by a voluntary agency, the Action Research Centre, appeared under the title: ''Life Wasn't Meant to Be Impossible' '. Unfortunately, as an increasing number of Australians are discovering, life in present-day Australia is, if not impossible, at least extraordinarily difficult. Those who are feeling the pinch most are those who always suffer when times are bad: the unemployed, single or deserted mothers, large families and pensioners (particular invalid pensioners). More and more, they are being forced to beg for assistance from welfare agencies because their Government welfare payments-particularly those which are not indexed-have failed to keep pace with the rises in living costs.

Proof of this is to be found in a report prepared by the Victorian Council of Social Service and released yesterday. It shows that the demand for emergency relief from people in Victoria without food or money almost trebled last year. In the first six months of 1981 there were 13,335 requests for cash or food, compared with 5,013 during the same period in 1980. Significantly, 80 per cent of those seeking emergency relief did so while at the same time receiving Government pensions and benefits. Where emergency relief was once regarded as a one-off payment to meet a financial crisis, the report says voluntary agencies are now being asked to supplement income permanently for an increasing number of people who are living in a chronic state of poverty, punctuated by periodic crises.

While the report is confined to Victoria, there is no reason to believe that the situation it documents is peculiar to this State. Indeed a report by the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat on poverty six months ago found that 1.7 million Australians were living below the Henderson poverty line. Even after applying more stringent tests to the concept of poverty, the secretariat found that 1.06 million, plus another 130,000 juveniles living away from home, were living in poverty. Increasingly Australia is becoming a divided society. The gap between the haves and the have-nots is growing, partly as a result of weaknesses in the tax system; and more and more people-particularly the young-are being excluded from a fair opportunity to share in the country's wealth.

While this should be a matter of concern to Governments, both State and Federal , there is little evidence that this is in fact the case. On the contrary, both have been locked in a constitutional argument over responsibility for those in need. The short answer is that both are responsible, and both can assist. Ensuring income security for the disadvantaged in our society should not be left to the voluntary welfare agencies. The Federal Government, for its part, should as a matter of urgency re-examine the whole range of pensions and benefits. Old age and invalid pensions have been indexed since 1977. But unemployment benefits and benefits paid to single parents (such as the children's and guardians' allowances) are reviewed each year, and as a result have fallen well behind the cost of living. The benefit for unemployed 15 to 17-year-olds, for example, has been frozen at $36 for the past five years. The Government argues that to give them more would encourage them not to work. Yet as the Victorian Council of Social Service report showed, people on unemployment benefits were the major group seeking emergency relief. If the Government cannot find work for them, or sustain a buoyant economy, it should at least ensure that they don't starve.

Welfare payments have increased markedly in the past 10 years. Nonetheless there are still areas of pressing need-single parents and the deserving unemployed especially-and the next Budget should see a substantial increase in their welfare payments. At the same time the Government should seriously consider the suggestion made by the Minister for Trade and Commerce, Sir Phillip Lynch, during the Lowe by-election-that the means test should be re-introduced for all age pensions and other social security benefits. It is neither socially just nor equitable that social security benefits should be available to many thousands of well-off middle-class people who do not need them while hundreds of thousands of other Australians live in poverty.

The State Government, for its part, could help by providing gas and electricity subsidies or concessions to those receiving pensions or benefits. In its policy speech the Victorian ALP promised to extend to single parents the present pensioner concessions, such as reduced rates and fares on public transport. There is scope for extending this kind of help. Ultimately, the aim must be to find ways of ensuring income security for all Australians. It is a moral responsibility which no Government, whatever its political coloring, can avoid.

SPEECH.PARA: Professor Else Oyen, a professor from the University of Bergen in Norway, who was the Australian Broadcasting Commission's guest of honour on 27 July 1980, had this to say:

Many years ago, during the first few years of this century, people from all over the world travelled to Australia to look with awe and admiration at the Australian welfare state. Here was the cradle of solidarity with less fortunate citizens. Here was the concern with society, responsibility for all its members and the willingness to take responsibility for that concern. A series of welfare programmes saw the daylight, like the old age pension, the invalid pension, maternity allowances, as well as a state arbitration system.

Needless to say, Professor Oyen was bitterly disappointed to find that in 1980 large and persistent poverty gaps had not been closed and appeared to have widened. Levels of benefit had been condemned by not being sufficiently adjusted to allow for inflation and welfare rights had not been established for the population at large. Far from establishing such rights, this Government has established a large and growing proportion of people who are completely dependent upon social security payments, not just for days or for weeks but for months and for years.

In 1973 we were shocked by the findings of the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty, which told us that the poorest Australians were those in single- parent families. There are now about 200,000 lone parent pensioners in Australia , many of them condemned to long term dependency and long term poverty. June 1981 figures show that 87 per cent of supporting parents had no additional income or received less than $20 additional income a week and 77 per cent of A- class widows were in a similar situation. There is no incentive for these women to take poorly paid part time jobs because the penalty on lost pension, lack of child care at reasonable cost and lack of school and vocational care create insuperable problems. The cost to the community of 80,000 B-class widows is a direct consequence of the unemployability of women who have been out of the work force for decades and whose re-entry is apparently not the concern of the Government. The future social costs to this country of children whose only experience has been of poverty and privation is likely to be substantial. Current costs are homelessness, alcohol and drug dependency, alienation, psychological disturbance, despair and suicide. These are already with us.

At the second Poverty Inquiry Conference in Melbourne in September 1980 Professor Henderson identified growth in unemployment as his reason for poverty being so much worse than it was in 1973. This produced three main effects on the taxpayers and on the Government decisions that were being made. He made three additional points: Firstly a check on the growth of real wages in an attempt to reduce the rate of inflation and an increasing reluctance to pay taxes to provide income maintenance for the poor; secondly, a compounding effect of slow economic growth while the numbers of pensioners and beneficiaries continue to increase-subsequently, a reduction in the real value of the unemployment benefit and the family allowance while prices and costs continue to rise-and, thirdly, the wave of reaction against taxation and government expenditure which has restrained the growth of public employment in the service sector while the manufacturing industry has not taken up the slack.

Do Australians really understand what lobbyists are talking about when they call for tax cuts across the board? As the value of each welfare dollar has diminished the number of applications for aid has increased by leaps and bounds. It has more than doubled over the last two or three years. A suburban financial counselling centre in Western Australia reports a trebling of calls on its facilities over the three years of its existence under the family support scheme . This service has had some money available for relief but it will have none after 30 June this year. The one below-award salary provided for this project is shared by two overworked counsellors, another common and deplorable consequence of inadequate funding policies.

Despite Federal Government contributions since 1979, emergency relief is still very largely dependent upon private and voluntary funds. Government funding of all types in Victoria has been identified as providing 23.75 per cent of the total funding-that included State and local funding-in 1981-82. Because the problem is so diverse and because it is impossible to say how much and how many people are affected and exactly who are those in need of emergency relief, one is certainly very optimistic about the fact that emphasis has now been given by the Government to the need actually to identify the answers to these problems.

In 1976 and 1977 the main causes of need for emergency help were cyclical or truly emergency ones related to particular localities where manufacturing industry had been forced to close down, where industrial disputes had deprived people of income for a period, or where particular geographical and locational factors were involved. This changed in 1979-80, becoming endemic rather than epidemic. The Western Australian Council of Social Service received funding from the Western Australian Department for Community Welfare to employ someone to commence a similar system of identification which not only will establish an emergency relief uniform recording system but also will facilitate the co- ordination of existing services. Most of the money available is private as distinct from public but it is rapidly drying up. As we were told today, the Salvation Army has had to reduce from $16 to $10 its average payment for food relief. Some of the trust funds work in a rather discretionary fashion. Their practices could be identified as punitive and sometimes bureaucratic. They are certainly slow moving. I know of families who have been evicted while the fund that had been approached was making up its mind whether to help with the rent arrears which were the cause of the eviction. It has been described to me that money from these funds simply keeps the masses off the streets and provides a supplementary dole system.

The effect on individuals is cumulative degradation, loss of dignity, loss of power over decision-making, marital tension, enforced relocation which amounts to dislocation, insecurity and loss of personal direction. Those who seek financial counselling are not suffering from mismanagement, despite the impression that Senator Walters has apparently gained in her State; they are suffering from lack of money and in many cases the condition is chronic. The people who are most at risk have no reserves to cope with unexpected events such as sickness in the family, rental rises, escalating electricity, gas and water charges or a death in the family. I am glad to hear that 94 per cent of pensioners are coping but the other 6 per cent still constitutes many people. They are those who are repeatedly being seen by the assistance agencies.

Other elements which certainly do not help families on very low incomes to cope are the lack of child care, which means that the individual responsible for the care of young children is unable to seek work; the lack of opportunity to work; the lack of training-this boils down again, I suppose, to the lack of jobs, the shortage of housing and the high prices that must be paid for housing. One supporting parent, whom I know with three children finds that her income is just sufficient to feed and house her family. Like many in a similar plight she has no resources of her own to call upon for electricity, gas or water rates. Like many, if emergency relief is not available, she and her children have to move in with relatives and the electricity and gas is cut off. The water supply is reduced to a dribble in Western Australia. The cost of reconnection is then an added burden on the funds. It is a common practice now for the emergency relief services to provide sufficient food for two weeks for a family so that the bills for electricity can be paid.

A recently widowed woman of 43 with no children who will be on unemployment benefit until she turns 50-she is unlikely to find a job after 20 years out of the work force-receives $116 a fortnight. She pays $70 a fortnight on her house- she is another one of these 'imprudent' people who happen to be paying for their own home, if I understand the interjections from the senators opposite. She pays $40 a fortnight for food and other essentials. She must allow $10 a fortnight for electricity. I think the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) would be well aware of the essential nature of that particular little budgeting strategy in Western Australia. She is already $4 overspent on her benefit every fortnight and has no money with which to repay her personal loan taken out to cover the expenses of her husband's illness and death.

Another widow, with a 16-year-old son, who will also be on unemployment benefit until aged 50, unless miraculously a job turns up, has been forced to leave her home and has now to pay $110 a fortnight rent out of her $116 a fortnight pension. No other rental accommodation is available for her. I again quote Else Oyen:

You firmly believe that Australia is one of the highest taxed countries in the world. This is hardly true. A recent survey of taxation in the 25 OECD countries shows that Australia is number 21 on the list.

We have a wretchedly inequitable collection and transferral system to try to move taxation from those who are comfortable in this wealthy society and to provide for a dignified standard of subsistence-let alone living-for increasing numbers of Australians. I am not convinced that decent, taxpaying Australians are satisfied with the present state of affairs. I join with those who call for a reformed tax system, the expansion of public sector 'human' services, immediate action not by emergency relief-life is one unremitting emergency for too many people-but by identifying those who are most vulnerable and assuring them of a decent income.

This provided assistance to some 300,000 families with 800,000 children who had rceived little or no help under the old arrangements. The 1981-82 Budget increased the allowance for large families, with the result that more than half a million families have been assisted, including nearly half the dependent children in the country.

In a similar endeavour to help those in needy groups the Government has increased the tax threshold since 1975-76 by 66 per cent to $4,195. It has increased the dependent spouse and sole parent rebates from $400 to $830 and from $200 to $580 respectively since 1975-76, which is an increase of more than 100 per cent. I would very much like to see an increase in the amount of tax rebate for a dependent spouse. I would like to see a more realistic taxation deduction. I would like to see the rebate of $830 increased, as somebody suggested, to $1,340 or a little bit more than that if possible. I suppose that it is easy enough to make suggestions. There has been an extension of public health benefits for sickness and supporting parents beneficiaries and there has been an extension of Commonwealth support for sole parents. It has introduced automatic twice-yearly indexation of pensions in line with consumer price index increases to ensure that pensioners are protected against inflation. This has meant that the standard rate of pension has risen by over 70 per cent since 1976. Unfortunately, of course, costs have also risen substantially in that time. The change from a means test on assets to a test on income only has meant that the number of individuals eligible to receive government assistance has increased. This initiative has assisted many people who were disadvantaged under the old system and has enabled them to obtain some pension support.

The Government outlay for social welfare has increased from $6,367m when the present Government came to office in 1975-76 to $11,357m. It has almost doubled. It now amounts to almost 28 per cent of the 1981-82 Budget outlay. That is a lot of money in anybody's language. Assistance to the aged has increased from $2.2 billion in 1975-76 to $4 billion in 1980-81, and a further increase to $4.6 billion is estimated for 1981-82. The Government has raised the upper limits at which people may receive some pension payment from $61.90 to $159.40 per week for a single person and by $103.40 to $266.90 per week for a married couple. These limits change in accordance with CPI increases.

All of these initiatives show the commitment of the Fraser Government to maintaining the position of those individuals who are solely or almost totally dependent on the pension. The tapered income test which replaced the old means test has been a step towards ensuring that those in greatest financial need receive the greatest financial assistance, while at the same time offering some reward to others for self-help provision. I feel that there is something to be said for allowing permissible earnings of pensioners to be $50 a week. I think that is a step that the Government could take. I am sure that it would be very helpful to pensioners. We would have to be careful that this allowance did not put pensions into the tax bracket, but I am quite sure that our Treasurer (Mr Howard) will take that into consideration in the next Budget. The Department of Social Security also provides an important range of welfare services directly to individuals and to organisations throughout Australia.

As well as providing these services, an important aspect of the operations of the Department of Social Security is its assistance through subsidy programs to State, local government and community organisations which provide services to people in need. The Federal Government outlayed $9.4m in subsidies to help fund a total of 128 projects under the handicapped persons welfare program. Under a three-year scheme a further $23m will be made available for approved projects. I have been associated with a project in the Woodridge area in which my son-in-law is very interested. Under that project help and therapy are given to handicapped people. The Lutheran Church also has such projects in Dalby and Southport. All churches are very much concerned with helping people in need. We must give thanks to all those who provide this assistance.

The program for accommodation and home care for aged and disabled people is designed to provide a wide range of care and services for the aged or disabled people and to ensure that their needs are being appropriately met. Under this program a three-year $225m funding scheme commenced on 1 July 1980. Over 670 projects providing over 13,000 beds were selected for funding. We have to be conscious of the fact that these days people seem to be living longer. There is certainly a great need for care for the aged. A great deal of this work is being done by churches and other organisations throughout Australia. Australia's first nursing home specifically designed for people with multiple sclerosis received approval under the program for a capital grant of almost $450,000. Expenditure on grants under the Aged or Disabled Person Homes Act during 1980-81 totalled $ 29.5m. In 1980-81 expenditure under the Aged Persons Hostels Act totalled $16.2m . These are large amounts of money and when added together they make a very significant contribution.

The Commonwealth makes grants under the Homeless Persons Assistance Act towards the capital and operating costs of voluntary welfare organisations and local government bodies which provide accommodation, meals and welfare services to homeless people. I think that I have given a fair resume of what this Government has been doing. I think it is something that we should remember.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has a very good record.

—It certainly has, and it can stand on its record too. Another matter that I wish to mention concerns the unemployment benefit and the amount of money made available by the Government to people who are out of work and who certainly need to be given help. This form of assistance cost $1 billion last year.
—But those under 18 have not had a right for six years.

—According to the information that I have it is certainly a large amount of money. Unfortunately, in some cases people collect this money more than once. I feel that in this area a system of identity cards would be very important. With such a system we could at least be sure that the dole was given to people only once. In New Zealand, which I visited recently a system exists whereby local authorities provide help to make sure that people on the dole are working for the money that they get. I have told the Senate about the amounts of money allocated by this Government to welfare services, the unemployment benefit and other benefits. We must realise that this Government is ensuring that the community has the most efficient relief services possible.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has stated its policies clearly and has always acted on them. On the other hand, the Opposition has not. From statements that have appeared in the media recently, Senator Grimes appears to be at odds with his leader. The Sydney Morning Herald of 8 March points out that Senator Grimes supports an assets test while Mr Hayden, in an interview on the Mike Walsh Show on the same day, stated that the Australian Labor Party wanted to improve, not restrict, access to benefits. A report that Senator Grimes supports an assets and an income test appeared in the Australian of 9 March. I think that before members of the Opposition declare that the Fraser Government is not doing enough in the social security area and that the ALP could do better, they should all get together and firstly agree on what they would do. They have already caused unnecessary worry and anxiety to thousands of Australians, firstly with Mr Hayden's reference to a wealth test and, secondly, with Senator Grimes's talk about both an income and an assets test. We read in today's Press that the number of positions in the Department of Social Security is to be increased by 580 for the 1981-82 year. Surely, at a time of Government cut-backs and reductions, this is proof of this Government's commitment to help those in our community who are less able to cope. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The Bill before the Senate will make important changes to both the Health Insurance Act and the National Health Act.

Firstly, Mr President, the Senate will be pleased to know that the National Health Act will be amended to authorise the provision, by the Commonwealth, of free vaccine for immunisation against the disease of mumps. The inclusion of a mumps vaccine at Commonwealth expense in the immunisation programs presently conducted by the States and Territories complies with the principles of good public health and is an indication of the Government's continuing concern to safeguard and improve public health.

It is proposed, Mr President, to substitute a combined measles/mumps vaccine for the measles vaccine currently being provided. The combined vaccine will be administered to children at 12 months of age in accordance with the childhood immunisation schedule recommended by the National Health and Medical Research Council.

It is anticipated that around 342,000 children will be immunised in a full year with the new vaccine. At today's prices of $4.65 per dose, the Government will be contributing $1.5m a year to the new immunisation program. Although this will , in part, be offset by the phasing out of the single measles vaccine, the additional expenditure at to-day's prices will be in the order of $1m each year.
I turn now to the proposed changes to the health insurance arrangements.

Honourable senators will be aware of the considerable attention that has recently been focused on what is commonly described as medical benefits fraud by medical practitioners. This Bill contains new measures which will present a very strong deterrent against such abuse.

It is now possible to estimate, from statistics compiled by my Department, that the extent of fraud and overservicing by some members of the medical profession is of the order of at least $100m a year in medical benefits, of which about half is attributable to fraud and half to overservicing. My references to fraud relate to such matters as making claims for services that were not provided, whereas my references to overservicing relate to the provision of services which were not reasonably necessary.

Before proceeding to outline the provisions relation to fraud I wish to emphasise that it is the Government's view that it is a minority of the medical profession who are abusing the health insurance system. It is for that reason that I believe these provisions will have the support of the great majority of medical practitioners.

In commercial terms, medical practitioners are in a virtually unique position. The financial structure of their practices is largely underwritten by the medical benefits scheme which is publicly financed through both taxation and medical benefits fund contributions. Furthermore, most patients are generally not in a position to question the correctness of medical accounts. The operation of the medical benefits scheme is therefore very heavily dependent upon the trustworthiness of medical practitioners.

The existing health insurance legislation already contains provisions for penalties in the form of imprisonment or fines to be imposed by the courts on practitioners found to have committed medical benefits fraud. However, those provisions do not take into account what might be termed the commercial aspects of such fraud. Furthermore, there are sometimes substantial practical difficulties faced by the prosecution in obtaining what might reasonably be considered to be adequate penalties in medical benefits fraud cases.

The Government considers that a medical practitioner who has been proved to have committed medical benefits fraud on two or more charges is guilty of a most serious breach of trust and should be dealt with accordingly. It believes that this serious breach of trust warrants the exclusion of that practitioner from the financial benefits of the medical benefits arrangements for a substantial period. Accordingly, this Bill contains provisions under which services by a practitioner who has been found by a court to have committed medical benefits fraud on two or more charges will not attract payment of medical benefits for a period of 3 years.

I must emphasise that there will be adequate provision for appeal. First, in relation to the initial findings by the court, the practitioner has the usual rights of appeal to a higher court. Furthermore, before a first disqualification for medical benefit purposes comes into effect, the practitioner concerned may apply to the Minister for a review of the disqualification. During the course of any first period of disqualification, the practitioner may again seek a review of that disqualification by the Minister. The minister will be empowered, upon any such application, to modify the disqualification by several means, or a combination thereof, including:
a reduction of the period of disqualification from three years to some shorter period;
permitting the continued payment of medical benefits for certain specified types of services;
permitting the continued payment of medical benefits in respect of services to specified groups of persons or services in specified places (such as hospitals).

Provision will also be made allowing an appeal by a practitioner to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a review of a decision by the minister on an application made to him for modification of a disqualification.

I should point out to the Senate that the provisions which I have outlined above concerning ministerial reviews of disqualifications apply only in respect of a first period of disqualification. They do not apply to any subsequent disqualifications which may arise where the practitioner concerned has again had two or more medical benefits fraud offences proven.

The Bill provides for the publishing and laying before each House of Parliament of a statement setting out the details and effects of a practitioner's disqualification. There is also adequate provision made for patients of a disqualified practitioner to be advised of the particulars and effects of the disqualification.

I ask honourable senators to note that the provisions which I have outlined relate to cases of medical benefits fraud proven by due legal processes through courts of law. They are founded upon, and are limited to, the financial aspects of transactions through the medical benefits scheme and they stand apart from any penalties the courts may see fit to impose in relation to the criminal aspects of such cases. In order that the necessary supporting regulations and administrative arrangements may be made for the operation of these provisions, they will come into operation on a future date to be fixed by proclamation.

While the Government has given priority in this Bill to the problem of fraud, it is also very concerned at the extent of overservicing that is believed to occur. It intends therefore to review the existing legislation relating to overservicing and take whatever measures are shown to be necessary to control this other area of abuse.
The Bill also includes provisions of an administrative nature, concerning the issue of health care cards to people in the low income category as defined in the health insurance act.

Currently, the legislation provides for the making of a declaration that an eligible person having a low income is a disadvantaged person. Such a declaration operates for a period of 6 months and enables the person to obtain concessions under the health insurance arrangements. The person is deemed under the legislation to have lodged a further application for a declaration of disadvantaged person status at the end of the 6 months period. However, this has the practical disadvantage that a new declaration can only give continuous disadvantaged person status retrospectively. The amendment provided for in the Bill will enable the assessment of eligibility for continued disadvantge person status to be carried out over the last four weeks of the six months period and thus for a new declaration to be made before the end of that period.

Recently, Mr President, medical practitioners have been moving towards incorporation of their practices under company laws in order to gain certain benefits in relation to superannuation and to limit their personal liability for damages.

My Department has been involved in deliberations with representatives of the profession and with other interested organisations to ensure that, in relation to health benefits matters, the incorporation of medical practices does not affect the personal responsibility of practitioners for their services, and that they continue to be individually subject to the provisions of the health insurance legislation relating to the making of false statements and claims and the provision of excessive services.

In principle, the Australian Medical Association has made quite clear its position on maintaining the personal professional responsibility of medical practitioners to their patients, whether or not they are employees of incorporated medical practices.

It is consistent with this approach that a practitioner who provides a service to a patient ought to be personally identified on any documents used in connection with the claiming of benefits. Accordingly, the Bill before the Senate provides that Commonwealth medical benefits are not payable in respect of a service unless these documents contain information to be prescribed by regulations. This will enable the making of regulations requiring accounts, receipts and assignment forms to bear the name of the individual practitioner who has provided the service and other associated information.

Also consistent with the principle of personal accountability of practitioners are the provisions of this Bill which aim to ensure that, in the emerging situation of incorporation of medical practices, or in other employment situations, individual practitioners will continue to be subject to existing provisions concerning irregularities in connection with claims for medical benefits and controls over the provision of excessive services attracting medical benefits.

The proposed new provisions will provide that, where a practitioner is an employee of an incorporated practice or some other type of employer, both he and the practice or other employer will be accountable in relation to the making of false statements or claims in respect of medical benefits.

In relation to overservicing-that is, claiming medical benefits for medical services that are not reasonably necessary-the existing legislation provides for a system of medical services committees of inquiry. These committees are able to make recommendations that practitioners who are found to have provided excessive services should be counselled, reprimanded or required to repay benefits. The provisions of this Bill will ensure that, in proceedings before such committees of inquiry, practitioners employed by incorporated practices or other types of employers cannot, in effect, shield behind alleged directions by the incorporated practice or other employer. The incorporated practice or other employer will also be subject to the operation of these committees. However, in a case of incorporated practices, the other practitioners who are not directly involved, will not be affected as individuals.

Honourable senators will be aware that the basic registration of medical practitioners to practise is effected under State and Territory laws. Responsibility for ensuring the personal accountability of practitioners to their patients insofar as clinical procedures are concerned, is primarily a matter for the State and Territory authorities. For this reason I am therefore consulting with my State and Northern Territory colleagues with an aim of obtaining, as far as practicable, appropriate co-ordination of their registration laws and those of the Commonwealth which are concerned with medical benefits.
The Bill also provides for time limits to be imposed on the lodgment of claims for commonwealth medical benefits.

Claims lodged by the public on the funds will no longer be automatically accepted for payment if the service was rendered prior to the introduction of current health arrangements and more than two years have elapsed between date of service and date of lodgment. The date the current health insurance arrangements came into operation is specified as 1 September 1981 and provision exists to vary this date in the event of future changes. It should be noted that there is no intention to impose a time limit on the lodgment of claims relating to services rendered within a current scheme.

A time limit will also be imposed for medical benefits claims where the doctor bills the Commonwealth direct. A claim will no longer be automatically accepted for payment by my Department if the claim is not lodged within six months of the service being provided.

At the discretion of the Minister for Health, the time limits referred to above may be extended where this is considered justified, particularly to avoid any hardship that may be caused to the claimant.
A period of grace of three months will be allowed after the legislation is enacted and before the restrictions are imposed.

As I have already indictaed, there is presently no time limit on the lodgment of a claim involving Commonwealth medical benefits. The major reasons for the imposition of time limits are the difficulties and costs currently experienced in processing 'old claims' and the opportunities for fraud and incorrect payment that the present system provides. It is hoped that in the future these problems will be substantially reduced.

Registered medical benefits organisations are currently required to lodge claims for reimbursement of Commonwealth medical benefits with my Department and also to provide such support information as is prescribed. A similar requirement exists for the organisations to lodge claims for advance payments of Commonwealth medical benefits. Such claims are required to be accompanied by certain information including prescribed information about earlier advances.

The Bill presently before the Senate provides that the form and the manner in which the required information is to be provided in support of claims for reimbursements or advances, may be prescribed by regulations. It is intended that the regulations will specify the manner and form by reference to the media on which the information is to be recorded-for example, disc, magnetic tape or film-as well as the format for the data and the actual information content for each item of data.

Information is currently supplied in a non-standard fashion which has required my Department to operate expensive manual and computerised systems. For this reason it is considered, in the interests of economy and efficiency, that the new provisions are necessary.

Section 106AA of the Health Insurance Act presently provides for the publication of the particulars of determinations made by the Minister for Health in accordance with the report of a medical services committee of inquiry on alleged cases of overservicing on the part of medical practitioners. As a further means of discouraging such improper practices, Mr President, clause 26 of the Bill will amend section 106AA to require the Minister to prepare a statement setting out the particulars of any such determination and have a copy of it laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of its preparation.

Clause 31 of the Bill makes a similar amendment to section106G of the Health Insurance Act which contains similar provisions relating to the reports of optometrical services committees of inquiry. Again a statement setting out the particulars of any determination by the Minister will be required to be laid before both Houses of Parliament.

The Bill, Mr President, will also make important changes to section 130 of the Health Insurance Act. This section concerns the divulging and release of information obtained by a Commonwealth officer in the performance of his duties under the Act. It is believed that these proposed changes will, amongst other things, greatly assist the Government's attempts to combat and discourage the instances of fraud, overservicing and other improper practices to which I have previously referred.

The present provisions of section 130 are mainly concerned with maintaining the confidentiality of information, concerning the affairs of other persons, which is acquired by officers in the performance of their duties under the Act. May I take this opportunity of re-affirming the Government's continued belief in and support of this very important principle.

The Government also believes, however, that in order to assist in the discouragement of the sort of improper practices to which I have just referred and the effective administration of other Commonwealth or State Acts, provision should be made to allow the release, by my Department, to specific persons or authorities, of information relating to these matters.

The amendments to section 130 will therefore allow the release of information concerning the conviction of a person on charges of fraud under the Act, to the Commonwealth Departments of Social Security and Veterans' Affairs, specified State authorities and personnel and authorised personnel of registered health insurance organisations. The new provisions will also allow the release to these persons of information considered to be relevant to, respectively, the administration of an Act administered by either the Department of Social Security or Veterans' Affairs, the administration of a specified law of a State or Territory, or the carrying on of the business of a specified registered health insurance organisation, whichever the case may be.

These provisions do not open the way for indiscriminate use of information concerning the affairs of individual members of the public. Protection of the identity of individual persons will be maintained except in cases where the person has been convicted of an offence under the health insurance legislation or where the Minister has reasonable grounds for suspecting that the person has committed, or been a party to, such an offence. Furthermore, persons under the control of any recipient organisations or authorities shall not divulge information made available by my Department except in the performance of their official duties within that organisation.
I now turn to the amendments to the National Health Act.

Honourable senators will be aware that, under the new health funding arrangements, States and Territories generally have the responsibility for determining levels of public hospital charges. However, the levels of public hospital charges, and the related benefits, are a significant factor in determining basic hospital contribution rates.

As a general principle, the benefit available from basic hospital insurance should generally cover the charges raised by public hospitals, provided the charges do not bear too heavily on the hospital insurance system, and, therefore , on contributions to the basic hospital tables.

The amendments to the Act extend the existing power of the Minister for Health to declare standard hospital inpatient fees for hospital benefit purposes to cover professional and outpatient service fees for which basic hospital benefits are also payable. They will ensure a consistent approach by the Commonwealth in this area and, at the same time, provide a mechanism for the Commonwealth to protect the interests of contributors where hospital charges raised conflict with Commonwealth policy or would increase basic hospital table contribution rates to an unreasonable extent.
The Bill also proposes the conferring on the Minister of an additional power to control management practices of registered health benefits organisations.

The Government has always maintained a policy of minimum interference in the internal administration of registered health benefits organisations. It also believes that healthy competition in the industry promotes efficiency, assists in keeping contribution rates at minimum levels and, therefore, is in the best interests of contributors. These views remain unchanged. It is believed, however , that a broad power to deal with inappropriate management practices would be desirable. As the National Health Act currently stands, there are provisions that may be used in relation to specific instances of undesirable management practices, but only on an ad hoc basis.

In addition to conferring powers to deal with inappropriate management practices, the new provisions will authorise the Minister to issue directions to a registered organisation, other than a friendly society, prohibiting it from carrying on business other than business as a registered organisation.

A further minor amendment proposed in the Bill relates to the processing of rule changes of registered health benefits organisations under the National Health Act. The Minister's power to approve changes to rules relating to benefits and conditions for the payment of benefits for non-basic tables will be extended to cover existing tables as well as new tables. However, the overall policy of allowing organisations considerable scope for innovation and flexibility in relation to non-basic health insurance benefits cover would not be affected.

The Government has for some time now viewed with concern the various problems that have necessitated many of the amendments proposed in this Bill. These proposals have been foreshadowed for some considerable time and will receive, I believe, the full support of the Australian people. Much careful thought and planning has gone into their preparation.

Overall, Mr President, I firmly believe that the Bill contains important provisions which will be of great assistance in ensuring that the provision of health care in this country remains as efficient, equitable, cost-effective and free from abuse as possible.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

This Bill amends the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 to provide a mechanism for Australia to introduce reciprocal countervailing duty measures.
Last November, following the countervailing action taken by the United States against Australian lamb exports, the Government announced that Australia would be introducing this amending legislation.

Specifically, the amendments will allow Australia to take reciprocal countervailing action in any case where another country applies countervailing duty against Australian exports without applying an injury test or using a concept of a subsidy broader than the concept currently embodied in the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act.
The United States legislation already contains provisions that have the same effect as the measures proposed in this Bill.

Problems were created for Australia last year when America threatened countervailing duty action against Australian lamb exports without applying the necessary 'injury test' and adopting a broader definition of a 'subsidy' to that currently contained in the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act.

The difficulty with America has been overcome for the time being as a result of a bilateral understanding with that country. This understanding was made on the basis of Australia joining the Subsidies and Countervailing Duties Code and, consequently, the 'injury test' is now accorded to Australian exports by the United States.

The Government however, has indicated that it will review its membership of the Code in the light of experience and the option of considering withdrawal from the Code remains open. Accordingly, the decision to join the Code does not negate the adoption of the principle of reciprocity in relation to countervailing duty actions by Australia.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Committee stage of the debate on the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill 1982 in the House of Representatives on 22 April, as reported on page 1801 of Hansard the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner ) quoted a passage from a published paper of mine which, he claimed, supported the Government's argument on voluntary unionism.
