To the extent that the Minister purported then to describe my full argument, his account was a perverted caricature. In order to set the record straight and, perhaps, also because it will assist any proposed select committee in its deliberations on this matter-although I detect some scepticism in the breast of Senator Chaney on that score-I seek leave to have the full text of my paper which was delivered on 20 June 1979 and published as Monograph No. 9 of the Industrial Relations Society of Victoria incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
COMPULSORY UNIONISM AND CONSCIENTIOUS OBJECTION:
POLITICS, MORALITY AND THE CASE FOR LEGAL REFORM
Senator Gareth Evans

All lawyers-and most practitioners of industrial relations-know that there is no necessary connection between law, politics and morality. Very often the demands of each tug in different directions, with considerations of morality as often as not coming in a poor third. It is not always easy to reconcile conflicting attitudes and accommodate moral principles in a legal form which is universally acceptable, but it should always be the responsibility of legislators to try.

The present Commonwealth law on conscientious objection to trade union membership is embodied in S. 144A of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904, a new provision enacted by the Fraser Government in October 1977. Recent experience amply demonstrates that this law is far from being universally acceptable. It may be that the nature of conscientious objection claims is such that no law, however well drafted, can entirely eradicate disputes about them. But equally, it is not clear that any real attempt was made by the Government either to think through the issues of principle underlying the enactment of S. 144A or to take into account genuine differences of opinion which exist about the proper scope of any such clause. In what follows I shall attempt to sketch out, successively, the state of the present law, the different attitudes of those who are affected by it, and the considerations of morality or principle which in my view ought to govern its operation. The concluding section endeavours to pull the threads together and make some specific suggestions as to how the law should be changed to make it more generally acceptable. No-one should underestimate the difficulty and sensitivity of this task, but nor should anyone underestimate its urgency. Until the law is changed, conscientious objection will continue as an industrial relations minefield, capable of exploding at any time.
Present Commonwealth Law

Conscientious objection clauses were first introduced into the Conciliation and Arbitration Act in 1956, as part of the S. 47 preference provision. Under them a conscientious objection claim could not in any way be made at large: it had to be in the context of seeking exemption from the operation of a preference clause in an award. Nor were there any penal sanctions provided for unco-operative unions or employers.

Section 47 was not without its difficulties from the trade union point of view. It conferred no right upon unionists to participate in hearings before the Registrar, nor to appeal against a Registrar's decision to grant exempt status,1 nor was there any provision for revocation of exemption certificates once granted. But by and large S. 47 was uncontroversial in its practical operation. Not many applications were made-including renewal applications only 238, or an average of 11 per year over the whole period 1956-77-60% of these were granted.

The present S. 144A is a very different kind of provision. A number of features of the old S. 47 clauses are, it is true, retained: the description of ' conscientious beliefs' as including those which 'are or are not of a religious character'; the requirement that a successful applicant pay the equivalent amount of the union fee to consolidated revenue; the absence of any provision allowing participation by the trade union in proceedings before the Industrial Registrar; the absence of any revocation procedure; and the absence (indeed now explicit prohibition) of any right of appeal against the granting of exempt status.

But what is different about the new section is that it is not in any way tied to the existence of a preference clause in an award, thereby making it possible for any unionist to claim exemption from membership of any union at any time. Furthermore, it contains a number of provisions imposing substantial penal sanctions against unions and employers, whether acting individually or in concert, who in any way pressure or prejudice the position of an employee possessing an exemption certificate.

For whatever reason-because the scope of this section's operation is wider, or because more people know about it, or because more have felt encouraged by the present Government's announced hostility to compulsory unionism to take advantage of all the opportunities S. 144A offers for mischief-making, or for some combination of these-the fact is that the new section has been very much more controversial, and very much more utilized, than its predecessor. Between 1977 and March 1979 fully 534 applications had been made under S. 144A of which 194 had to that date been granted. And a number of them-most conspicuously the Biggs2 and Aper3 cases in 1978 have provoked explosive industrial disputes

It became evident early in the life of S. 144A that, whatever its other merits or demerits, it was not especially well drafted. Some of its numerous ambiguities and uncertainties were clarified by the Federal Court in a reference of a number of questions of law by the Industrial Registrar in the Aper Case, so far the only case to be litigated under the new section. This case held that a self-employed person could not be issued with a S. 144A certificate; that the ' associations' in respect of which a belief had to be held meant all classes of industrial association and not just those registered or capable of being registered under the Act; and that in order to qualify as grounds for exemption, a conscientious objection had to extend to all associations and could not be confined selectively to one or more individual associations.

But what the Full Court in Aper left unanswered, or incompletely answered, was at least two other questions of equal and possibly greater practical importance, viz. just what kind of character does a belief have to have in order to make it 'conscientious', especially in a non-religous context; and what precisely are the rights of unions-and the obligations of the Industrial Registrar-in respect of participation in the Registrar's exemption proceedings? On the first question the Court gave some guidance, but not enough to be really helpful in marginal cases. On the second, its utterances were positively Delphic, creating more confusion than clarity. These are questions on which the legislation must, in my view, be explicit if it is to retain any credibility at all, and I shall return to them again below.
The Politics of Conscientious Objection

The conscientious objection issue is one that tends to arouse strong passions among all those whom it touches. This fact, here as elsewhere, makes the task of the law reformer that much more difficult. The prescription, however, is not to put the whole question into the too-hard basket. What it means, rather, is that the nature and force of the various competing attitudes must be carefully assessed and fully taken into account in proposing and drafting changes to the law. Law reform, and particularly industrial law reform, which is undertaken in a political vacuum is almost invariably destined to be either irrelevant, ineffective or counterproductive. Here there are at least four distinct groups4 of persons whose views are immediately relevant: objecting individuals, trade unions, employers and politicians.
Objecting Individuals

The base line position of individuals objecting to trade union membership tends to be quite straightforward. Compulsory unionism-indeed any other form of compulsory association-is a grave infringement of civil liberties. The right to freedom of association must extend to the freedom not to associate. There is no justifiable reason for forcing anyone to join an organization against his or her will, especially when that organization is doing something or supporting something of which that person does not approve. The extent to which arguments of this kind should be accepted is a matter taken up in the next section; for the moment they are simply noted.
Trade Unions

The views of most trade unions can be put equally bluntly. As recently articulated for example, by the Secretary of the Federated Storemen and Packers' Union, Simon Crean, they can be summarized as follows.5
Compulsory unionism is legitimate because those who receive the benefits of union action should pay the price.
No-one can opt out of paying taxes because he disapproves of the Government, or the society in which he lives: why should union membership be any different?

Unions are prepared to recognize genuine conscientious objection cases. They have done so in the past-at least when religious claims have been made-and will continue to do so in the future, whatever the law. It is not quite clear what would ever constitute genuine conscientious objection on non-religious grounds, but unions would be prepared to look at such claims if and when they arise.

There is no need for any statutory procedure to protect the rights of individuals, for unions can be relied upon to regulate themselves in these matters. But to the extent that a statutory procedure is laid down, it is objectionable insofar as it does not give unions the opportunity to participate in conscientious objection hearings, to thoroughly test objectors' beliefs, and to appeal against adverse decisions.
Employers

The views of employers tend, as is the case in many problem areas of industrial relations, to be somewhat mixed. Employers-because of their preference, by and large, for a quiet life-are not nearly as universally or unequivocally on the side of conscientious objectors, and against closed shops and compulsory unionism, as some of the more strident industry pronouncements would suggest. Among the arguments one often hears in favour of compulsory unionism are the following.
It serves industrial peace by eliminating the resentment, clashes and direct industrial action that may result from unionists and non-unionists working together.
It may be desirable where a particular union has a record of settling its grievances via conciliation and arbitration rather than direct action and can give guarantees to this effect for the future.
It may have a moderating influence on unions whose membership is comprised largely of those who join only because they have to.
If all employees join and vote in union elections this is likely to result in a leadership more in tune with rank and file opinion.
If union muscle is such that compulsory unionism will occur anyway, there will be less dislocation if this is imposed by law rather than forced by direct action.

On the other hand, it is certainly true that employers would in principle overwhelmingly support the rights of conscientious objectors, and the desirability of their having protection of some kind in industrial legislation. But I believe that it is equally true that the great bulk of employers would readily acknowledge the desirability of the trade unions affected by such claims having some kind of say in determining whether particular conscientious objection applications are genuinely based.
The Labor Party

The views of conscientious objection that will ultimately count most are, for better or worse, those of politicians. Here, as might have been predicted, a relatively clearcut divergence exists between the Liberal Government and the Labor Opposition. The Labor Party's Federal Platform does not directly address the issue but, as Keith Marshall has noted, the ALP position was clearly put on the record by Bill Hayden in a major address delivered to the BWIU Federal Conference.

'We will change the present unworkable conscientious objection provision of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. You know, as I know, that the union movement has always acknowledged conscientious objection. That fact was never more obvious than in the great debate that followed the embroiling of Australia in the Vietnam War.

A Labor Government will provide the right to offer opposing argument when conscientious objection application for exemption is being heard, and it will provide the right of appeal after the decision. The present formulation of the conscientious objection provision is nothing more than an extension of the Prime Minister's tactics of provocation and confrontation.'6

The Labor Party did not oppose the amendments to S.47 introduced in 1956, and does not now oppose the continued existence of conscientious objection clauses in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. But it regards the present terms of S. 144A as quite inadequate to ensure that conscientious objection claims made, and accepted, are genuine and not spurious.
The Liberal Government

The attitude of the Fraser Government, on the other hand, must be presumed to be embodied in the terms of the present S. 144A-a provision which clearly elevates the position of the individual applicant for exemption at the expense of competing claims of the trade union concerned. Conscientious objection claims are regarded as a matter solely between the applicant and the Registrar, in the resolution of which the views or concerns of the relevant union have no part. The Government's position on these matters, and in particular on the desirability of amendments to S. 144A of the kind canvassed by the Labor Party, was spelled out in the following letter to me from the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations replying to a question asked in Parliament six weeks earlier:

'I refer to your question without notice to my colleague the Attorney-General, concerning matters arising out of the recent dispute in which Melbourne tramway employees refused to work with Miss Barbara Biggs who had obtained a certificate of exemption from trade union membership. (Hansard, 13 September 1978, pages 518 -519).

You raise two matters in your question. Firstly, you ask whether I would table papers relating to Miss Biggs' application for a certificate of exemption. As you will be aware, it has long been the established practice and understanding that applications for, and hearings of applications for, conscientious objection certificates are to be regarded as confidential to the applicant and the Registrar. Miss Biggs' application proceeded on that basis and accordingly it is a matter of propriety and good faith that the well-established understanding operative at the time at which her application was made and heard should not now be over-turned.

The second matter you raised was whether the Government would amend section 144A of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act to provide for representation of, and cross-examination by, unions at hearings of applications; to require the Registrar to publish reasons for his decisions; and to allow an aggrieved union a right of appeal to the Commission. The operation of section 144A is being kept under review and if the Government were to be satisfied that these or any other alterations are desirable, appropriate amendments will be made to the section.'7

Just what it will take to persuade the present Government that amendments to its legislation are indeed desirable remains to be seen. I am not sure that, where trade unions are concerned, this Government is susceptible to any kind of reasoned argument. But, imbued with that spirit of optimism which a few more years in politics will undoubtedly knock out of me, let me at least make the attempt, in what follows, to sketch out some grounds for changing present law and practice which I hope do have some moral and political force.
The Morality of Conscientious Objection

I believe that the standard arguments of both individual objectors and trade unions, as sketched out above, tend to put the matter too crudely and too absolutely; the underlying issues of principle are rather more complex than either side will readily admit. A more credible account, I suggest, is one which acknowledges that both sides of the debate have important points to make, but steers a balanced course constructing a conclusion which owes something to both sides. This argument can be stated in four steps, as follows.

1. It must be accepted that a logical corollary to the undisputed democratic right of free association is the right not to associate. As a matter of first principle, no-one should be forced to join any organization against his or her will. If that right is acknowledged in principal, it ought to be capable of enforcement in practice, if necessary by statutory means.

2. But that is not quite enough to conclude the argument in the particular case of trade unions. In the industrial context, additional considerations of fairness come into play. This is the argument that those who reap the benefits of action undertaken on their behalf ought to contribute directly to its cost. The unions' interest in the outcome of claims to exemption from membership is, to this extent, well founded in principle: it is not just a matter of realpolitik.

3. But the fairness argument is not, by itself, conclusive either. What it does do is shift the onus of proof back to the objector. It means, that those who wish to opt out of union membership should be able to produce strong, persuasive and genuinely conscientious reasons for doing so. Reasons based on mere personal dislike or distaste for unions, or for the activities of any particular union, are not enough.

4. Since unions have a direct and immediate interest in the outcome of exemption claims-based not merely on self interest but on principle-it would appear reasonable that they be entitled to participate in the determination of such claims. Such participation should certainly extend to the right to put counter evidence and submissions to the determining body, and arguably should also extend to testing by cross examination, the applicant's case. Applicants for conscientious objection status are no less likely than applicants for anything else to rely on irrelevancies, half-truths and untruths; it is important in all cases that these be exposed. The present inquisitorial system, whereby unions are excluded from the proceedings between the Registrar and applicant, may or may not as a matter of strict law offend the canons of natural justice, but that this exclusion is offensive to any principles of fair play, is perfectly clear.
The Criteria of Conscientious Objection

The terms of S. 144A do not, as has already been stated, give the Registrar much help in determining what is a genuinely conscientious objection. S. 144A (1 ) requires him to be satisfied 'that the person's conscientious beliefs do not allow the person to be a member' of any industrial association. 'Conscientious beliefs' are then defined in S. 144A (2) to mean:
'any conscientious beliefs, whether the grounds for the beliefs are or are not of a religious character and whether the beliefs are or are not part of the doctrine of any religion'.

The question remains as to what it is about such beliefs, be they religious or non-religious, which makes them 'conscientious'. There is very rarely much contention on this score when religion-based claims are in issue, although in the past it appears that it has usually only been members of somewhat exotic sects, like the Exclusive Brethren, who have regularly taken advantage of the law. The real practical problems arise when non-religious claims are in issue. The Federal Court in the Aper Case addressed itself generally to the issues in this way:

'Quite clearly there are persons, such as those adhering to the faith of the Exclusive Brethren, whose faith does not permit them to belong to any associations. In addition, no doubt, there are others within the community who conscientiously believe that industrial relations are best settled by individual negotiation and bargaining between employer and employee and who would be unable , by reason of that belief, if conscientious, to join either an employer or an employee organization. There are, we have no doubt, others in a not dissimilar position who hold a relevant conscientious belief about all relevant associations.'8

So far so good, but still in this passage the central question remains unanswered: that is, what is the nature of a conscientious belief about industrial relations, as distinct from some other kind of belief.

On this question, on which everything else hangs, there is a relative paucity of case law: in the Federal industrial jurisdiction, only the Aper Case itself, and in the State industrial jurisdiction, just one early N.S.W. case on similarly drafted legislation.9 There are a considerable number of authorities interpreting Commonwealth statute law on conscientious objection to military service but these-while certainly very suggestive-at best only indirectly assist the Registrar in resolving industrial cases.

The Court in the Aper Case does quote extensively from a leading High Court military case,10 but its primary object in doing so is to muster support on the particular 'war analogy' for its conclusion that a conscientious objection under S 144A has to extend to all industrial associations and not a selected minority. The passage cited in Aper from the decision of Barwick C. J. in Thompsons Case emphasizing the durability depth and sweep that an opinion must have to make it conscientious does however indicate the general drift of the Federal Court's thinking. So does the following short passage which is the only one bearing on the present problem offered by the Aper Court in its own words;

'. . . the fact that the section had its origins, as did the legislation dealing with military service, in provisions requiring the existence of a conscientious belief founded on religious grounds indicates the depth of conviction which is required. It involves an innate conviction of what is morally right and morally wrong.'11

Most of the ingredients for our guidance in conscientious objection cases are now to hand. But in none of the relevant authorities, least of all Aper itself, is there anything as convenient as a fully worked out check-list of criteria for conscientious objection. Pending the writing of specific criteria into the statue itself-which would be, ultimately, the most desirable way of getting some clarity and uniformity of approach-we shall have to construct a check list of our own.
Clarifying the Criteria of Conscientious Objection

The best starting point for such an exercise is probably the definition offered by Dwyer C. J. in a frequently cited12 Western Australian case Grondal v Minister of Labour and National Service with the language of which it is obvious the Aper Court was familiar

'I would say that a conscientious belief is an individual's inward conviction of what is morally right or morally wrong, and it is a conviction that is genuinely reached and held after some process of thinking about the subject. It represents a conclusion that is uninfluenced by any consideration of personal advantage or disadvantage either to oneself or others, and perhaps when put to the test should be ordinarily combined with a willingness to act according to the particular conviction reached although this may involve personal discomfort or suffering or material loss.'13
My reading of such hints as are thrown out by the body of case law generally, leads me to suggest that one can identify four distinguishing characteristics of a conscientious belief, as follows.14

1. It Reflects a Moral Position. A conscientious belief involves a belief that something is not just right or wrong, but morally right or wrong. As the Aper Court put it, picking up the language in the Grondal Case, 'it involves an innate conviction of what is morally right and morally wrong'.15 A 'moral' position can perhaps be described as one taken in accordance with what is perceived to be a moral principle-as distinct from being based on whim or impulse, or being a mere reflex response to some stimulus. Another way of identifying a moral position, familiar in philosophical writing, is to say that the person espousing it must be willing to have it universally adopted-to say, in effect, that 'the principle holds not just for me but for everyone'. On this view it would be a moral objection to say that it is wrong for me to be to be forced to join a union-but it may be a moral position to object to anyone being forced to join a union.

It should perhaps be added that a moral position can, clearly, be based on religious or non-religious considerations; it can be orthodox or unorthodox, logical or illogical, demonstrably true or demonstrably false. What matters is that it be the product of principled belief as to rightness or wrongness.

2. It is Compelling in Character. A conscientious belief is one that involves a sense or feeling by the person claiming it that it is his duty to espouse it. A belief of a casual or 'take it or leave it' kind is not conscientious; it must be characterized by some depth-i.e. reflect a deep conviction, not a shallow or superficial one, capable of being easily swept away. Barwick C. J. in the Thompson Case16 refers to the 'compulsive quality' of a conscientious belief.

The language of S. 144A itself makes this point to the extent that it requires a person's beliefs 'do not allow' him to join an industrial association. This particular phrase also appears in the military legislation, prompting Barwick C. J. to add in the Thompson judgment, 'the use of the expression 'does not allow' in the section reflects the depth and nature of the required conviction'. The Aper Court, it will have been noted in the passage cited above, also refers to the 'depth of conviction which is required'.17

3. It is Durable. A conscientious belief is one that is held with a degree of tenacity and consistency over time, although this is not to say it must be absolutely unchanging. Barwick C. J. states this criterion very clearly in his judgment in the Thompson Case:

'A conscientious belief because it is a matter of conscience with its compulsive quality is durable though not unchangeable . . . . Though durability is in general a quality of the demands of conscience, conscientious belief as I have said may change . . . . But that such beliefs may change does not, to my mind, impinge upon the proposition that the section requires a present conscientious belief . . . .'18

4. It Involves a Subordination of Self-interest. A conscientious belief is one quite unmotivated by considerations of personal advantage or disadvantage. It would be difficult to take seriously a claim that one 'shouldn't have to join a union because there's nothing in it for me'. Dwyer C. J.'s dictum in the Grondal Case makes this perfectly clear. And, putting what is essentially the same point another way, nor should an objection be regarded as conscientious if (as was the case to some extent in the Aper Case) it is based solely on personal experience of rough treatment by a particular union or even the union movement as a whole.

The four criteria identified do of course, to some extent overlap in a mutually reinforcing way. Nonetheless in determining conscientious objection claims, it is both possible and helpful, for the Registrar to seek satisfaction from the applicant as to each point in turn, in order to build up an overall picture as to the nature and intensity of the belief under scrutiny. If this approach is adopted it ought to be possible in practice to fairly readily distinguish a genuine conscientious belief from an objection which is based on either
(a) intellectual persuasion (e.g. a belief that union activity in some industry , or in the economy as a whole, is economically unhealthy or ultimately counter- productive); or
(b) predilection, personal preference or emotional leaning (e.g. an intense dislike of going to meetings, or a distaste for the personal style of union leaders).

This is not to say that a genuinely conscientious belief cannot also have attached to it elements of one or both of (a) or (b). The point is simply that a conscientious belief can and must be distinguished from either: it must be the case that one's conscience rebels against the imposition, not just one's intellect or taste-buds.

It must be acknowledged that it remains easier to say what a conscientious belief is not than what it is, and this is still particularly true of objections mounted on non-religious grounds. The criteria outlined would in theory still leave the potential for a non-religious belief to come within the protection afforded by S. 144A, but it is difficult to articulate in practice what the elements of such a belief might be, and it is obviously easier to see how religious beliefs would qualify. Certainly none of the highly publicized recent applicants-least of all Miss Biggs-would seem, on a proper analysis, to get to first base. But if all that is so, it follows not from any deliberate attempt on my part to narrow down the operation for the section, but simply from the true meaning, when properly analysed, of the words which Parliament itself has chosen .
Changing the Law

There are five specific changes to the law which I would argue should be made. All of them have been foreshadowed to a greater or lesser extent in the preceding discussion, and most can accordingly now be stated quite briefly.

1. Criteria of Conscientious Objection. It would be helpful though not essential, for the definition of 'conscientious beliefs' in S.144A to be extended so as to embody the four criteria developed above. Failing any such legislative change, I would argue that those criteria are, in any event, those that ought to be applied if the true meaning of the present section is to prevail.

2. Right of Appearance and Cross-examination before Registrar by Interested Organizations. The law at the moment is in a state of some uncertainty as to whether any such right exists. In the Congdon Case Gaudron J. held that the former S.47 conferred no such right (and that as a consequence there was no right of appeal of the Commission under S.88F of the Act because any such right was contingent upon the organization having standing before the Registrar).19 In the absence of any explicit provision conferring standing upon interested organizations in the new S.144A, one would have thought that reasoning continued to apply. However in a cryptic passage in the Aper Case, the Federal Court seemed to lend some credence to the notion that unions whose interests are at stake have a positive right to have their voice heard:

'We agree with the view expressed during the course of the hearing that the inquiry before the Registrar would necessarily be conducted in accordance with the rules of natural justice and would involve giving notice and opportunity to be heard to organizations likely to be affected'.20

This view does not appear to have been based on any detailed argument from counsel, and does not sit well with the decision in the Congdon Case unless it is construed to mean that unions should be given an opportunity after the event to comment orally or in writing on evidence which they have not directly heard nor had an opportunity to challenge at the time of its presentation. But if this is all that is meant, why state the point in terms of 'natural justice', which would seem to imply rather more than a post hoc opportunity to comment?

The Law ought to be clarified and if necessary corrected, to ensure that unions do have the right to be present to cross-examine and give evidence. As was argued earlier, their interest in the outcome is such that in principle this is only fair. One should also emphasise the important practical point that exposure of an applicant's case to searching test in a semi-adversarial context may well be the best way of revealing manifest deficiencies in that case. It is difficult to believe, for example, that Miss Barbara Biggs would have obtained a certificate in the first place-or that the industrial disputes this provoked would ever have occurred-had her application been properly tested at the outset; her membership of other trade unions in the past, her willingness to join others in the future, and the nature of her objection as being essentially based upon dislike of unions who disrupted vital industries, and the Tramways Union in particular, would all surely have emerged and made a finding of 'conscientious' objection to 'any' association impossible.

3. Statements of Reasons. Reasons for a decision should be required to be given by the Registrar. This is a necessary practical precondition for any appeal, and also a time honoured way of obliging any decision-maker to think carefully through the elements of a decision before making it. Nothing concentrates the mind more wonderfully than having to not simply intuit, but articulate.

4. Right of Appeal. A right of appeal is available to an applicant aggrieved by the Registrar's failure to grant him or her a certificate of exemption, but this right is explicitly denied to anyone equally aggrieved by a certificate being granted. There is no reason in principle why the normal S.88F appeal rule should not apply here as elsewhere, and both the possibility of bad individual decisions and the desirability of a uniformity of general approach makes it appropriate and sensible for unions to have this right. It certainly cannot be claimed that there is any inherent triviality about conscientious exemption claims such as would not justify their taking the attention of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission or the Industrial Division of the Federal Court: the whole community is now only too well aware of the industrial consequences of unacceptable decisions on this issue.

5. Revocation of Exemption Certificates. There is no clear basis in the Act upon which an application for revocation of an exemption certificate could be made by anyone during the currency of that certificate: It would simply be a matter of contesting or refusing the renewal of such a certificate when it expired, normally after twelve months. But circumstances do arise from time to time when it becomes apparent that a revocation would be amply justified and would much assist the resolution of an industrial dispute if it occurred. A classic example occurred during the Biggs controversy when, with the dispute still flaring, the lady in question declared in the media that she had before the Registrar been 'virtually forced to say what I didn't believe-that all unions, and the concept of unionism, are bad'.21 Whether this was in fact an accurate report of her encounter with the Registrar is beside the point: what is crucial is the acknowledgement of a state of belief inconsistent with the continued possession of a S.144A certificate.
Finally

It may be that the views I have expressed on this subject will not wholly coincide with those of many of my colleagues in the Labor movement, particularly those trade union leaders who are inclined to argue for the removal of all legislative constraints and a return to simple self-regulation. But I am enough of a civil libertarian-and enough of a cynic about the real world-to want to see important basic rights enshrined in legislation and not just left in reliance upon good will, even if that good will can reasonably be expected to be forth- coming in the overwhelming majority of cases.

Equally, however, I am under no illusions as to the one-sided way in which S. 144A has so far worked, and was perhaps intended to work. If it is to be accepted as an important civil safeguard, and not just a charter for mischief- makers and a source of endless industrial confrontation, it is very important indeed that its substance and administration be reassessed, and that correcting amendments where necessary be introduced, along the lines suggested.
