SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is dealing with two pieces of industrial relations legislation which have been introduced by the Government and delayed while it tried to get its act together in relation to these proposals. The Bills represent the umpteenth attempt by this Government to grapple with industrial relations problems in Australia. I say, quite clearly , that anybody would be blind to suggest that there are not very serious and very sizable industrial relations problems in Australia. We have too many unions and too many arbitration systems. We have a progressively weakened federal system of arbitration at a time when the opposite thing should be happening. We should be strengthening the centralised wage fixing capacity and strengthening the capacity of a national arbitration commission to control the industrial relations climate.

SPEECH.PARA: We live in a country where there is no wages policy. The authority for that proposition is contained or displayed on the one hand by such diverse authorities as the report of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development which was quite critical of the absence of a wages policy in Australia and, on the other hand, by such eminent authorities as the former Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Andrew Peacock, who, only a fortnight ago when explaining, for purposes of his own, what was wrong with this country alleged, on a number of occasions, that the absence of a wages policy was crucial to the concerns which we face as a country.

Not only do we not have a wages policy, but also there is no policy from this Government on the introduction of technology as it affects the work force; there is no incomes policy, and, what is more, there is no prospect of an incomes policy under a government such as the Fraser Government; and there is a high level of industrial disputation. The year 1981 had the worst strike record in this country for seven years. The rate of average weekly male earnings in the December quarter of 1981 increased by 5.8 per cent. The previous comparative high figure which is sometimes cited by this Government was for the December quarter 1974 when wages increased, per employed male unit, 5.4 per cent as distinct from 5.8 per cent in 1981. That happened because of the absence of a wages policy. I think it is significant to point not only to that high level of industrial disputation but also to the fact that, at the same time, we have the highest level of unemployment since the Great Depression. We have the highest level of unemployment which would usually be regarded as a factor in limiting industrial disputation if we saw punitive arguments as the means of stopping industrial unrest.

For a variety of reasons there is a very serious industrial relations problem in Australia. We have heard advanced, in the context of that very serious industrial relations problem, arguments by Government senators and, indeed, by Government Ministers that Australian wages have to be competitive with the countries of South East Asia if we are to have any sort of export-led recovery. I see the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) is shaking his head. That argument has been advanced frequently by his colleagues, if not by him. I do not really understand what that means. If it means we have to have a comparative wage situation with Korea or Singapore, I think we ought to start thinking again about where this country is going. In the context of those factors which I have mentioned-the absence of a unified industrial relations system, the absence of a wages policy, and the absence of a prospect of an incomes policy, a high level of industrial disputation and so on-we find a government which will tackle none of these basic problems.

This legislation has been introduced at a time when the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner), who enjoys the distrust of employers and employees alike, is about to be removed. This Government introduced this legislation in that context. The Minister for Industrial Relations stood, on certain assumptions, for deputy leadership of his party and finished up with five votes. That shows the confidence which the Liberal Party has in that Minister's competence and capacity to carry out the administration of his portfolio. Of course, we have, at this time in this sort of situation, a government which will tackle none of those fundamental problems but which embarks, instead, upon a course of confrontation rather than concensus. It is a sort of Falkland Islands syndrome within Australia.

Legislation has been introduced again which does not have the approval of the employer organisations in any substantial degree. It is designed to appeal to the sort of gung ho, hip-shooting fringe-dwellers of the National Country Party and is really not, in any sense, based on any analysis of what the needs of this country are in terms of sound industrial relations. Once again there is an attempt to manipulate industrial relations as an arm of government policy for cynical, political purposes. This legislation is another step towards the law of the jungle in Australian industrial relations at a time when Australia desperately needs consensus, desperately needs a steady hand in government, desperately needs in business circles a degree of certainty about where this country is going and desperately needs a degree of leadership from government.

Let us not forget some of the fundamental facts. According to World Bank statistics the decline in per capita income of this country is incredibly significant in terms of OECD figures. I remind the Senate, as I suppose I have done on previous occasions, that that decline has been documented in government reports, such as the report of the Crawford Study Group into Structural Adjustment, and so on, and has been drawn attention to in a number of publications; but it seems to have been completely ignored by the present Government. Professor Kasper drew attention to it in a submission to the Crawford Study Group, a submission which has been quoted at some length. I simply make the point that, on world data, in 1966 Australia stood fifth in the world in terms of per capita income after the United States of America, Sweden, Switzerland and Canada. By 1973 we were tenth-we had moved from fifth place to tenth place.

The band-wagon of Australian growth, development and increasing wealth had turned out to be a hearse by 1973. By 1979 we had gone to eleventh place, having been passed by a number of the European democracies, and we have now been passed by Japan. It is interesting to note the order of those countries which had a higher per capita income than Australia as at 1979: Switzerland, Sweden, Denmark , Germany, Belgium, Norway, the Netherlands, France, Canada and so on. Both the United States and Canada have slipped, but in 1982, of the OECD countries, only Italy and the United Kingdom remain below Australia in terms of per capita income. Similarly, if one looks at Australian growth rates one will see exactly the same sort of level of performance.

I mention these things because if we are to improve that sort of performance-I would argue that we have a desperate need for better economic performance in this country-central to improved economic performance is an improvement in the industrial relations environment in this country. I repeat that that is central to it. That involves some sort of agreement about fair shares in Australian society. It involves matters of, for example, tax avoidance-the tax avoidance industry was succoured by this Government until quite recently. It involves questions of redistribution of wealth away from the poorer section of the community to the wealthier section, as has happened under this Government. In my view it involves questions about the sorts of taxes we are prepared to impose on capital accretions of wealth, something which the Liberal Party sought to remove from the agenda of political debate in this country as though it were a naughty expression which should not be discussed in Australia. Alone again, Australia being amongst the OECD countries which do not have a significant form of capital or wealth tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your party's stand on that?

—I just made the point that the horrendous thing is that in the last election campaign attempts were made to remove that issue from the agenda of political discussion in Australia. As I have said, central to this issue of economic recovery is the need for a better industrial relations performance. Some time ago-in 1975-in a moment of temporary aberration the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) recognised that fact when he talked about the basis for any successful industrial relations policy being trust, mutual respect and good will. There is no capacity at all in Australia for trust, mutual respect and good will in industrial relations as long as this Government remains in power under the present leadership. That is one of the tragedies which is again exemplified by this piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I said earlier that the Crawford report on structural adjustment made the point that if there were to be any restructuring of Australian industry, which is desperately needed, it had to be done on the basis of concensus and a common pact between employers, government and trade unions. The capacity to reach that concensus is no longer there. One of the reasons it is not there is the policies followed by this Government, which are exemplified by this sort of legislation. As I said earlier, this is about the twelfth time since the Fraser Government came to power that it has sought to rectify industrial relations problems by legislation of this kind. This legislation is as doomed as the last lot and the lot before that were because it is not based on any notion of the importance of arriving at a national concensus on industrial relations policy. At the end of my comments I intend to move an amendment to the motion that the Bills be read a second time, to the effect that this legislation be referred to a select committee of the Senate for examination.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with a standing committee?

—I do not suggest that it should be referred to a standing committee, as Senator Jessop asks, because no standing committee of the Senate is competent to deal with or has relevant terms of reference to deal with such an important subject. The fact of the matter is that we have now arrived at this situation in this country: Whereas it was once said in wartime that war is too important to be left to the generals. I now say that industrial relations is too important to be left to the Fraser Government. It has a failed record going back seven years. It has produced nothing except, last year, the highest record of industrial disputation since it came to office and, at the same time, a high inflation rate, a high level of unemployment and a total absence of a wages policy.

SPEECH.PARA: We see only one course which will avoid this Government going down that old road-paved with ancient typewriters-which it has followed in the past. We do not want the Government to go down that road again. We believe that a Senate committee should examine the fundamental issues in this legislation. Of course, we have tried this before. Last year I introduced a Bill proposing a greater capacity for amalgamations of unions. It was rejected by the Senate. But one of the important factors about that legislation was that it sought to progress towards union amalgamations which would be based on a community of interest, as determined by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Industrial realism.
—As Senator Mulvihill says with that flattery which comes so seldom from him, industrial realism was present in that legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to comment specifically on some of the provisions of the legislation. The first comment I make is that it weakens the influence and power of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission at a time when exactly the opposite process should be taking place. In Australia we have this ludicrous situation of having seven bodies capable of fixing wages and conditions of employment. There are six State arbitration systems and a national arbitration system. If one adds all the State parliaments, there is a total of 13 bodies. The arbitration Commission exerted a role as a centralised wage fixing tribunal for some time in Australia-in the period to June last year, when the Prime Minister flew overseas to the royal wedding and abandoned industrial relations in Australia to the troglodytes. That is when the real problems started again. The objects of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, apart from the object of securing industrial peace, as far as it is possible, include the strengthening of the representative organisations of employers and employees because they are fundamental to the industrial power of the Commonwealth as set out in the Constitution. It is fundamental that the representative organisations of employers and employees be strengthened in order that they might participate in that process provided by the Constitution and, of course, the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.

My second major objection to this legislation is that again it shows the chronic confusion of the Fraser Government between wages policy and the dispute settling function of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Wages policy is something we do not have any more. The Arbitration Commission is, in my view, the most suitable body to provide a centralised wage fixation system for this country. I think it is very important to realise, in relation to industrial matters as well as many other matters which are of concern to this country at a time of economic chaos, that people at every level of society and of every walk of life in Australia are asking: Where is this country going under this Government? It is essential that we look towards the preservation of existing institutions and provide for continuity and development of those institutions rather than rely on peculiar ideological theories imported from abroad-creatures of fashion-which fill the vacuum in conservative heads for a few months and then go out of fashion. That is what we are doing. It is important that there be continuity in the development of institutions and that the central function of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission be strengthened rather than weakened , as it will be by this legislation.

The legislation is quite complex; it has many provisions. I want to deal with some of the major ones which are the subject of the matters we intend to refer to a Senate select committee. The first of those matters is the so-called stand- down provisions. The current situation, briefly stated, is that if an employer has an industrial dispute in his establishment or finds that sections of his work force cannot be usefully employed because of industrial disputation either in his establishment or somewhere else he is entitled to go to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. If, after argument, he establishes a prima facie case before an arbitrator or a judge, he is able to obtain a so-called stand- down clause which entitles him to stand down those employees who cannot be usefully employed because of industrial disputation. That provision, of course, will remain.

This Government, by this legislation introduced at this extraordinary time, is proposing to introduce another provision which will give employers the right to stand down employees automatically by simply making a declaration to the effect that the employees are engaged in industrial action, however defined-it is not very clear how it is defined. Employers may also stand down employees if they cannot be usefully employed or if their business is suffering substantial loss or damage. That effectively provides for a unilateral declaration by an employer that in his opinion a section of his work force cannot be usefully employed. It goes without saying that during the period that unilateral declaration made by an employer is in force those employees who are stood down as a result will not be paid. That is at the whim of a single employer. Absolutely no safeguards are provided in this legislation against any abuse of that process by an employer.

In the Australian economy of 1982, when we are looking to the future, it is not the time to turn back the law relating to industrial relations to what it was in England in 1782. That is what this Government is doing. The British courts decided in the eighteenth century that as a matter of common law one could employ somebody, sack somebody but not suspend anybody. An employer could not leave somebody in limbo, without pay, at his whim. That was the common law prior to the introduction of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act in Australia. That will happen under this legislation if it is carried, and that is what the Government presumably seeks to do. It is extraordinary that any Parliament would condone that situation in a country which has all the difficulties that this one has to which I have referred. I hope that the Government will look to the future rather than to the long distant past.

There are no safeguards against the use of that provision by employers. There is no provision for a hearing before an impartial tribunal, no concept of a fair go, which one would have thought was integral to the notion of obtaining any consensus about anything in this society, and no provision for appeal. The dispute which leads to the standing down of employees without pay might in fact be caused by the employer. He can still stand them down. It is not an unlikely circumstance that the dispute might be caused by the employer. Nearly 30 per cent of industrial disputes in Australia are attributed to mismanagement by employers. In such a situation an employer could still stand down employees under these provisions. That is totally disastrous if we are to strive in any sense towards a better environment and a better atmosphere in industry and proceed to try to reconstruct the economy on the basis of some common sense of direction. That is the point we have reached and that is what is required.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the withdrawal of labour?

—What about the withdrawal of labour? It is a right which is conceded by Senator Crichton-Browne's party in its platform. What is he talking about? He should get his party's platform changed if he wants to interject against me on that issue.
—It has the same effect.

—It does not have the same social effect at all. We have a conciliation and arbitration system and all sorts of rules and laws about industrial relations because it has been realised historically that there is not a situation in which there is equality. That is the basis. If Senator Crichton- Browne wants to scrap all those systems, he should say so.
—It is not working.
—It is not working and it has no hope of working under this Government and under this legislation.
—The record has never been better.

—Senator Crichton-Browne must have just come into the chamber. I pointed out that 1981 had the highest level of industrial disputation in this country for seven years. In the December quarter of 1981 wage increases were the highest for seven years.

—You cannot really say there is equality in a situation in which an employer is bleeding to death because of a strike and has workers on his payroll whom he is continuing to pay. Is that an equal position?

—The Conciliation and Arbitration Act provides for a neutral arbitrator to determine that situation. That provision is in the Act now, and the Government is leaving it in the legislation. That is what we argue for. The primitives are coming out of the caves tonight. Contrary to Senator Chaney's belief, there should be an independent arbitrator in these matters, and it is the role of government to establish the mechanisms to provide neutrality and equality in these situations. I would not have thought that anybody but these two troggs who have interjected in the last few minutes would disagree with that proposition. Apparently I am wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: The second important point in this legislation is the question of the registration of unions, the provision that says, effectively, that unions can only be registered from now on if they are based on an industry. That is conceptually, in my personal view, highly desirable. But, of course, there is no adequate definition of 'industry' in this legislation and there is no mechanism for dealing with the enormous difficulties which would be encountered in implementing such a policy. One has to have regard to social, industrial and political realities before one embarks on these crazy, ideological goals. One of Evelyn Waugh's novels says: 'People devote so much time to building utopias in which no civilised person would want to live.' That is precisely what this Government is presumably trying to do with this bizarre legislation. It is trying to build some sort of industrial relations utopia which just will not work. None of the people involved in it believe it will work. They believe it is just another cynical exercise in manipulating industrial relations. We are very critical of the method adopted to achieve this proposal for industry based unions. This goal is desirable in my view. This country, economically, would be well served if the goal could be obtained, but it cannot be obtained by using a hammer. What is the opposite to a carrot in that situation?

TALK.START.PARA: —A stick.

—There has to be a little carrot, a little persuasion, a little encouragement and a little less stick from irrelevant people, such as the members of this Government, in relation to industrial relations.

SPEECH.PARA: The third point I want to mention is the question of the abolition of preference to unionists and members of industrial organisations, the so-called ' voluntary unionism provision'. It is beaut conceptually that everybody in this world should be able to join whatever he wants to and not join whatever he does not want to join. It just does not work like that. The whole question of preference for unionism is a matter which should get serious study from scholars such as Senator Crichton-Browne who is sitting over there. There is a history of preference to unionists. The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has the power to grant that preference on the basis of a variety of matters relating to ensuring industrial peace in a particular industry. Time is eluding me but I am sure that some other concerned person will take up that question in the context of the debate. As I said, these matters are too important to be left to this Government. I move:
Leave out all words after ''That'', insert:
''(a) the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill 1982 and the Commonwealth Employees (Voluntary Membership of Unions) Bill 1982 be referred to a Select Committee;
(b) the Select Committee report to the Senate by the first sitting day in September 1982;
(c) in considering the Bills, the Committee give particular consideration to

(i) the desirability or otherwise of encouraging the development of industry- based unions in Australia, and the best methods of providing changes in the structure of Australian Trade Union organisation,

(ii) whether the provision of ''voluntary unionism'' and the removal of power to award preference to unionists will contribute to industrial peace and an improvement of the industrial relations climate, and

(iii) whether the right of employers to stand down employees as a result of industrial action without reference to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is consistent with modern industrial practices, and will contribute to industrial peace;
(d) the Committee consist of seven Senators, as follows:
(i) three to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate,
(ii) two to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate,
(iii) one to be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats, and
(iv) an independent Senator;
(e) the Committee proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy;
(f) the Chairman of the Committee be appointed by and from the members of the Committee;

(g) the Chairman of the Committee may from time to time appoint another member of the Committee to be the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee;
(h) in the event of an equality of voting the Chairman, or the Deputy-Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote;
(i) two members of the Committee be necessary to constitute a meeting of the Committee for the exercise of its powers;

(j) the Committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives, and have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations it may deem fit;

(k) the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources, and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the Committee with the approval of the President;
(l) the Committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public;
(m) except where the Committee otherwise decides, its hearings of evidence be open to the public; and
(n) the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

The proposed select committee will consider the desirability of the various fundamental matters proposed in this legislation, such as the stand down question, the so-called voluntary unionism and the desirability of developing industry based unions in Australia. I commend that motion to the Senate because this is a very important matter. It is not just an industrial relations matter, it is a matter which goes to the heart of the capacity of this country to get out of the sloth it is now in in economic terms and to reassert itself as a modern economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill 1982 is no ordinary piece of legislation. It is potentially the most dangerous, inflammatory and repressive piece of legislation that has been introduced into this place since I have been here. This Bill strikes at the very heart of our Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and our system for fixing wages. It does not address itself to the problem that has been encountered in this country since indexation failed-that is, it does not make clear what system or wage fixation we should adopt. That is the first matter the Government should address.

SPEECH.PARA: Understandably the Australian Democrats have been very concerned about this Bill. We are acutely aware that the responsibility for this Bill passing or not passing into law rests squarely on the shoulders of all five Democrat senators. It would take only one Democrat senator to vote for this legislation and it will become the law of the land with the potential, as we see it, to provoke the greatest industrial confrontation this country has ever seen. For these critical reasons we have had extensive discussions with large numbers of people, such as employer organisations and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and particularly with small business people, farmers and individual unionists. They are all in agreement that this legislation would harm moderate unionists, that it would put some employers into financial peril and that it would go no way at all to restraining the excesses of militant unions.

We have given the legislation extensive thought. The Democrats have got their thinking on the matter clear. We have circulated widely amendments which we believe would lessen the impact of the more extreme parts of this Bill and allow it to perform some constructive purpose in our industrial relations law. Nevertheless, we support the amendment that Senator Button has moved which recommends that this legislation be referred to a select committee. We are prepared to support that move, providing the findings of that select committee are made clear to this House no later than the first sitting week in September. We do not want this committee to be used as an excuse to delay a decision on this matter. We are particularly concerned with the aspects of the Bill relating to voluntary unionism and to the automatic standing down of employees. Our amendments relate to those critical areas. We are happy for the whole Bill, together with our amendments, to be considered by the proposed select committee. We will be supporting that initiative by the Australian Labor Party.

I would like briefly to explain the purpose of our amendments and outline our detailed consideration of this legislation. The first thing to remember is that the nature of the conciliation and arbitration system in this country is such that benefits negotiated by unions, and thus financed by union members, flow to union members and non-union members alike. We have a unique system in Australia; our system of conciliation and arbitration is unique and it has some advantages. It means that the benefits negotiated before the Commission flow equally throughout the land so that we do not have in Australia, as is fairly common in some countries-notably in the United States of America-pockets of poverty and depression. We have a very egalitarian society. No doubt the Conciliation and Arbitration Act of 1904 has contributed to that situation. But it also makes the rapid escalation of wages easy. For that reason we advocate that some compromise between direct bargaining-collective bargaining between managers, employers and unions directly-and our present system of conciliation and arbitration should be worked out. This is the critical issue that the Government has to face. So far it has not done so.

In the past many workers have recognised that in order for them to be effectively represented and effectively protected all eligible workers should be members of the relevant union. It is probably not an exaggeration to say that the viability of our conciliation and arbitration system rests on the collective representation of workers through unions. This is the very principle that the Government now attacks. If it has such grave reservations about unionism, it should say so. It should address itself to the problem of wage fixing, rewrite the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and give a new approach to wage fixing and to unionism. Historically, nevertheless, employers have preferred to deal with organisations representing the industrial interests of their employees, rather than directly negotiate with individuals. In large organisations dealing with hundreds and thousands of employees it would be extremely difficult if the work force were not organised through representation by a single body; namely, a union. So to bring in legislation which attacks the very principle of collective representation of workers before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is to attack the very basis of our current system without putting an alternative in its place.

I will now turn to the three contentious areas and outline what the Australian Democrats suggest should be done. The areas are: Automatic stand-downs, the abolition of the preference provisions for unions and the very contentious clause 20, which allows individual employees to seek massive damages if they claim they are being disadvantaged in any way by not being members of unions. First, I refer to the right to stand down. The Democrats believe that the right of employers to stand down employees when there is industrial action and their employees cannot be usefully employed is vital. It is certainly vital for small business. Without it small business could not survive. However, we believe that the existing Act already gives employers an easy to obtain stand-down provision. Any employer can apply to the Commission at any time for a stand-down provision. In addition, he can apply for a general stand-down provision, that will remain in the award, in anticipation of industrial action, which provision can be implemented immediately the effects of industrial action become apparent.

Further, the original Conciliation and Arbitration Act was amended in 1977 to make obligatory the rapid and expeditious hearing of stand-down claims. Since 1977 there has been no evidence that the Commission has delayed hearing a stand- down claim. Nevertheless, we are anxious that stand-downs do not operate against small business in any way and we have suggested amendments that will have the effect of requiring the Commission to hear applications within two days and of giving employers the right to appeal to the full Commission if they are unhappy with the finding. To eliminate the Commission in the area of stand-down applications, as Senator Button pointed out, would be to give employers enormous power. They would be able arbitrarily-simply by signing a declaration- automatically to stand down employees without any reference or appeal by the employees or the employer to the Commission. This in effect would give employers an open slather to break the spirit and the letter of the law and would eliminate the guarantees that employees have to be paid a weekly wage, to have a reasonable assurance as to their future and, in the event of their services being terminated, to be paid a termination sum. So automatic stand-downs without any reference to the Commission, as we see it, could have very far-reaching repercussions. Our amendments are designed to speed up hearings, but we are very strongly opposed to automatic stand-downs.

The second contentious area relates to union preference. It is significant that union preference has been in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act since 1910 and that successive governments of all persuasions have not seen fit to alter this essential provision. It is in the Act for a very good reason-because the whole system depends on unions arguing their cases before the Commission. Therefore, it follows that there has to be reasonable membership of a union before it can represent employees in its area of operation fairly. We have come up with a solution which we believe attacks the two conflicting problems. There should not be undue coercion of individuals to join a union, but we have to keep in mind the essential fact that unions are necessary under our present system. We have said in our proposed amendments that the existing preference clauses should remain but that in future the Commission should be restricted from allowing further preferences to be put into the Act. The existing preferences would remain but we would allow either the employer or the union to apply for the withdrawal of those existing preferences if they so wished. We do not anticipate that there would be any rush by either employers or employees, through their unions, to withdraw the existing preference provisions in the Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be a freeze on all existing preference clauses?

—That is correct. It would also allow existing private arrangements between companies and unions to remain. As we read this new legislation, all existing private agreements between employers and unions could be subject to challenge and to penalties if the challenge were successful. Our third set of amendments addresses itself to the very contentious clause 20 in the proposed new section 144A. This proposed new section, as it is now drafted, makes it illegal for unions or employers to coerce in any way individuals to join a union and, if the individuals are disadvantaged, they have the right to apply to the civil courts to claim damages. Our discussions have led us to believe that this complex and contentious measure would, again, disadvantage moderate unions and would have little or no effect on militant unions. Further, it would render employers vulnerable to legal action for massive damages even though they may have been acting in good faith.

SPEECH.PARA: We have suggested a solution which we believe is worthy of very careful consideration by the Commission. In the Act there is an existing provision for conscientious objectors to apply to the Industrial Registrar to get a certificate of exemption from joining a union on the basis that they pay a fee to Consolidated Revenue. This conscientious objection clause has worked very well. There have been cases where people have applied to the Registrar and have obtained a certificate on the payment of a fee. In an attempt to balance the essentially conflicting requirements of compulsory unionism and the rights of an individual not to join any organisation if he so wishes-these are two conflicting principles-the existing conscientious objection clause should be widened so that an individual can apply to the Registrar for a certificate of exemption on the basis of principle only. These principles are spelt out. The individual may have a religious objection, a philosophical objection or just about any sort of objection to joining a union.

TALK.START.PARA: —Political.

—He may have a political objection. All that he then has to do is apply to the Registrar. But he has to pay the Registrar the appropriate fee. Essentially, simply by broadening the definition of conscientious objector, we are able, within the existing Conciliation and Arbitration Act, to bring in a fee for service. We can think of no other way in which the conflicting principles can be reconciled. We request that the Senate and the select committee give very careful consideration to this suggestion.

SPEECH.PARA: The fourth basic element to which the Bill addresses itself is the encouragement of the formation of industry unions. The Australian Democrats strongly support this concept of industry unions. We support this section of the Bill even though we have some very serious misgivings about its wording.

TALK.START.PARA: —No definition.

—Indeed, there is no definition. It seems strange to us that an Act of parliament dealing with industry unions avoids defining, in any meaningful way, exactly what the Government means by an industry union. We make it clear that we support the original approach and Bill drafted by the Department of Industrial Relations and agreed to by the National Labour Consultative Council-that is, the Bill introduced last year by Senator Button. That at least gives a practical approach to one way in which industry unions could be encouraged. As an employer I am very concerned at the fact that the companies with which I am connected have six, seven or ten unions often competing with one another, any one of which can at any time lay a log of claims on my doorstep and start negotiating. This is leading to enormous problems in industrial relations. If there is some way in which we can encourage one union to represent the employees in a particular industry or company that would be a tremendous step forward. The concept of industry unions is vital. Unfortunately, it is not spelt out in enough detail in the Bill, nor does the Bill show how this concept of an industry union can be encouraged.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats believe that the passage of the Government's legislation in the form in which it is presented would have far reaching consequences for industrial relations in this country. We further believe that certain important provisions within the Bill could be unconstitutional. The amendments that I have outlined briefly and which have been circulated I believe offer a fair balance between legitimate but competing claims of unions and employers. We hope that the select committee can represent a consensus of all political parties in the Senate; that it will look at the Bill in a constructive way, as the Democrats have certainly tried to do; and that it can come up with some practical solutions which the Government can think about. We stress again that we have done our thinking. We are not supporting the select committee's consideration of this Bill in any way as an attempt to defer its passage. We will not under any circumstances vote for an extension of time past this Parliament's first sitting week in September.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Senate is debating the second reading of a Bill to amend the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and it is debating the Commonwealth Employees (Voluntary Membership of Unions) Bill 1982. As an amendment to the second reading of the Bills the Leader of the Opposition ( Senator Button) has moved, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: ''(a) the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill 1982 and the Commonwealth Employees (Voluntary Membership of Unions) Bill 1982 be referred to a Select Committee;
(b) the Select Committee report to the Senate by the first sitting day in September 1982;
(c) in considering the Bills, the Committee give particular consideration to

(i) the desirablility or otherwise of encouraging the development of industry- based unions in Australia, and the best methods of providing changes in the structure of Australian Trade Union organisation,

(ii) whether the provision of 'voluntary unionism' and the removal of power to award preference to unionists will contribute to industrial peace and an improvement of the industrial relations climate, and

(iii) whether the right of employers to stand down employees as a result of industrial action without reference to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is consistent with modern industrial practices, and will contribute to industrial peace;

The amendment deals further with machinery matters relating to the establishment of that select committee. I understand that discussions are currently proceeding in relation to those machinery measures. In general I support the establishment of that committee. I do so because I believe that the committee will provide an opportunity for sane, mature consideration of the proposals that have been brought down by the Government, free from the political involvement which is at the basis of the Government's proposals.

I do not intend to deliver the speech that I was to have delivered before I understood that the reference would go through tonight. However, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) has opened his mouth. I am not referring to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) who represented the Minister for Industrial Relations and made the speech on Mr Viner's behalf. Mr Viner has made his second reading speech. He has made his bed and he will lie in it. The second reading speech contains a number of inaccuracies which must be put to rest here and now. It is my intention to do just that. The Minister commenced his speech by saying:
In my Ministerial statement to the House on 'Wage Determination and Industrial Relations' on 16 February I informed the House that I intended to introduce a number of legislative initiatives.

The Senate will recall that the Minister was forced by the Senate to provide some documentation in support of his ministerial statement on 16 February. The documentation which emerged was pathetic. It provided no real basis or proof of the so-called legislative initiatives which were implied in the Minister's speech to the Parliament on 16 February. One therefore wonders why the Minister made his statement on 16 February when it did not contain the specifics which were desired by the Senate. He did so because 16 February was before the Lowe by -election. It was purely and simply a political act. If industrial relations in Australia does not want anything else it certainly does not want political manipulation, either by Mr Viner or by the extremists within the trade union movement. For purely political purposes the Minister came into the House and made an unsubstantiated statement. He did so for the purposes of the Lowe by- election. Following that he rushed the legislation into the House of Representatives just before Easter-in time for the Victorian election-with no real, mature consideration being given to the clauses of the Bill. This is despite the fact that unions and employers, generally speaking, were opposed to the provisions of the legislation and had made their opposition known to the Minister. That was all done for a political purpose-the Victorian election.

What happened? Mr Thompson, the then Victorian Premier, jumped on the bandwagon and said that he, too, would go along with the Federal Government and institute some measures relating to industry unions-whatever that may mean-in Victoria. How he would have done that is another question. Of course, honourble senators know the industrial relations setup in relation to Victoria. They know that the registration of unions as it applies in, say, New South Wales and Queensland and in the Federal jurisdiction does not apply in Victoria. Not only did the Minister not come out with a definition of industry but also, of course, the Minister as well as everbody else, would have known that-unless something has happened since the time I was involved on a day to day basis in the industrial relations arena-the situation could not have existed. In any event, there was no machinery in Victoria to allow this to take place.

All that Mr Viner did was to create an atmosphere in which certain moderate unions had to explain to their members what effect the disastrous proposals of Mr Viner would have on those in the trade union movement who seek to achieve orderly industrial progress; for example, the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association in Victoria, with something like 70,000 members, prior to the Victorian election distributed to all of its members a detailed report of what the Viner proposals would mean. The Association did not want to do that. It has no record of party political action and certainly no record of party political action against this Government or against the Victorian Government except, of course, when it came to an industrial matter relating to trading hours. But the Association was forced by Mr Viner to notify its 70,000 members, many of whom would have normally been Liberal voters, of the disastrous effects of the Viner proposals. Of course, the political ploy of Mr Viner backfired. The Liberal Party lost the Lowe by-election and the Victorian election. Quite obviously there were other factors, but this action of Mr Viner shows that he does not understand that thousands upon thousands of people within the trade union movement are quite well aware of the situation within the trade union movement and object very strongly to its manipulation by the extreme Left and by the likes of Mr Viner.
I go further. Mr Viner's second reading speech was seen to be a dishonest presentation of the Government's case and a distortion of the facts. He stated:
I now present a Bill to the House about matters that I then foreshadowed.
He then made this classic remark:
The Bill contains a number of elements but its philosophy can be distilled to three main things: Protection of the rights of the individual . . .

Presumably, the Minister is talking about the right of the individual to decide whether to become a member of a trade union. Is he talking about that or is he talking about the freedom of individuals to form the associations of their choice? He cannot be talking about the latter because, according to the fine print of the Bill, the Minister assumes that he knows what an industry organisation is. The Minister will prescribe this by regulation. That flies in the face of international agreements relating to freedom of association. It is tantamount to the dictatorship in Poland saying to Solidarity: 'No, you are not a union. The union shall be structured in this, that or the other way'. The proposals in this legislation usurp the authority of the Industrial Registrar, the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, the Federal Court of Australia and the High Court of Australia. That authority is arrogated by the Minister. The implications of this must surely be studied. I trust that that will be one of the most important functions of the proposed select committee. The Minister stated that the philosophy is:

. . . to open the door to movement from within the work force so that present union rigidities and monopolies are loosened and structures created which are more suited to a modern economy and representative negotiations between employers and employees.

What a lot of nonsense. We are asked to buy a pig in a poke in deciding what industry unions mean. As I and Senator Button have mentioned and as was mentioned by Senator Siddons in his speech just a moment ago, there is no definition whatsoever. The Minister arrogates power by regulation to do what is now the job which is done by the Registrar, the Federal Court and the High Court . The Minister talks about monopolies. Clearly, one understands that the Minister's proposals could well establish a monopoly union situation in certain industries. Whether that is a satisfactory situation and whether it is consistent with the Government's strategic policy for this nation are questions which the Government itself must answer.

Let me return to the point that the Minister made in his speech. It is a distortion of the facts. He said that the Government's decision to withdraw the power of the Commission to award preference is a protection of the rights of the individual. In fact, it is no such thing. That statement shows the ignorance of Mr Viner of the very basis upon which preference for unionists provisions were inserted originally in awards of the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Mr Justice Higgins, in one of his original judgments, clearly indicated that his award of preference was in pursuance of the principles of freedom of association which ensured a circumstance whereby an employer could not impose an anti-union will on his employees and whereby the employees were encouraged by virtue of the award provisions to belong to unions. Of course, those provisions must be read in conjunction with section 144A of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act-the conscientious objections provision section 144A prescribes that where a person satisfies the Registrar that that person's conscientious beliefs do not allow that person to be a member of an organisation and where that person pays the prescribed fee the Registrar shall issue a certificate to that effect. We should bear in mind that the definition of ' conscientious beliefs' is stated as:
. . . any conscientious beliefs, whether the grounds for the beliefs are or are not of a religious character and whether the beliefs are or are not part of the doctrine of any religion;

The Government seeks to repeal section 144A of the Act. It seeks to lump conscientious objectors in with all others who decide not to join a union-the backsliders, the freeloaders, and the agents provocateur, of whom there are some . Here is the Government lumping genuine conscientious objectors, for whose rights I have stood up and fought over the 23 years that I have been a member of the trade union movement, in with backsliders, agents provocateur and simple non -payers. That also is a question which no doubt will be considered when the legislation is considered in the select committee. The members of some groups, including religious groups, for their own reasons, having made a practical judgment-I do not agree with them-as to the rightness or wrongness of the situation, have some conscientious objections to belonging to a union. I invite them to make submissions to the proposed committee when it is set up. I am certain that their submissions would be quite contrary to the Government's attempt to lump them, genuine conscientious objectors, in with all the backsliders.

The proposals that have been mentioned by Senator Siddons have some merit. Although I do not quite understand them, I assume that he means that all persons who are not members of a union should be required by some means or another to pay a fee for service; in other words, that there should be a recognition of the fact that unions spend a great deal of effort, time and money in achieving award provisions which are applicable to members and non-members alike, while always preserving the rights of conscientious objectors. Senator Siddons pointed out that the Australian Democrats' amendments seek to allow existing award provisions to operate but in some way to allow objections to be taken to other provisions similar to what the Government has set out in its legislation. I cannot quite correlate that objective with Senator Siddons's statement about the need for those other than conscientious objectors to pay a fee for service. No doubt that will be explained in detail to the committee. In any event, the Parliament does not have any power to invalidate existing award provisions relating to preference for unionists. There may be a misunderstanding of that provision by some honourable senators, but I am quite clear that the Parliament does not have that power. It is not given the head of power in section 51 (xxxv) of the Constitution. The Minister went on to state:

Fundamental to the Government's approach is its belief that the expression and pursuit of democratic freedoms, including the rights of association and the withholding of labour, and the operation of free institutions, such as trade unions, cannot survive in the absence of law.

That is true, but when we come to framing laws we must ensure that democratic procedures are adopted. Is it democratic-this is another question that ought to be considered by the committee-to reduce the required number of persons approving an amalgamation to 12 1/2 per cent plus one? That is what the Bill provides. At present for an amalgamation to be effective 50 per cent of the union members must vote in the amalgamation ballot, half of whom plus one must vote in favour. Now the Government is proposing that 25 per cent must vote in the case of an industry union-whatever that might mean-half of whom, 12 1/2 per cent, plus one must vote in favour if the amalgamation is to take effect. Is that a democratic procedure? That is also a question that surely must be considered as relevant when the committee deliberates on this measure. The Minister in his statement said:

The notion that for some reason unions are so different that they and the conduct of their members should stand beyond the law is untenable and at the root of much of the industrial trouble Australia has experienced in recent years .

But the question must arise as to how this legislation overcomes that situation. Clearly, it does not do so. The Minister's statement was quite contrary to that of the Acting Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, in January 1982. Mr Anthony said:
You cannot stop strikes and make people behave responsibly simply by passing laws.
We need a new national spirit, a spirit of goodwill and unity; to see what our problems are and what needs to be done about them.

That statement was made by the Acting Prime Minister. But the Minister for Industrial Relations is bringing down legislation which is opposed by thinking people within the trade union movement and by thinking employers. Of course, it will be of central interest to the proposed committee to know what the central trade union movement is doing about regulating itself in matters of industrial disputes.

As I understand it, at the Australian Council of Trade Unions Congress, the President, Cliff Dolan, adverted to rules 13 and 14 of the ACTU relating to the conduct and control of industrial disputes. The more that this is emphasised, the more likely it is that people such as Mr Viner will be painted into a corner and will not have available to them the political motivation to bring down such political legislation as that which is now before the Parliament.
The Minister, in his second reading speech, made another statement concerning the preference for unionists provisions. He stated:
It may be of interest to honourable members to note that this is consistent with provisions passed recently in the United Kingdom Parliament.

How recent is 'recent'? The only amendments which have been passed to the United Kingdom's employment Act were passed in 1980. If that is recent then so be it. But what has been the effect of those amendments relating to preference for unionists and the sanctions that are imposed? We should bear in mind that the Commission cannot award compulsory unionism. Therefore the Government's suggestion that this is an anti-compulsory union Bill is fictitious. It is contrary to the facts. It is not only a distortion of the facts but also it is untrue. There is no provision in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act whereby the Commission can award compulsory unionism; none whatsoever. Any such award has been found to be invalid. For the Government to go to the country and say that this is an anti-compulsory union Bill is untrue.

Let us see what has happened in the United Kingdom following Mrs Thatcher's amendments to the employment Act. I am sure that this will also be of interest to the proposed committee. The United Kingdom legislation-the recent legislation , according to the Minister-came into effect on 1 October 1980. Statistics for industrial disputes in that year showed that the proportion of workers directly involved in disputes whose causes were trade union matters-this is what the English legislation was designed to overcome-was 7.7 per cent. In the year following the legislation that figure had risen to 23.2 per cent of all disputes . That is notwithstanding the fact that the number of disputes had declined because of unemployment. Yet the Minister, Mr Viner, is blindly following Mrs Thatcher down the road to perdition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills that we have before us are the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill 1982 and the Commonwealth Employees (Voluntary Membership of Unions) Bill 1982. In responding to the debate which has taken place, I acknowledge the much greater interest in this chamber in the legislation than is evidenced by the number of speakers who have spoken this evening. I understand that a significant number of honourable senators on both sides of the chamber wished to contribute to the debate. They withdrew on the assumption that a motion referring the Bill to a committee would be passed and that in that circumstance an extended and very lengthy debate on the Bill at this stage would not necessarily be of any assistance. I indicate that it is not the wish of the Government that the Bill should go to a committee. The Government will be opposing that motion. Indeed, the Government will also be moving an amendment to the motion in case it is passed. From the indications I have had from the Australian Labor Party, the Australian Democrats and the Independent senator, Senator Harradine, it would appear that provided all those parties vote together the Bill will go to a committee. I acknowledge the interest of honourable senators on this side of the House who sought to speak on the Bill but who have not spoken because of the situation in which we find ourselves.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some curious aspects to this debate. All honourable senators who have spoken so far have expressed concern about the need for consensus in Australia, a consensus which will form the basis of a better system of industrial relations . I do not think that anybody who has spoken, be it for the Opposition or the Australian Democrats, or Senator Harradine, has claimed that the system is perfect. Of the three speakers so far, Senator Harradine, least of all, has conceded defects in the system. I think that was probably due to the shortage of time. Even he would concede that the system is not necessarily functioning satisfactorily in many respects. I join with those honourable senators who believe it is important that there should be good will. I agree with the statement made by the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) which was read into the debate a little while ago. All those sentiments are very important.

That brings me to what is curious about this debate. It seems to me that when one reads the debate in the other place and considers the debate here it is extraordinary how, in a field in which we are seeking to build consensus and goodwill, so much attention is given to attacking the person and the personality of the present Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) and so little attention is given to the fact that there is broad agreement about the need to move in the directions Mr Viner has set forth in this Bill.

It may be that Senator Harradine is alone in his total opposition to some aspects of this Bill. But I draw the attention of the Senate and the people of Australia to the fact that the Bill puts forward a proposal for a first minor step towards the possibility of industry unions-a step which the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button), who has spoken for the Australian Labor Party today , embraced. It was embraced by Senator Siddons on behalf of the Democrats. There has been some quarrel with the technical aspects of this step and whether there has been a sufficient definition of industry union and so on. I will come to that point later. If one looks at that aspect of the Bill, at the broad concern which has been expressed in the industrial relations community, in the Government, the Opposition and so on about the need for us to be moving towards industry based unions, one sees that the discussion on this Bill could contribute to a greater consensus.

I believe that the provisions which are in the Bill and which I will refer to in more detail shortly do not warrant the comments which were made, particularly in the House of Representatives and to a lesser extent, in the Senate. When we look to the position with respect to stand downs, we find that, notwithstanding the accusation that this is a Bill which will cause industrial conflagration, Senator Siddons, leading for the Democrats, conceded that for small business in particular the protection of a stand down power is important. I will deal again, in more detail, with the attitude of the Australian Democrats with respect to this matter. The key point I wish to make is that this Bill deals with three areas on which I believe there is a broad consensus in the community. Whilst it may be fair for the Parliament to be critical and difficult about the way that sections of this Bill might be phrased and to say that more could be done to define an industry, I believe it is absolutely wrong to categorise a Bill, which essentially deals with the individual freedom of people as to whether they join a union, the question of preference, which relates to industrial unions, and the question of stand downs, which the Democrats, at least, believe is a very important issue for small business and, I think, for the whole business community, as divisive and difficult in the sorts of words that have been used here today. I suggest that people outside this place who are concerned about whether we take an intelligent approach and try genuinely to tackle the problems of Australia compare the pleas for reason and consensus with the way this debate has been conducted. I commend for their attention the debate on this Bill which took place in the House of Representatives and the Opposition's contribution to that debate.

The Bill deals with a series of propositions, some of which, of course, do not give rise to any dispute at all. There are certain technical matters on which I will not waste time. There are matters which relate to the extension of periods for which union officers may hold office. There are various matters which, I understand, have been through the NLCC which are broadly agreed to by all parties and therefore will not be subject to any opposition in this place. There are provisions which relate to various reciprocal arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States which would avoid unions jumping from State to Federal jurisdictions in circumstances of deregistration. I suspect that the Opposition may be opposed to that, but I understand that the Australian Democrats are not opposed to that and were that to come to a vote it would have the support of this Senate.

So there are various elements of the legislation which are widely supported and which would have a majority in this place. That is one of the reasons why I regret that the fate of the Bill could be to be referred to a committee. These useful provisions will, like all other provisions in the Bill, be delayed if that occurs. It is no good the Democrats saying that they will not move to send it to a committee to delay it. Of course the effect of any reference to a committee is to delay the provisions, however desirable they may be.

I refer to the major elements of the legislation and to what the Government has proposed and what attitude had been adopted by honourable senators opposite. We have a proposal which relates to industry unions. I have said already that there is broad agreement in this place that we should move towards a system of industry unions instead of the craft unions which have been a feature of our situation. I think--

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you mean by 'industry unions'?

—I will come to that point, although it is quite adequately explained in the second reading speech. Honourable senators should have taken the trouble to read it. In that regard I remind honourable senators of Senator Button's concern about our need to move gradually and in accordance with the reality of the industrial situation if we are to move to industry unions. If that view is based on the fact that there is an industrial reality outside this place which needs to be accommodated in the legislation, why is there any complaint about the proposal in this legislation that the question of what is an industry should not be precisely defined at this stage but should be defined by regulation after consultation with the parties concerned? It should be defined after consultation with employers, employees and the National Labour Consultative Council. It is clearly established in the second reading speech that:

SPEECH.PARA: It is proposed to leave to regulations the prescription of the classes of industry for which a union can be formed to enable discussions to be held with the ACTU and employers as the process of change is initiated. In this way the development of industry unions can occur in consultation with unions and employers directly involved and the peak employer and union bodies.

Nothing could more clearly fit the problem which was defined by the Leader of the Opposition in his speech. We will be feeling our way in this area. We will be moving to a desirable objective. I suggest to the Senate that the scheme of the Bill which has been put down by Mr Viner on behalf of the Government acknowledges that this is a novelty and that it is a matter of moving into some uncharted waters.

Another small point with respect to industry based unions was the point made by Senator Button which suggested that unions of any other sort could no longer be registered. That shows a misreading of the Bill. There is nothing which affects the existing classifications of unions which may be registered under the legislation. Those provisions are not touched. Those provisions remain; we have added to them.
