TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was addressing myself to the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill which is being debated in this chamber. I had made the point that, whilst the Bill had been described as one which would produce a high level of disputation and, indeed, was described by the Democrats as one which would produce unprecedented industrial confrontation, it in fact deals with propositions which have support or partial support right around the chamber. I mentioned the support for industry unions which had been expressed by the Opposition, the Democrats and the Australian Council of Trade Unions and, I think, not by Senator Harradine but that may have been by omission. Certainly within the Government there has been long-standing support for that proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The availability of the stand down power to small business is admitted by the Democrats to be of fundamental importance, yet the attempt to extend that is again seen in very dramatic terms. I was trying to direct the attention of the Senate to the great degree of common ground and to the common sense which lies behind what has been put forward in this legislation. To return to industry unions with which I was dealing at the time of the suspension of the sitting, the position of the ACTU was laid down in its constitution as long ago as 1927. It refers to the development of the trade union movement towards an industrial basis and the amalgamations of unions where practicable to establish one union in each industry or sector.

We find this is supported by the Jackson Committee to Advise on Policies for Manufacturing Industry in its report of October 1975 which referred to the present fragmentation of unions, the difficulties to which that gives rise and the fact that that is a fertile field for demarcation and jurisdictional disputes. Let me refer to the remarks made by Senator Button during his contributions to debate in this place on the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill (No. 2) on 25 November 1981. His comments made it quite clear that he regards demarcation disputes as a serious problem. He said:

Further, the present position of the law discourages and delays attempts to form industry based unions by adding another pitfall in the procedure which must be followed to effect an amalgamation between more than two unions.

The most significant criticism made of this attempt to come to grips with what everybody says is a desirable goal seems to be that there has been an inadequate definition of industry. As I pointed out before the suspension of the sitting and as Senator Button pointed out, the industrial scene is one in which the realities will impose themselves on the pattern. It is fair enough that we should be putting forward a proposal which involves the careful preparation of regulations describing an industry, regulations which will be drawn only after consultation with the employers and the unions which might be involved.

I see this Bill, which I support, as an attempt to take an early step towards what has been agreed as a generally desirable goal. I regret that the Opposition in the Senate should see the need to subject this matter to further inquiry and debate over months and to delay the introduction of the legislation. The Bill also deals with the matter of stand downs. On this matter Mr Viner said:

If unions are to have as a basic principle the right to strike then it is surely not unreasonable for employers to have at their individual disposal the right to protect their commercial interests in circumstances where they are put at risk by union action.

It is quite clear that there is at the moment an inequality in this area. It is a fact that unions are able to go on strike without notice and without safeguards being present and cause employers very considerable difficulty. In the absence of some provision of an award permitting a stand down the employer is not in an equal position. I think that the remedying of that defect is something which would be seen as a very considerable advantage by a large section of Australians. The fact is that that inequality of the position between the employer and the employee in these areas is something that is widely recognised. It is no good harking back to the days when the employee could be seen as somebody who could be just put upon at the will of the employer. I think those days have long gone. The public, which is so often the victim of industrial action that is not going through the protective provisions which are available and not being subjected to the processes of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, understands that there is an inequality of bargaining power which needs to be rectified. I want to refer to the support which has been given to this concept by the Australian Democrats. A few days ago they publicly said:

The Democrats believe that the right to stand down employees who cannot be employed due to industrial action elsewhere is necessary for employers, in particular for small businesses, if they are to survive.

In the Democrats' view we are talking about something which is necessary for small business if it is to survive. That is why this legislation ought to be proceeded with and passed. This is an important power if, in the words of the Democrats, employers are to survive. I was asked where the safeguards are. That was an important point in the challenging of this section. Will those honourable gentlemen opposite who are asking for safeguards accept mandatory safeguards against employees going on strike? It seems to me that that is a reasonable quid pro quo and I accept the logic of the position. If honourable senators wish to assert that there should be safeguards, surely there should be mutuality in those safeguards. But we do not have a system in which the right to strike is entrammeled by having to get the permission of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission; the right to strike is availed of without warning. I suggest that if there is a genuine belief that we should produce some equality in this area the need for the sort of safeguard which has been claimed is not there.

The position of the Democrats on this matter is that if the Government does not accept their amendments they will vote against the automatic stand down proposals. I simply draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that there is no difference in principle between us in the sense that there is an acceptance of the need for stand downs. The difference is on a narrower point of what safeguards should be available. I point out that the safeguards are not available with respect to the prevention of a strike which could be very damaging to employers. The question of equality, therefore, is non-existent if one accepts the Democrats' view, and it was the point of equality which was stressed in the debate on this Bill.

The third major area with which this Bill deals is the field of voluntary unionism. It is in this area that, I think, it is quite evident that there is some real philosophic difference between us but it is a difference in which I think the Government's position is much closer to the community consensus than is the position which is being adopted by the Opposition. It was evident from the tone of the debate we heard that to some people the fact that a man is not a member of a union is something which one would say is almost pejorative-that it is a sign that there is something wrong with that person because he is not a member of a union. I would have thought--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—It is quite obvious from the contribution of, for example, Senator Harradine, that non-membership of a union is wrong in the absence of a conscientious objection. He seems to think that if a man is not a conscientious objector he is a backslider if he is not a member of a union. I have to say that I do not believe that that is the basic attitude of members of the community whom every honourable senator in this place is supposed to represent. I do not believe that the Australian community regards a man who does not wish to be a member of a union as a backslider or as someone to whom one applies some other abusive term.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —If I may take up the objection which--

—Order! I suggest that the interjections be a little less audible than they are at present because even I, from the chair, am having difficulty hearing the Minister. Whilst I will not stop the interjections I ask that their intensity be lessened.

—The basic objection put forward by Senator Harradine was that the provisions meant that conscientious objectors were lumped together with backsliders and others whom he described. The simple fact is that if the obligation to become a member of a union were removed there would be no need for a conscientious objector provision. A person is free to make up his or her mind as to whether to become a member of a union. I find it quite extraordinary, as I think does the great bulk of people in Australia, that honourable senators opposite should find if offensive that people should have freedom of choice about whether to join a union. If they do not join a union it can be an impediment to their obtaining employment.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation has been described in strong terms by the Opposition. I point out that in leading the debate for the Opposition Senator Button said he thought it was 'beaut conceptually'-they are his words-but he went on to talk about the practical difficulties in moving to a situation in which no preference is given to unionists. If there is a genuine wish in this chamber to follow the sentiments that were so carefully expressed, I believe, by Senator Button for the Opposition and by Senator Siddons for the Democrats we should be trying to build a consensus and we ought to be capable of examining, without heat or emotion, the concept of whether a man can be forced to join a union to see whether the patterns of the past are to be changed.

I make the general comment about this legislation that there seems to be a great preparedness to attack it because it differs from some practices of the past. Senator Button has had extensive practice in the law in this field; Senator Harradine has had extensive practice as a union official and knows the field; and Senator Siddons is an employer of a large number of people and has had practical experience in this field. With great respect to those honourable senators who believe they are practitioners, including the honourable senator shaking his head, perhaps only the practitioners are satisfied with the past pattern of industrial relations in this country. Many of the people in Australia are not satisfied and are looking for the sort of changes the Government is introducing in this legislation. They are looking for a community in which people are free to join or not to join a union, in which a man is entitled to earn his livelihood without being forced to join a union, in which an employer can protect himself against strikes, and in which unions are organised on an industry basis, which is supposedly common ground around this chamber.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —A series of matters is being raised by interjection now, and I have no time to deal with them. If the sentiments expressed in this debate are genuine, to some extent that will be borne out, if the Opposition succeeds in having this matter referred to a committee, in the way in which the committee is conducted and the way in which the members show by their membership of that committee whether they are genuinely trying to get to the facts, the truth and solutions which will work. Whilst I oppose the reference to a committee and whilst I am about to move an amendment to the amendment moved by Senator Button, if Senator Button's amendment, requiring the legislation to be sent to a committee succeeds, I believe it is incumbent on the committee members to work in the spirit of the speeches made in this place and to demonstrate by that that their remarks are genuine.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has been elected three times on an industrial relations platform which includes commitments to industry based unions and to voluntary unionism. To suggest that, when we bring in this legislation in the terms which I described, it should go to a committee is specious and unnecessary. I move:
(1) Paragraph (d), line 1, leave out 'seven', insert 'eight'.
(2) Paragraph (d) sub-paragraph (1), leave out 'three', insert 'four'.

That amendment should have been circulated, but I shall quickly explain it. Senator Button's amendment calls for the setting up of a select committee which will have seven members: Three nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, two nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, one to be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats and an independent senator. The purpose of my amendment is to restore what has been the main practice in the Senate, which is to have an equality of Government and Opposition or non- Government senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —They did not have it in the Townley committee.

—I will come to that. The normal Senate practice has been to have an equal number of government and opposition senators. I therefore moved that amendment. I sought information from the Clerks as to the practice. It is well known to all honourable senators that our standing committees operate on the basis of an equality of membership with, effectively, a government majority. If we look at the record from 1970 to 1979 we will find 11 select committees, and in the case of all but two of them there is an equality of numbers with a government chairman. One exception is the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange in regard to which former Senator Murphy moved that there should be an opposition chairman, namely Senator Rae, who chaired the Committee before the election of the Labor Government. The other exception which is a precedent for this matter is the Senate Select Committee on the Rights of Migrant Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it will be something of a test of the sentiments expressed by Opposition speakers who claim that we should build a consensus in this area to see whether they are prepared to accept an amendment which will be in accordance with the most usual arrangements of the Senate and an earnest of their good faith in this matter. There is a tradition in this place whereby many committees -both select and standing committees-are able to tackle problems in a sensible way and are able to produce reports which are not based on party divisions. In this area in which there are claims from members of both the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats that we should be moving towards a national consensus, they should be prepared to show their faith in the processes which have so often served the Senate and, I believe, Australia well. I commend the Bills to the Senate and I oppose the Opposition's amendment. I moved my amendment to ensure that, should the Opposition's amendment be passed, the resolution will be in a better form than it otherwise would be.

I repeat: It is a sad thing that when so much lip service is paid to the idea that we should be striving for some unity of purpose in this area, Bills which do no more than take the first step towards the promotion of industry unions and to increase the freedom of people to belong to unions or not to belong to unions as they choose without the interference of the laws or anybody else in their lives, should be regarded as being so contentious, as something that the Senate cannot deal with for months and as something which gives rise to the sort of comments that were made in this place about the Minister who brought them forward. I commend the Bills to the Senate and trust they will have passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the amendment, although I have not spoken previously in the debate. It is not my intention to speak at length because we have agreed to co-operate with the Government in expediting the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill and the Commonwealth Employees (Voluntary Membership of Unions) Bill, but the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) made one or two remarks that are a little provocative. I want to commend the Minister on his speech.
—I would not.

—I know that Senator Georges would not commend him. He had a lot to say by way of interjection during the Minister's speech. I should have thought that it was one of the more constructive consensus-seeking speeches made by a Minister in regard to industrial relations that I have heard for a long time.
—Sanctimonious pap!

—Senator Evans says 'sanctimonious pap'. It is easy to lounge back there and make that remark. I would like to hear from Senator Evans some time as to how he believes that kind of a remark helps constructively in a debate which affects industrial relations, one of the most contentious matters of this time. Senator Chaney quite properly said that at least as far as the Australian Democrats are concened, and I think as far as the Australian Labor Party is concerned, the distance between us is not as far on these matters as it might appear to be.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the standdown provisions. The Australian Democrats certainly believe that some rights should be given to a small business person to stand down an employee who cannot be gainfully employed because of industrial action elsewhere. For instance, there may be an electricity blackout, or a Transport Workers Union strike may prevent raw materials from coming into a factory. There is no argument-I do not think the Labor Party would advance an argument; in fact , I know that the Labor Party do not advance an argument-that an employer in such a situation should be forced to keep on his employees ad infinitum and go bankrupt. The Labor Party agrees that there is justice in standdowns in that case; the Australian Democrats agree that there is justice in that; and the Government agrees that there is justice in that. But the Labor Party and the Democrats say that by bitter experience it is wrong to give all employees an automatic standdown right which in the past they have abused, particularly in the building industry, standing down workers four days out of five because standing down an employee is much cheaper than sacking an employee. Abuses have crept into this.

If the Government wants to facilitate stand-down provisions, the Democrats will support it, but will not support it in what it is trying to do in this Bill. We absolutely agree with the Labor Party that, if there is such a simple methodology of standing down an employee, some unscrupulous employer can simply go to a justice of the peace and make a declaration, saying: 'I believe that nine out of 10 of my employees should be stood down' and if ipso facto they are stood down they have no right of appeal to any person. I do not believe that any reasonable-minded person, particularly the Minister, can see justice in that. All we are saying, and as far as I can understand it all the Labor Party is saying, is: 'Let that declaration be subject to some appeal'. The appeal mechanism is there in the form of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. That has worked for five years. I have yet to meet an employer who objects to the present provisions in the Act. My colleague Senator Siddons, the most distinguished and experienced industrialist in this chamber, has not spoken to an employer who objects about the present provisions in the Act. Let the Minister name one employer who has asked the Government to change the standdown provisions in the Act. Let the Minister name one employer who can recount an experience of the present legislation acting adversely against him. We have issued that challenge in earlier debates and not one name has been trotted out. In fact, we can quote the names of employers who have come to us and said: 'For God's sake, stop the Government doing this insanity because it will breed confrontation and chaos'.

Similarly, as Senator Harradine suggests, there is a dilemma with the preference provision. It is a very big dilemma. The Democrats agree with Senator Chaney that no one should be forced to join an organisation. I do not know the expression Senator Harradine used, whether he used the term 'backsliders' or ' freeloaders' or whatever. It is difficult to get a word that describes them without giving offence. I have been guilty of using the word 'bludgers'. I find that offensive. It is a peculiar type of individual-he may belong to an industry or a factory-who allows his mates in that factory to pay their dues of $50 or $ 60 a year to a trade union, and that is the average union fee, to win safety conditions, better showers, better wages and other conditions and then says: 'I am not going to make a contribution to the fight for better conditions or better safety, I am simply going to be a freeloader'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a better word.

—That is a far better word than 'bludger' or 'backslider'. We agree on that. We have come to a consensus on the word 'freeloader'. There is a dilemma about preference. The Australian Democrats' compromise is a fee for service. We say that we should not force anybody to join a union but we can take away preference and institute a fee for service that is paid either into Consolidated Revenue or to the union fund where it cannot be used for political purposes. We say that a person in an industry should not be a freeloader but should pay towards the costs of fighting injustices or gaining better conditions . A person should not be forced to pay money into an organisation, namely, a union, out of which money can be extracted to supplement a political party, whether it be the Communist Party, the Labor Party, the Democrats, the Democratic Labor Party, the National Civic Council or whatever, against his wishes. We say that is wrong. We have put forward a compromise. We are not saying that it is the answer to everything; we are saying it is a possible answer. That is why Senator Button's proposition that the matter should go to a select committee appealed to us. Had the Government demonstrated that in either of these two areas urgency called-namely, that massive damage was being done by the employers not having the right of automatic stand-downs or that preference for unionists had caused massive disputation and the loss of incredible amounts of time in disputes in the last year-we would have been reluctant to defer this matter by sending it to a select committee. The Government has not done that.

SPEECH.PARA: What does Senator Button's amendment mean? It means that for three sitting weeks or 16 actual weeks between now and the first sitting week in September we will ask distinguished members of the Senate to take public evidence. We will ask members of the Senate to say to small business people, trade unions, big business and industry associations: 'Come and tell us the bugs in this proposed legislation. Is there any way in which this legislation, good though its intent might be, can be improved? Are there any ways in which this legislation might unconsciously cause strife?' Is there anything wrong with that proposition? I think that Senator Button has done a most responsible thing in moving his amendment. The Government could have said: 'To move and pass this amendment will cause chaos in the community'. But no Government speaker has said that. Senator Chaney has not said it; nor has any Government speaker in the other House. The Minister has not said it; nor has he demonstrated it.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not think about it.

—I am trying to pay the debate the respect which I think the contributions of Senators Button, Siddons, Harradine and Chaney deserve. I think it is one of the best debates that we have had in the Senate chamber for some time. I conclude by commenting on the amendment to the amendment, namely, the amendment moved by the Government proposing the constitution of the committee be changed. Senator Button has moved that there be three Government senators on this seven-person committee; that is, two Labor, one Democrat and one Independent, who, of course, is Senator Harradine. The Government has put forward a proposition that the number be increased from seven to eight and that the Government and this side have four each. I am not opposed to the Government having equal representation on this committee but if the committee polarises on party lines, which it would do in the election of a chairman, there would be four votes for a Government nominee and four votes for a non-Government nominee. There would be a tie. I understand that then a coin is flipped and whoever comes up heads is chairman of the committee and has not only a deliberative vote but also a casting vote. It has been put to me today by Government Ministers that in these matters it is traditional for a Government member to be the Chairman of a select committee. I do not know quite what the word 'traditional' means.
—It didn't happen in the migrant civil rights committee.
—Was that when Senator Murphy raided the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation?
—Senator Townley, an Opposition senator, was chairman.

—I am not too interested in past history but I am told-I do not put too much weight on these figures-that since Federation there have been 43 Senate select committees of which 17 have had non-government majorities and non- government chairmen. I do not put too much weight on those figures because I am told that before 1910 there were not too many organised parties in this place anyway. But I have been told that there have been a few distinguished exceptions , including the one that my friend Senator Mulvihill announced-the Senate select committee inquiring into the notorious raid by a present High Court judge into the headquarters of ASIO. That committee had a non-government chairman.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite apart from tradition-I have said this before-I believe that we all live under the myth in this place that the Executive, the Cabinet or the Government is separate from the Parliament. This is not the Government where we are meeting tonight. This is one House of the Parliament. It does not matter a damn which party is in government when it comes to this chamber exercising its business. In fact, I have heard those sentiments quite properly expressed by Government senators time and again and have applauded them for it. So, it is a total irrelevancy to say, for any reason-the least of which should be a traditional one-that a Government member should be the chairman of a select committee. I would have thought that the person best suited to the task should be the chairman of any committee of this chamber. I would be very happy to vote for the Government's amendment so that the committee would have four Government and four Opposition members, but that means that the election of the chairman is then left to the flip of a coin. My friend and colleague Senator Siddons tells me of his recent experience on another Senate select committe that was appointed to inquire into the Bendigo Clothing Factory. He said that that committee was ruthlessly mismanaged because a Government member was chairman. The Government overrode objections and the Government directed the business of that committee towards its own ends, and we are not going-

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he say that?
—He did say that and I believe you, sir, were one of the offenders , a ruthless offender.
—Ruthlessly correct.

—I acknowledge the interjection, for incorporation into Hansard, of Senator Crichton-Browne, who just said that what I was saying was ruthlessly correct. I record in Hansard that Senator Crichton-Browne said that, which vindicates me in what I am saying. Therefore, we are not prepared, after that experience, to take the chance-
—You would acknowledge that the Senate committees do not usually divide on party lines. We do not do that.

—I will concede that. I pay a tribute to Senator Walters's colleague Senator Archer, who is chairing with great distinction a select committee upon which I have the honour of serving now. But I am saying that there has been experience in this place of the casting vote of a chairman being abused. In this very important matter we are not prepared to take that risk. Therefore, we will be voting against the amendment to the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented. I do not want to labour a trivial allegation which is known to Senator Button and Senator Siddons to be quite untrue, without substance and without fact, but I think it is worth putting on the record that Senator Martyr was elected chairman of that committee unanimously by Senator Siddons, Senator Button and me. At no stage was there any complaint about the conduct of his chairing of that committee, about the way he cross-examined witnesses and about the way he accommodated contrary views from Senator Button and Senator Siddons from time to time. In fact, as I reported when I spoke to the majority report, I thought that there was a fair amount of goodwill and fellowship amongst all of us. There was certainly no complaint from Senator Siddons. I am disappointed to hear that he has had to go back to his chief and tell him what he has not been prepared to tell me or to complain about to the Chairman or to Senator Button.
—Order!
—If there is any substance--
—Order! Senator, you claimed to have been misrepresented. You are ranging rather wide of the mark.
—The misrepresentation is that there was something improper about the conduct of myself and Senator Martyr on that Committee.
—You said so yourself.
—No, I did not. You misrepresented me like you misrepresented Senator Siddons a moment ago.
—Have a look tomorrow at the Hansard record of what you said.
—I know what I said. It is how you repeated it--
—Senator Crichton-Browne, address your remarks through the Chair.

—Anyway, I am quite sure that if Senator Button had had any complaints-he is a man of integrity, impartiality and decency-he would have complained during the period of the committee. He did not. I found Senator Siddons very easy to work with, and he made no complaint either. The only complaint I have heard has come from Senator Chipp, which rather surprises me. Perhaps, on reflection, it should not. I can only say that I find it disappointing that he has cast aspersions upon those members of the committee that brought down very reasoned and balanced reports, whether it be the minority report or the majority report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate on the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill was adjourned last night I was in the process of explaining the Australian Labor Party's support for the use of fully retrospective legislation as a counter to certain classes of tax avoidance and in particular the appropriateness of the application of retrospective legislation to the accumulation of tax free capital gains in defiance of section 26AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act by the Bell and Bond corporations in the last couple of years.

SPEECH.PARA: I will recapitulate what I said about retrospectivity only to the extent of summarising in the couple of minutes I have left the basic elements in the ALP's position. They are essentially four-fold. They cannot be repeated too often. Firstly, we take the view that fully restrospective legislation is the most effective known deterrent to the use of tax avoidance schemes. It is a way of dealing with those schemes which will make unnecessary continued resort to massively detailed amendments of the kind that we have been seeing in recent years. Secondly, our position is that the use of retrospectivity is justified only where blatantly contrived schemes are concerned, namely, the kinds of schemes which have no conceivable commercial justification other than tax avoidance, the kinds of schemes which nobody could go into other than with their eyes open as to their true nature and the kinds of schemes which Parliament could easily be persuaded were of this nature. Thirdly, we take the view that full retrospectivity is not appropriate where wide-ranging discretions of the Commissioner of Taxation are needed to deal with some particular avoidance scheme or arrangement. Rather, we take the view that this kind of legislative strategy is appropriate only in the context of very specific measures to deal with equally specific known abuses. Finally-perhaps most importantly of all-we do not advocate the retrospective application of penal provisions. We regard retrospectivity as appropriate only to ensure that the taxpayer ends up paying the tax which was due and at the otherwise applicable marginal rates in respect of the scheme in question. We think it is possible to gain general acceptance for this approach. We look forward to the day when both the Government and the Australian Democrats will join us in seeing not only the desirablility but also the inevitability of taking measures of this kind.

I conclude by saying that we welcome this legislation as a serious-minded attempt to cope with some major loopholes evident in the previous law. We do not think the legislation goes far enough for the reasons that I have explained but at least it makes the attempt. If the cancer of tax avoidance with all its inequality and all the sense of injustice that it creates is to be rooted out we have to get a lot tougher than this Government has so far been prepared to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are tonight debating the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1982 which seeks to make ten principal amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act. The Bill before us is a demonstration of the Government's continuing determination to crack down on tax avoidance, particularly in the areas of trust estates, profits, the disposal of certain shares and transfer pricing. I think the Bill also demonstrates to the Australian community the human face of the Liberal-National Country Party coalition. Clause 9 provides an extension of the deductions which are available under section 78, principally to include donations to the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals in the various States and the Territories and donations of $2 or more to three appeals concerned with relief for Poland-namely , the Help Poland Live appeal conducted by the Australian National Committee for Relief to Poland, the Australian Red Cross Poland Appeal and the World Vision of Australia Poland Emergency Appeal. The measures relating to donations to appeals for Poland were announced on 18 February 1981 and deductions for donations of $2 or more, under section 78 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, applied as from 5 February 1982.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me deal with a number of areas in which we intended to close up loopholes that existed in the Income Tax Assessment Act. Honourable senators may recall that in 1980 a series of amendments were passed in relation to trust estates. Those amendments were intended to close up the loopholes in the then existing legislation. Unfortunately, in our society it is the business of a number of practising accountants and lawyers to seek a number of legal technicalities whereby they can overcome certain provisions of the Act for the benefit of their clients. It is the intention of the Government to trace these loopholes through and to introduce legislation to crack down on such tax avoiding schemes.

The Bill contains two principal amendments in relation to trust estates. The first one concerns beneficiaries who are presently entitled to income which does not relate to an individual; in other words a company or a beneficiary acting in the capacity of a trustee of a further trust estate. By this we mean that a number of multiple trusts are in use, in each of which an indefeasible vested interest below the tax threshold applies. In the first case, that of trusts, we seek to tax the income to which a beneficiary is presently entitled at the tax rates appropriate to the status of the beneficiary, subject to a tax threshold of $4,195.

In the second case we are seeking to close a loophole which developed as a result of amendments made to the principal Act in 1980. In the 1980 legislation we provided an initial threshhold of $1,040. Tax was applied to the trust income of children, being unearned income, which exceeded that threshhold. An exception was when the income was derived from employment. Astute tax avoiders set up trusts which had the formal content of trusts in respect of services rendered, thereby overcoming the exclusion in relation to employment income over the threshhold of $1,040, which would have attracted a tax of 46 per cent. There is an obvious injustice and we are determined to crack down on that loophole.

We are also concerned that the astute tax avoiders have manipulated section 26AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Section 26AAA sought to bring to tax profits made on property sales made within 12 months of purchase. These astute tax avoiders sold their shares in a company that actually made the profits. The intention of the legislation before us tonight is to bring to tax the profits made on the sale of shares in companies which engage in property aquisition and sales, subject to a profit making undertaking or scheme, within a 12-month period.

The other area about which I wish to speak-I do not wish to speak on all the areas covered by the amending legislation-relates to depreciation. The Bill provides for a concessional basis for taxing industries associated with basic iron or steel production. We welcome the opportunity which is given to the steel industry to write of by way of depreciation charges its capital equipment costs over a five-year period. I think it is somewhat unfortunate that only one industry has been picked out. Australian manufacturers need the Income Tax Assessment Act and its associated regulations to provide greater flexibility as far as depreciation charges are concerned. We would also like to see a reduction in the number of categories in the income tax order relating to depreciation, and an increase in the rates, thereby enabling Australian businesses to become much more competitive on the international scene.

Australian businesses are in a great deal of difficulty in that they are being hamstrung by inadequate depreciation charges and have to compete in price on overseas markets. In other words there is less incentive for Australian manufacturers to invest in new equipment where the charges are inadequate. I certainly would press for an extension of the sorts of depreciation rates that are currently embodied in the legislation which are restricted to the iron ore and steel production industries, to cover the manufacturing industry generally. We hope that by effecting a reduction in the number of categories we will bring about a greater flexibility which will enable Australian industry to compete more effectively in the international scene. Certainly this Bill, if it is passed, will provide that flexibility to the iron and steel industries, but we would like it to be extended in the future to the whole of manufacturing industry.

I am very pleased to report on the attack on transfer pricing. Honourable senators will know of the concern I have had ever since I came to the Senate about certain practices by multinational companies operating in Australia and effectively transferring their profits out of Australia. That means that the Australian tax authorities do not get their just share of the revenue. Furthermore, it places Australian manufacturing firms owned by Australians at a tax disadvantage and a cash disadvantage, because they are not really competing on equal terms. I think Senator Siddons spoke in some depth on this matter. He comes from a firm which is Australian-owned and Australian controlled and which possibly has to compete with some of these firms which, we thought, under the provisions of the previous section 136 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, were forbidden to engage in transfer pricing practices. As a result of a number of representations and an investigation and report by the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources concerning the aluminium industry, the Treasurer (Mr Howard) at last recognised the need to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act and introduced extensive amendments to the provisions which had stood for many years in the form of section 136 to limit the practice of transfer pricing.

The Bill before us tonight also makes provision for certain medical expenses paid to a group or company practice to be tax deductible. Honourable senators might recall that in Peate's case a doctor's arrangement was shot down by the High Court of Australia under section 260 of the Act. Technically, the decision in Peate's case represented good law to the present time. It was felt by the Government that tradesmen and others had the advantage of taking others into a practice, partnership and so on but if a doctor tried to do such a thing he would be shot down by virtue of Peate's case. Certainly, the Commissioner of Taxation could take action, probably under Part IVA, by virtue of that decision. This amendment does not enable doctors to take their wives into partnership, but it enables them to take other practising doctors into partnership. In cases where a doctor takes a fellow doctor into partnership and they form a company and render services to a client, the client, if he has concessional expenses over $1,590, can claim a rebate on the item.

It is rather unfortunate that a number of professions have sought to reduce their ethical status to take away their personal liability responsibilities, but I suppose they are recognising some of the present day practices of increasing amounts of litigation being directed in respect of professional negligence. They are taking measures to protect themselves against what might be excessive court claims. This amendment to the Income Tax Assessment Act recognises the change in the professional arrangements that are being made, particularly in the medical profession. There is a basic condition that a doctor must be in partnership with his professional colleagues, in other words, with other doctors. The provision forbids a doctor taking his wife or children into partnership. Certainly, that practice could be attacked very strongly under Part IVA and all its penalties would be applied. Peate's case is still good law so it is necessary to introduce this change to enable medical practitioners to combine in a company and to enable the recipients of their services to be able to claim expenses which will be rebatable provided their total concessional expenses exceed $1,590.

The Opposition has questioned some of the penalties that were mentioned in relation to transfer pricing. Some honourable senators felt that the penalty of a 10 per cent charge was not high enough and, prima facie, this might appear to be the case. But that argument overlooked the fact that the 10 per cent penalty is not a tax deduction, so the effective charge is not 10 per cent but more in the vicinity of 18 or 19 per cent. Transfer pricing practices are not in the same category as the ordinary Part IVA arrangements. By these arrangements I mean the blatantly contrived, artificial schemes for which Senator Evans felt there was some justification in introducing an element of retrospectivity. Perhaps the 10 per cent charge for the late payment in these days of higher inflation, even though it is not tax deductible and is an effective charge of 18 or 19 per cent, will be subject to change at some future time. I hope that the Minister who replies will make some comment on this later in the evening.

The only other matter I wish to raise in relation to this Bill is that I thought it was regrettable that in this debate the Reverend Fred Nile's name was mentioned rather uncharitably. The Reverend Fred Nile is now a member of the Legislative Council in New South Wales. I draw honourable senators' attention to his maiden speech in the Parliamentary Debates of 25 November 1981. In that speech Reverend Nile recognised that because of Press reports people were getting a one-sided view of his philosophy. He stated:

Some honourable members of this House would have heard of my name before and have perhaps formed impressions of me based mainly on the mass media. All honourable members know how dangerous that can be. I would rather be judged in this House for what I really am, rather than the news media image, which may or may not be true to life.

Reverend Nile then spoke about his concern for high taxation, unemployment and inflation. He drew attention to the working class having to bear the burden for certain types of income taxation. It is probably appropriate, when considering the question of tax avoidance and moral ethics, to refer to the final paragraph of Reverend Nile's maiden speech. He quoted French philosopher, Albert Camus, who won the 1957 Nobel Prize, as saying:

The world expects of Christians that they will raise their voices so loudly and clearly and so formulate their protest that there is not even the slightest doubt what they are saying. Further, the world expects of Christians that they will eschew all fuzzy abstractions and plant themselves squarely in front of the bloody face of history. We stand in need of folk who have determined to speak directly and unmistakeably and, come what may, to stand by what they have said.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have often read that it is important to have pauses in speeches and my pause was at the beginning. I want to make a brief contribution to the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1982. There has been a wide-ranging debate on this topic. It is a complex piece of legislation. Senator Hill, who spoke earlier, made that point and certainly Senator Watson did. The Bill contains provisions dealing with tax avoidance, both internationally and domestically, relating to short term capital gains and gifts of art. It also deals with zone allowances, living away from home allowances for Service personnel, depreciation for the steel industry, gifts to charity, changes to rebate provisions for medical expenses and so on. It is a complex, wide-ranging piece of legislation. It adds further complexities to an already highly complex piece of legislation. The income tax laws are becoming increasingly incomprehensible. Their very incomprehensibility is a cause of much litigation and many loopholes in the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Income Tax Assessment Act in Australia now runs to more than 1,000 pages. I make this point simply because it is our view that a very wide-ranging inquiry into the Income Tax Assessment Act is now needed, with the aim of simplifying tax laws. I do not want to be always attributing blame in relation to these matters. It is not necessarily helpful to the political debate to do so. But I make the point that in 1975 the Taxation Review Committee under the chairmanship of Mr Justice Asprey tabled its report. Whatever one thinks about each and every one of the many conclusions which the Committee drew in that report, it was a very thorough document. If one looks even through the index of the Asprey Committee's report one will see many references to the importance of simplicity in tax legislation. Part of the blame for the present situation must be attributed to the Fraser Government, after six and nearly seven years in government, because it allowed the Act to deteriorate and become so complex.

The Government has failed also to introduce retrospective legislation to close off tax loopholes. I think that is very important. In various debates in this chamber we have discussed the desirability or otherwise of retrospective legislation. But in respect of the major social evil with which this country is confronted, namely tax avoidance, there should no longer be much room for argument about the desirability and moral and social validity of retrospective legislation as a means of preventing tax avoidance. The result of that failure has been a flourishing tax avoidance industry. It is now anybody's guess as to how much a wealthy section of the community is getting away with in terms of tax avoidance. That goes to the very moral fibre of this country. The fact is that 85 per cent of pay-as-you-earn taxpayers are paying 22 per cent more tax as a result of the last Budget because others in this society, through selfishness or for other reasons, are not paying the tax that they ought to be paying. That is a crucial moral, political and social issue for this country to face up to.

We have been debating industrial relations legislation here today. It is not only a question of what legislation like that contains, what machinery it provides for conciliating disputes, or what machinery it provides for fair shares in wages policy. We cannot get anywhere with those sorts of issues in the system in which a wages policy is sought to be established-not by this Government but by a better one than this, one would hope-unless there is confidence in the integrity of a progressive tax system. There is no confidence in the integrity of a progressive tax system in this country. Because of that, there is no room for establishing under this Government the basis for a social consensus about fair shares in respect of incomes and wages. The importance of that, I believe, cannot be overestimated because, until agreement is reached about that important social issue, not only are fair shares impossible but also the symbolism of a just society in terms of distribution of income is not there. So tax avoidance, in a sense, has become a symbolic issue. As I said before, it is an important moral and social issue which goes to the core of the integrity of the Government and the system of government in this country.

One of the main aims of this legislation is to amend section 136 of the Income Tax Assessment Act so as to close off loopholes relating to transfer pricing. This provision of the legislation is to be applauded. The only sad thing about it is that it is seven years too late. In 1975, the Asprey Committee, to which I referred, mentioned the need to close off these loopholes which were available to transnational corporations. If one looks at the Asprey report they were, obviously, then being exploited by these corporations which ensure, if they can, that their profits are maximised in places with low tax rates such as Hong Kong, Manila and Malaysia in certain circumstances. What companies do in this situation is to ensure that their profits are earned in countries which have a low level of taxation. In 1975, as I have said, the Asprey Committee commented on this and drew the attention of the Government to it. Now, after a seven-year honeymoon or whatever-a seven-year itch; certainly a seven-year irritation for this society-the Government has finally seen fit to act on the matter.

In the meantime, companies have been putting their bickies in the tin for the rainy day which might happen when we get a decent government in this country and they have to pay their taxes as they ought to pay them. It is not just simply a case of Australia, as a society, losing tax revenue from these people. The potential damage caused by transnationals engaged in transfer pricing can include many other things other than the tax revenue loss to government. It can include loss of profits to local shareholders, which is something that local shareholders ought to be more conscious of. They do not have legislation to protect them, as trade unionists do under the Fraser Government, to make sure that they do everything exactly as they are told! Shareholders are not in that position. Perhaps they are not as aware as they ought to be of the loss of profits to local shareholders from transfer pricing.

Secondly, transfer pricing results in loss of higher wages to Australian workers for the same sorts of reasons. Businesses which operate in this country, and their employees, are all in the same boat. It is not a very healthy boat at the moment. There are a lot of leaks. But they are all in the same boat and the sooner there is greater recognition of that fact, the better it will be for this country. Further, transfer pricing can lead to a reduction in our balance of payments, already notoriously sick. It can lead similarly to a loss of foreign exchange. So, while we welcome the action incorporated in this legislation, we regret very much that it has come too late. We regret very much the fact that the penalties provided by the Government for this form of tax avoidance are inconsistently low when compared with penalties applied elsewhere in the legislation and are inconsistent with the moral turpitude-if I may use that stern Victorian expression-of tax avoidance. We want to make it quite clear that --

TALK.START.PARA: —Very nice.
—Senator Messner laughs. Moral turpitude is something that he probably has not heard about since he was in kindergarten. He ought to hear more about it now.
—You should read some more of Anthony Trollope.

—Senator Messner should not talk to me about trollops here. I find it regretful that someone can be so criticised for erudition in an illustrious chamber such as this. We applaud the Government's action. We say that it is well worth while in many respects, but it is too late and the penalties provided are too small. That is consistent with this Government moving with the speed of the Arctic land mass towards doing something about tax avoidance. The Government will begin to catch up with a few tax avoiders by the year 2000. When one looks at the speed of light with which the tax avoidance industry has developed under this Government, one will see that it is a turtle and a hare sort of race but the turtle here is hopeless in every respect. It has no brains as well as no speed. It has no conviction about dealing with tax avoiders and no strength of character. It has nothing. It is a miserable turtle of a government, if I might continue with the analogy. I will give an example of what I mean.

SPEECH.PARA: When this Government tried to act against the Commonwealth Aluminium Corp. Ltd, which is owned by Kaiser Aluminium and Chemical Corp. of the United States of America and Riotinto Zinc Corp. of the United Kingdom, the High Court of Australia in its decision sided with the company. It was an extraordinary decision of the High Court but it was not surprising, as the Court was presided over by the former Chief Justice, that such a decision should have been arrived at, particularly in view of the fact that the Asprey report suggested, as I have said, in 1975 that section 136 of the Income Tax Assessment Act was inadequate. The High Court was at that time adopting a very narrow interpretation of these provisions of the Act and at last the Government was finally forced to do something. All we are able to say about that is-I hope I may not appear too churlish-I suppose better late than never.

Of course, even this legislation will be argued about by lawyers and challenged . But at least we have begun to get to the stage where some of the loopholes in the income tax assessment legislation might be closed off. Of course, the whole problem of transfer pricing could be made much easier to deal with if the Government demanded fuller information from transnational companies. In my view it would not be an outrageous thing for a government to do. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development has recommended ground rules or codes of conduct for transnational companies. Senator Carrick, the Leader of the Government in the Senate rushes into the Senate brandishing the OECD report with the favourable parts for the Government marked with one of those yellow pencils.

TALK.START.PARA: —And inaccurate.

—He reads those selected passages with great glee, which reminds me of the classic Walter Bagehot story, in which he described statisticians as being like drunks as they use lamp posts for support rather than for illumination. That is what Senator Carrick does when he comes into the Senate; he uses the OECD report for support rather than for illumination and he does not read those sections of the report which are not particularly comforting to the Government, like the section which says that the Government has no wages policy. As Senator Walsh pointed out, he does not refer to the passages of the report which are glaringly inaccurate, as is exposed by the diligent Senator Walsh, the shadow Minister for Finance, who has now left the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I said that the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development has recommended ground rules or codes of conduct in relation to transnationals. One would hope that the Government will take those up and insist on greater information being supplied by transnational companies operating in Australia. The OECD has said that companies should not be given the option of making available to governments the fullest information; they should be required to make available the fullest possible information. Without that information it will remain a difficulty for the Commissioner of Taxation to determine whether transnational companies operating in Australia are flouting the laws.

In the context of debate about taxation legislation over a long period we on this side of the Senate have pointed time and again to loopholes which ought to be closed off by retrospective legislation, to the size of the tax avoidance industry in Australia and to the fact that the tax avoidance industry in Australia removes the possibility of any consensus about where this society ought to be going. It removes the possibility of having an incomes policy in this country or, at least, a wages policy-which this Government does not have. Without these things and while people are making enormous sums of money out of tax avoidance one cannot have a consensus on any of these issues in a country such as Australia and the country has no prospect of economic rehabilitation. We have pointed out these things over three or four years now.

While we have been doing that the tax avoidance industry has burgeoned from posing a couple of thousand identified tax avoiders in 1975 to having some 23, 000 tax avoiders in 1982. That is an indication of the size of the tax avoidance industry and the way it has flourished under this Government-to the detriment of other taxpayers and to the detriment of any possibility of agreement about what are fair shares in a society such as ours.

The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development has recommended to governments such as the Fraser Government in Australia that there should be guidelines and codes of conduct for transnational companies operating in a country such as this, and that those guidelines should require those companies to give the government of the sovereign state-if Australia be a sovereign state any more-very clear information about their activities. Only then can a fair and proper assessment be made of true tax liability. Until such a fair and proper assessment is made there will still be massive tax evasion, the lack of morale in the society that goes with tax evasion and the constant criticism by trade unions and others that it is not fair for their members to be placed in a certain economic situation by government policies while so many others can avoid it by avoiding the law. In the context of this debate we again tell the Government that it ought to establish guidelines for transnational companies. If the Government is genuinely concerned, as a government, about the tax avoidance issue and is not just looking after some of its mates, it will do something about it as quickly as possible.

I support the amendment which has been moved by my colleague Senator Walsh. The essence of that amendment is to ensure that penalties relating to tax avoidance are consistent and sufficiently high to be a genuine deterrent against that practice which is a social evil of enormous proportions. The second purpose of the amendment is to ensure that transnational corporations operating in Australia comply with the OECD and United Nations codes of conduct and to see that this Government insists on their so doing. Thirdly, we are concerned that the Bill fails to take retrospective action against persons flouting the tax system through blatant avoidance schemes utilising section 26AAA of the Act. Fourthly, our concern is that the Bill endorses use by the medical profession of corporate and trust arrangements with significant tax avoidance implications.

I need to say nothing about the medical profession and its tax avoidance activity except that, if anything, it enjoys a reputation in this society marginally lower than that of politicians. I spend a lot of time in the Senate urging better performance from members of this Government-they are politicians par excellence-because if we get better performance from this Government in the areas of tax avoidance and industrial relations, which we have discussed in this place and elsewhere, politicians will move up the hit parade well ahead of the medical profession, which will continue to slide down with the connivance of this Government which is allowing that profession even further opportunities for tax avoidance. I think it is most unfortunate that those unhappy doctors who have so much to answer for in this community-other than at the occasional times when they look after us-should be encouraged in that activity by this Government . I commend to the Senate the amendment moved by Senator Walsh and I hope that the Government will take some of the advice which we have suggested it profitably might take if it wants to look a bit better before the next election than it looks now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1982 amends quite a considerable number of provisions of the income tax law. Within this debate I wish to speak about various amendments but not about the Bill as a whole. The Bill will counteract tax avoidance through transfer pricing, introduce new zone allowances and grant tax deductions in respect of certain charitable donations. These are the amendments that I wish to speak to briefly.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that Senator Button had a considerable amount to say on transfer pricing. I also note that the report from the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources made comments in regard to the development of the bauxite, alumina and aluminium industries. The Government indicated that the proposed measures suggested in the report have been adopted by this Bill. While transfer pricing is mentioned particularly in regard to the mining industry, as a senator from the Northern Territory I note that transfer pricing has been carried out in other spheres of primary production. Transfer pricing means that, for example, the price of an article purchased at a certain price on the north coast will increase by the time it arrives in Hong Kong or Japan. That means that an Australian producer, in partnership with an overseas firm, misses out on profit. There has been much to say about the mining industry.

In the north the same principle has applied to the production of pearls and prawns. There have been business arrangements between Australian firms which have overseas partners whereby the Australian partner, being the minority partner, has not been able to control the price of the pearls or, for that matter, the prawns. The majority partner overseas fixes the price at a much lower level in Australia, but when he transfers the product to overseas markets the prices increase tremendously. While there is a loss to the nation in income tax there is also a loss to the producer. I am pleased to see that action is being taken to counter this problem. Measures have been adopted to allow tax deductions for donations to Polish relief funds. This is very commendable. As honourable senators would realise, there have been many appeals throughout the nation to raise funds to send to Poland to assist the unfortunate people there through their period of privation and strife. This measure will be an incentive for people in Australia, who wish to assist the Polish relief funds, to make tax deductible donations.

I think it is very commendable, although it has no part in this Bill, that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) indicated last week that the flow of migrants into Australia is to be increased by some 10 per cent to 14 per cent. It is to be expected that the number of migrants coming to Australia this year will be 120,000-odd. I hope and expect that we will see an influx of Polish migrants who have been living in very poor conditions since the problems in Poland began.

One of the points I am very pleased to see relates to the zone allowances. Mr President, as you realise, over the years the zone allowance has brought considerable help by way of a taxation concession to the people in the outback. But over the years the level of the allowance has not increased and so its effect has deteriorated to some extent. The Government introduced this allowance in 1945 because of such things as the high cost of living, the problems associated with living in remote areas and climatic conditions. It was introduced to provide many of the people in the outback with the same degree of comfort as their cousins in the capital cities and along the eastern coast who live in better conditions.

Whilst the lifestyle and living conditions have become more sophisticated, particularly in the cities, there has been little change in many parts of the outback. At times I wonder whether there has been any change at all. I can well remember when the zone allowance was introduced. In the 1940s and 1950s an outback airline used to service some 128 places in the north of Western Australia, the whole of the Northern Territory, western Queensland and South Australia. That airline was Connellan Airways. That magnificent airline did a remarkable job and weekly or bi-weekly brought air services-mail, perishables and freight-to the people of the outback. It was an extremely good service, but over the years, through high costs and various adversities, it declined until it closed down. To some degree other charter lines have taken over. The services that the people in the outback had in the 1940s and 1950s really have not been brought up to date. To some extent living conditions have improved for the people out in the bush or the northern coastline. These people live vast distances from markets and from cities. The cost of transport, whether it be by aircraft, road or barge, has increased tremendously for people living in these very isolated areas. I often visit them in this Territory which comprises approximately 540,000 square miles and wonder how they have the courage and the tenacity to remain and work in these conditions. They are very dedicated people. There are many families. Their earnings-whether they be salaried employees or earning money from their own business-are not high at all. Their salaries are little more than, if not equal to, those of people in the city or in the country towns. Yet they live in conditions of adversity and in very high cost areas.

It amazes me, when I wander through the outback and visit Aboriginal settlements and go through the little co-operative stores and the bush stores and see the orders that have to be brought several hundreds of miles to people- whether they be on cattle stations, mining fields or what have you-how on earth these people can afford to live. To some minor degree the zone allowance assists them. It was thought that the zone allowance was to be cut out completely but many representations have been made to the Government from the people of the north asking that zone allowances continue and that they be reviewed. I am very pleased to see that the Treasurer, John Howard, saw fit to bring about an inquiry. The report of that inquiry was tabled in June 1981. It is interesting to note that the Committee which reviewed the matter saw fit to continue the zone allowance, but did not see fit to increase the allowance applicable to zone A or zone B. The second reading speech states:
The change follows a careful examination of the zone allowance system in the light of the report of the public inquiry into the system of income tax rebates for people living in more isolated areas.

Under the new arrangements given legal force by the Bill with effect from 1 November 1981, the basic rebates of $216 for zone A and $36 for zone B will not be altered, but the part of the zone rebate that is related to dependants will increase.
It will rise from 25 per cent to 50 per cent of the relevant dependant rebate amounts for zone A and from 4 per cent to 20 per cent for zone B.
That is something which people will not refuse. Interestingly, the speech continues:

A special basic rebate of $750, in lieu of the ordinary basic zone A and zone B rebates, will be available for people residing, or spending the required period of time, in particularly isolated areas in either zone--
That is zone A or zone B-

that is, at places in excess of 250 kilometres by the shortest practicable surface route from the centre of the nearest population centre of 2,500 people or more. 1976 census data will be used to establish the population of centres for the purpose of the special basic rebate.

I understand that after the 1981 census a review will be conducted and that a continuing review will be conducted every five years thereafter. I suppose that we cannot grumble at the recommendations of the inquiry, which have now been encompassed in legislation. I represent people of the outback. I feel that there is every reason in future reviews to increase the rebate from $216 in zone A and $36 in zone B to something that is much more effective. It must have been very difficult for the members of the inquiry to make a recommendation that would be effective in the Northern Territory, particularly in the isolated areas, particularly in those areas where a special basic rebate of $750 will apply. As I indicated a few moments ago, this was determined on the basis of a radius of 250 kilometres, by the shortest practicable surface route, from a town of no more than 2,500 people.

Let us look at the map. I am referring not only to the Northern Territory, but also to Western Australia and Queensland. The effect of this planning will be that many places will miss out on the special basic rebate of $750. They will be categorised as zone B, for which the basic rebate of $216 applies. Because of the area that falls within the radius of 250 kilometres of a population centre of 2,500 people, very little of the Territory will be left to which a special rebate allowance will apply. Places such as Borroloola, which is on the Gulf of Carpentaria, small isolated areas, Aboriginal settlements and cattle stations will come under the special basic rebate of $750, but a vast number of people will remain on the basic rebate of $216. Paupers cannot grumble at this because it is at least something. But, as I said, I hope that in the future it will once again be reviewed.

Let us look at the situation in Arnhem Land. People living in places such as Milingimbi and Maningrida and various other places have to have their supplies delivered by barge, at very high costs. These people will not receive any further zone allowance but will continue to receive the basic rebate of $216. However, as I said, I am very pleased to see that this basic rebate will remain and that reviews will take place. The people who receive the special rebate will be quite thankful.

I hope that in future we will see a very comprehensive review undertaken. I would like to see a review of the principle applied in determining the people in isolated areas who are to receive the special rebate. I do not think that using the 250 kilometre radius from a town of no more than 2,500 people is sufficient. As I have said before, too many people who should receive the special rebate allowance do not receive it. Once again, while I am being critical of the allowance-I believe it is not sufficient and that many more places in the Northern Territory should attract the special allowance-I am thankful that at least we will still have the zone allowance. I look forward to the time when it will come under review and the people, particularly those people who live in very isolated areas, can be given much more of a go.
