DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 April, on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
(Quorum formed).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are discussing two Bills in a cognate debate; namely, the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Legislation Amendment Bill 1982 and the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1982. The first Bill contains a number of tidying-up amendments in relation to colleges of advanced education. The second Bill deal with schools . I will address myself to some of the issues covered in the first Bill, particularly those issues concerned with the amalgamation of colleges of advanced education. I point to what will be a continuing problem in relation not only to colleges of advanced education, but also to universities and, in some cases, to community colleges such as that in Darwin. I refer to the problem of supplementation. Until the last Budget the arrangements for supplementation were that the Government would pick up the additional costs that had accrued to tertiary institutions such as colleges of advanced education at the end of the financial year, particularly in relation to those additional charges over which the institutions had no control. Examples of this would be the recent academic salary rises, rises in inflation, particular wage decisions given to non- academic staff, electricity charge increases and the like. That range of charges in most cases would not be able to be predicted by the administrations of CAEs and, therefore, does not fall within their competence to budget for.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has now adopted a new procedure-prospective supplementation. This, of course, means that real increases now will not be covered. An estimate is made of the additional costs which might arise in the ensuing year and the CAEs are granted that amount. The Government has made it very clear that there will be no financial relief whatsoever for institutions that go over those types of expenditures. The reason I raise this matter in relation to this legislation is that it deals with some of the problems resulting from amalgamations. I think we should take particular note here that there are specific problems that those amalgamated institutions will be running up against. Those institutions face a twofold problem now. Their constituent elements were granted that prospective supplementation. Therefore, each of the constituent elements, had it continued as a single institution, would have specific problems built into it. Over and above that, the amalgamations, of course, in many cases have added additional charges, some of which the Government has specifically funded for, some of which it has chosen to ignore.

The amalgamation problems merely compound the problems of supplementation because the ensuing administrations within those institutions will now be expected to budget not only within that prospective supplementation grant but also within the proposed additional costs for which the Government has estimated . If either of those or, what is more likely, if both of those groups of expenditures exceed the budgetary expectations imposed on them by this Government, that amalgamated institution, at the end of its first year of operation, will be in dire financial trouble. I believe that in most cases the Government has overestimated the reserves of those institutions and their capacity to adjust in the type of rapid way that the Government seems to expect.

I also point to the fact that this Government has not been able to project the additional cost rises in the economy. Given the vast range of economic advice that this Government has available to it, it has not been able to budget and stay within its means. Why should this Government expect that a tertiary institution which has far less access to those detailed projections and assessments should be able from month to month to eke out its total budget arrangement and stay within the total amount that the Government has projected? It hardly seems fair for any institution, let alone those institutions that have newly amalgamated, to have that imposed upon them. I suggest that the impressive name that we give to what the Government has engaged in-'estimates of increased costs'-is little more than a guesstimate of what will actually happen. Indeed, anybody who knows anything about the way some of these estimates are made is rather taken aback that the Government's source of advice in relation to them often rings people in various institutions and asks them what they think will be the outcome of a wage case or other particular element that may affect CAEs. I do not believe, and I am sure that the Government cannot believe, the rhetoric it is putting out in relation to this. The consequence of this economic situation for the CAEs is that they have set about attempting to cut back. I will refer to a specific area in which CAEs would be able to cut back. If they are to cut down on their courses, for example, and trim their sails somewhat, the obvious place to look for cut-backs would be the major component of recurrent costs, the salaries of staff. If we look at the latest report of the Tertiary Education Commission in relation to the staff in CAEs we discover that, with respect to combined university and CAE staff, it states:

In both sectors the number of staff aged 55 years and over is relatively small. Based on a retirement age of 65 years, approximately 9 per cent of staff at universities will be due to retire within the next 10 years. For CAEs the corresponding figure is 7 per cent; in some of the States the normal retirement age for staff who belong to State superannuation schemes-
Of course, some of those are still in CAEs-
is 60 years, which at a maximum could produce a retirement rate as high as 17 per cent over the next ten years.

We are not looking at 10 years. We are looking initially at one year in terms of the amalgamated institution or at a rolling triennium. It concerns me that it really is not possible for those internal budgets of CAEs to meet the types of propositions put up by the Government and seemingly from which the Government has no intention of retracting. In other words, there will be forthcoming no additional financial relief for the types of problems that may very well emerge from those amalgamated institutions. Other types of problems of CAEs, I think, also have not been given full weight by the Government. I refer to a lot of discussion about the economies of scale in the major institutions. I give as an example the Brisbane College of Advanced Education, which encompassed a number of campuses spread throughout Brisbane. Previously those campuses had their own administration and operated individually. The Government quite rightly saw that in the initial phase of the Brisbane College of Advanced Education, there would be increased costs involved and it allocated additional funds. However, the Government estimated that in some way after the initial period, economies of scale would set in and that these additional costs would not be faced. I suggest that the only way in which those economies of scale could be obtained would be by cutting back the services offered by those constituent colleges. If those colleges maintained their level of operation I suggest that there would be no economies of scale. Indeed, on any organisational principle one would expect increased costs because of the problems of communication between a variety of campuses. In other words, one would expect that the various institutions and their administrations would stay in place and that all that would be likely to happen would be the imposition of a further administration up above to co- ordinate the work between the various campuses. I do not believe it has been shown that the types of savings that the Government is projecting onto the CAEs will necessarily occur. As I have already said, if those cuts do not occur then those institutions will be in dire financial trouble.

The way in which some of these amalgamations took place is only to be deplored. Nevertheless, in recent times we have found a striking resilience on the part of those institutions to grapple with the problems with which they were presented by the Government. In many cases those institutions presented to the Government extremely useful propositions and methods for amalgamation. Only a few of those proposed amalgamations have yet to be concluded. I believe that we should be rather reticent about accepting the particular method that the Government used in this case as a model in the future for educational re-organisation. I do not believe that the method that the Government used is a good one or that it should set a precedent for further work in tertiary education institutions in this country, particularly in the area of the CAEs.

I am particularly concerned with the possible destruction in future years of the CAE presence in my State. The CAE was initially amalgamated with the James Cook University. I am concerned that the northern areas of such a big State could eventually be left without any effective CAE presence. I do not denigrate in any way the administration of James Cook University but merely point out that universities and CAE have tended to develop, at least in recent years, different attitudes and different projections of their role within the tertiary education community. Hybrid institutions, such as the James Cook University would become, do not necessarily sit very well within our educational structure. A simplification and redefinition of the roles of universities and CAEs would be an extremely useful activity in the future, not in terms of imposition but in terms of co-operation with those institutions. A great deal of change will be necessary in the tertiary education area in the future. These changes could be carried out by the institutions themselves to the advantage rather than to the detriment of tertiary education in this country.

Other points in the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Legislation Amendment Bill 1982 to which I wish to direct my attention concern a number of matters that I do not necessarily want to go into now. Indeed, some of the points which are relevant will probably be just as relevant in a subsequent debate quite soon on another set of Bills to be presented in this chamber by which the Government is seeking once again to introduce fees for second and higher degrees. It probably would be as well to leave the discussion of those points until that debate takes place.

In conclusion I refer to the research centres of excellence. Ther has been a great deal of support for this proposition within tertiary education institutions in Australia. I think this concept is a welcome advance in this area. My major concern relates to the source of funds for research centres of excellence. While it is extremely difficult to say categorically where the funds come from, I think a reasonable case can be made out that the research centres of excellence have been funded from savings made by all tertiary institutions in this country. In other words, all institutions have cut back expenditure in order to obtain a funding arrangement for the research centres of excellence.

When this Government initially raised this idea in its policy speeches I believe that it gained a great deal of support around Australia for the inovation. However, the Government lost rather heavily once it was realised that funding for the research centres of excellence would not be in addition to funding already available to other tertiary institutions. That was unfortunate. The notion of research centres of excellence is particularly attractive for a country such as Australia which has a fairly sparse population in comparison with its geographical spread. The Government must pursue concentration in certain areas. In other words, it must seek to establish staff and capital equipment in particular places around Australia. These various centres then attract students. This is better than trying to spread ourselves rather thinly across the whole of the continent.

If research centres of excellence are to work an additional step is required. The funding of staff, establishment costs and capital costs have been provided. Although I said earlier that I was critical of where the money came from to provide for those centres, those things have been provided. The missing element is the post-graduate students who provide the base for future operations. Here again we face the crucial problem of the funding of students. Having concentrated our research in certain areas, it is imperative that we provide reasonable funds for post-graduate studies within this country. We must educate our citizens who, at that level, are already products of a very expensive education system. We must not lose one prospective post-graduate student. The funding of those students will ultimately make or break those research centres. It will establish them either as renowned international centres dealing with particular areas or simply centres dealing with particular research studies. To make them centres of excellence we must gather together the best students and the best staff and fund them adequately. Anything less than that will be merely another farcical operation in tertiary education in this country, of which we already have sufficient.

I have said before that the Australian Democrats hold very firmly the notion that educational funding, particularly at this level, is crucial to the economic growth of this country. It is absolutely vital for us to be able to progress well past the year 2000, which after all is only 18 years away; it is not light years away. We must, since we have not done so in the past, grapple with the essential task of setting national goals for our tertiary education institutions . They can be set only by a co-ordinated operation between all governments- Federal and State-within this country so that we can agree on what is needed. We need to fund the institutions and the students to produce the highly educated citizens in this country who will in turn support and be the mainspring for our economy in the year 2000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. This table indicates that the Government's new policy will result in schools suffering a shortfall of approximately $14.3m and tertiary institutions losing approximately $26.5m in 1982. It is clear that the Fraser Government's aim in introducing the new formula is to further reduce funds to public education. In line with the philistinism for which this Government has become infamous, the Minister for Education has set the scene for further encroachments into tertiary fund and funds for government schools. What such reductions will mean in terms of schools is that children in government schools will face an inevitable reduction in educational resources. These children will miss out on such things as art and craft facilities, sports facilities, library books and school excursions. Innovations such as microcomputers for school use will disappear. The many excellent and dedicated teachers in the government school system will be handicapped and the educational standards of government schools will decline.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the Government will try to justify reductions in funds for schools by pointing to the slight decline in enrolments in government schools. However, as the Schools Commission pointed out in its latest report, a marginal decline in enrolments does not necessarily create economies and may in some circumstances force up per pupil costs in government schools. If in every government school throughout Australia one child leaves one class in any given year that does not reduce the number of teachers needed or the school facilities needed to service the rest of the children. Any enrolment decline would have to be significant to affect these factors. The Government's argument that the decline in funding for government schools is to take account of falling enrolments is specious. I think we should see the Government's actions for what they are-a further channelling of public money out of the public sector and into the private sector. If the Schools Commission's recommendations for 1983 are adopted there will have been between 1976 and 1983 a 10 per cent reduction in real terms in funds for government schools and a 78 per cent increase in real terms in funds for non-government schools.

It is figures such as these which demonstrate the government's hyprocrisy when it cries poor. Government members and senators are very fond of making speeches saying that they would like to be able to spend more on education, social welfare or health but that in view of the current economic stringencies increased spending is not possible. Yet we all know that this Government has not reduced public spending. This is the biggest spending, biggest taxing government in the history of Australia. Yet, wherever possible, it channels the money that it collects away from the public services for which the community pays its taxes and into the private sector for facilities which are available to only some sections of the community.

Anticipating some of the criticisms that will come from Government senators, I must restate that the Labor Party does not oppose Federal support for non- government schools; that is, we support funding of non-government schools on a needs basis. This was the policy which the Labor Government implemented in office. This is the policy which we will implement under the Hayden Government. However, at the same time as acknowledging the continuation of needs-based funding for the private school sector we must make clear that we will not tolerate concurrent deterioration of the public education system in which 75 per cent of Australia's school-aged children are enrolled. It is very clear that the abandonment of cost supplementation, which is provided for in these Bills, will contribute to such a deterioration in the public education system.

The situation for tertiary institutions is no less serious. Earlier this year the Academic Salaries Tribunal recommended modest salary increases for academics in universities and CAEs. The cost of providing for these salary increases in 1982 is $75m. With the abandoning of cost supplementation, universities and CAEs know that they will not be reimbursed for that $75m at the end of 1982 and are faced with the dilemma of where to find the money to pay these salary increases.

I ask the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) who represents the Minister for Education whether this $75m provided for in the anticipatory cost increases component is supposedly included in the 1982 grants to universities and CAEs. If this $75m was not adequately provided for it is estimated that something like 300 jobs in universities and CAEs would have to be abolished to save this amount. Such large scale sackings of staff would result in severe reductions in the quality and availability of tertiary education in Australia. I ask the Minister to give the Senate, during the course of this debate, an assurance that the Government will not allow such a situation to arise, that it will not leave universities and CAEs short of necessary funds. This scenario of universities and CAEs being forced to come begging to the Government for additional funds to cover cost increases which could not be anticipated is indicative of the effects that the abandoning of cost supplementation will have.

The second substantive matter dealt with in the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Legislation Amendment Bill is that of structural and funding changes consequent on the Government's forced amalgamation of 30 colleges of advanced education. I reiterate the Labor Party's opposition to the manner in which these amalgamations have been carried out. These amalgamations were ordered as a result of the razor gang's report and not as a result of any serious study as to the best use of educational resources in this country. The arbitrary figure of 30 colleges was apparently arrived at simply in pursuit of the Government's obsession with cutting costs and reducing the public sector. While it is doubtful whether the amalgamations will in fact save very much money , it is not doubtful-it is certain-that the quality and availability of education at the institutions involved are suffering. These amalgamations have been carried out without any educational objectives in mind and they have taken place to the detriment of students and staff.

Rather than a rationalisation of single purpose institutions over a three-year period as suggested by the Tertiary Education Commission, the Government has achieved the elimination of 30 separate institutions over one year, at a cost of great disruption and dislocation to all institutions involved. The number of CAEs in Australia has been reduced from 69 to 45 during this period. However, the Government is not yet satisfied. Even though its target of abolishing 30 separate institutions has been reached, including six institutions which were not on the Government's original list of 30, the Government still insists that six more colleges amalgamate. These six institutions were on the Government's original list. However, they have been unable so far to make satisfactory arrangements for amalgamation. In this legislation the Government insists that these six colleges go ahead with amalgamation and it makes grants to them conditional upon their active pursuit during 1982 of what the Government has chosen to call consolidation. These institutions are: In New South Wales, the Milperra College of Advanced Education, the Armidale CAE and the Newcastle CAE: and, in Victoria, the State College of Victoria at Hawthorn, the Institute of Early Childhood Development and the SCV at Melbourne.

All these institutions face very serious problems in achieving amalgamation and there are very strong arguments for retaining them as separate institutions. I do not have time to go over those arguments this evening; however, I am sure that all honourable senators have received information and documentation from the institutions concerned. It appears that the Government intends to ignore the arguments for retaining independence of these institutions, to ignore the damage to education which it is causing and now to eliminate not 30 but 36 of Australia 's colleges of advanced education. I wish to comment briefly on the effect these amalgamations are having on the educational prospects of Australian women. Amalgamations and closures of higher education institutions have occurred principally among those institutions specialising in teacher education. As honourable senators will be aware, women form a majority of the students and a large proportion of the staff in teacher education. Cutbacks in this area have had a disproportionate effect on women as have the majority of the Government's attacks on the public sector.

It is very clear that this Government is not committed to public education, that is, education to which all members of the public have access. It appears to be intent on crippling the public sector and reducing the number of CAEs in order to reduce its commitment to public sector education. While the Labor Party condemns the Government's forced amalgamations of CAEs the major purpose of the Bills currently before the Senate is to provide, as I have pointed out for the last time, for cost supplementation to schools and tertiary institutions. To the extent that the Bills provide cost supplementation they have the support of the Federal Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twice a year the Senate and the other place debate Bills to provide financial assistance through the States to schools and institutions of higher education. At this time of the year we look at the supplementation of the amounts that were made available and announced in the Budget context. In this event the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Legislation Amendment Bill 1982 and the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1982 provide supplementation of $53.7m with respect to tertiary education institutions and $3.7m with respect to schools. As the total amount that the Commonwealth Government is making available to schools this year is over $1,000m, $3.7m is a drop in the bucket in the supplementation arrangements. It is a technical increase to make up for the impact of inflation. With regard to higher education institutions, the Commonwealth makes available nearly $2 billion, and this $53.7m is again somewhat of a drop in the bucket although, of course, set out in the Schedule to the tertiary education Bill are particulars of two very good initiatives that have already been referred to-that is, the centres of excellence program of research in universities and community language courses to be developed in higher education institutions, such as the teaching of modern Greek at a superior level at the Monash University in conjunction with the other two universities in Melbourne.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate in the Senate tonight is following traditional, well worn routes of talking about the mechanism of supplementation and, by inference, about the adequacy or inadequacy of the total financial provision. Senator Ryan's speech was a direct echo of Mr Dawkins's speech in the House of Representatives some days ago. Senator Macklin's speech was a direct echo of his own thoughts expressed six months ago in the Senate. My speech so far is somewhat of a rewrite of what I said 12 or 18 months ago. In considering the Bills before us I wish to get away from the minutiae of the financial technicalities that are virtually a matter of procedure at this time of the year. I wish briefly to begin to ask some larger questions about education in Australia. As to the matters that have already been raised in debates such as this-and for those who are interested and who may wish to look them up in the future-I refer to my own speeches of 13 May last year responding to the Review of Commonwealth Functions decisions on education, of 28 October last year, with regard to the secondary and tertiary education Bills and of 11 March this year on the question of cost supplementation becoming prospective supplementation. All of these matters have been covered previously and I do not think the debate so far has provided any degree of enlightenment on the matter to the Senate or to the public.

I believe that honourable senators should encourage one another to start a fresh debate in Australia about where education is going at the secondary and tertiary levels. The two levels are intertwined. We talk about equality of opportunity and the questions asked by parents and their children. Are the schools serving them for adulthood, employment and all the multi-purposes of an education experience? Parents are asking: Are our children really being served? In the universities we are seeing a traditional set of courses and research in excellence continuing. But the questions are still being asked. How can university and college education, provided to only a small minority in Australia , be extended to bring employment benefits to those of other professions, trades and careers?

I do not think that in our debates about the minutiae of financial processes we have brought ourselves to these wider questions. Have we addressed ourselves to the retention rates in secondary schools? Throughout the century there has been a gradual increase, and after the second World War a much increased rise, in the proportion of 15, 16 and 17-year olds staying on in schools. But does the public know that in the last few years those retention rates have fallen away, particularly amongst male secondary students? They have actually dropped. Has the road of progress to enlightenment in secondary education turned the corner? Are we heading back to a lower state of achievement? The recent decline in the retention of students at the middle teenage level in our schools is partly a reflection upon the too high level of youth unemployment in Australia, as in most developed technological societies. It is also a reflection upon a dissatisfaction by those children and their parents with the education system as it is.

A number of us in the Senate have tried to touch upon the inadequacies in the secondary system. We have talked about the 20 to 25 per cent-usually the lowest achievers-in the schools who lose motivation and self-confidence, who are turned off by school and who are bored with a curriculum that, for the most part, is geared for academic entry to universities and colleges. When will we arrive at the day when there is a real unison in the question: When will we start to serve those children? That question is being asked not only in the Senate but also by the public. When will we start to re-order the curriculum in our schools so that we are not just year after year lamely accepting the curriculum that is geared to university entry? This question remains very much in the minds and on the lips of the public in Australia-in the countryside, in the cities, in government schools and, to some extent, also in non-government schools. I believe that the resources that have been made available to an increasing extent during the 70s must be applied to meet the real needs of the people.

The matter is now beyond debate. The Budget Papers and all the appendices to the reports of the Commonwealth Schools Commission and the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission show an increasing monetary amount spent year by year by government on all sectors of education in Australia. Noticeably, very increased amounts have been spent in the area of technical and further education-that is, in trade training in the technical and further education colleges around Australia. Also there have been real increases in the total amount of money available from government in the secondary and primary schools area and in higher education. Some Opposition spokesmen will debate, as we have heard tonight from Senator Macklin, that the excellent initiatives that have been taken in the centres of excellence program have, by various readings of the figures, taken away from the amount that is available for the ongoing basic programs in universities. I am not convinced by those arguments, but it is undeniable that the total amount available from governments to universities, colleges, technical and further education and secondary and primary education has continued to increase in real terms. In the early 70s there was almost a doubling in the resources made available to education.

That doubling in resources met the question of the day, when there was a quite fervent education debate in the Australian community. But what has happened to that education debate? It has fizzled and there is desperation and frustration amongst the parents and children of Australia. The debates that too often occur in the Senate are in a technical language. They are point scoring debates about classifications of money that are lost on ordinary students and families. They have become the preserve of teachers unions, university staff unions, college unions and, to some extent, the political machinations of various institutions governing councils and their representatives, such as some vice chancellors and principals. The debate has been too often pitched at point scoring to see what amount in the proportion of votes can be gained for one party or another, to see how we can con the professionals amongst the teachers in the schools and the academics in higher education to see that we are identifying with them.

I believe the debate in recent years has been lowered to an appeal to those professional people. I do not believe that we have with us any more, in the questions that are asked in these debates, the people whom we fundamentally are seeking to serve. I wonder when honourable senators will receive views, letters and petitions from other than professional teaching unions or academic unions. When will we receive any point of views from the ordinary public? People see, year by year, an increasing financial allocation by governments. They see more and more equipment in schools. They see teacher-student ratios becoming more favourable and then they see a plateau in the funding. It is still being maintained at a high level, yet they are still confused about where it is going and whether their children are really being served.

I come back to what I believe are two broad but fundamental questions that have been left aside by the past debates about the minutiae of financial procedures. Are the children of Australia being served by the schools? How can the benefits of a university education be made available equally to other trades, professions and careers within Australia? What have we to learn from comparisons with Japan and the United States in terms of the higher proportion of 17, 18 and 19-year olds continuing with full time formal training? Those countries are much more directly geared to employment prospects and to the real needs in adulthood of their Japanese or American students. What have we to learn in Australia from the example in Canberra of a retention rate double that generally the case in other parts of Australia? Is that only a reflection upon the more affluent families that live in the capital city? Is it a reflection upon the largely professional families that live in Canberra and give the traditional motivation to their children to go on with higher education?

Are there other factors? How can we be sure that the opportunities for making available education opportunities of direct benefit to the young people of Australia are being fully taken up? One is still left, often, with the view that there is a remaining inertia in the curriculum systems at almost all levels of education in Australia. I do not wish, with too broad a sweep, to disparage the people in all the State systems, in the independent schools, in universities who are, in a professional way, seeking reform in the directions that I am indicating. But I think we should much more humbly and much more carefully try to be accountable to the ordinary people of Australia, and bring to these debates the questions that the ordinary people are asking and not just consider the views of the academic and education professionals or the newsletters of the teaching unions. We should consider the real concerns of the ordinary families and young people of Australia. I hope that opportunities such as the debate of these Bills will, in future, lead us to more substance in education considerations by the Senate. I support the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to clarify a matter which arose in Question Time earlier today when, at the end of a series of questions concerning the Falkland Islands crisis, I asked a question which drew the response from Senator Sir John Carrick that I was making untimely and severely critical remarks concerning the participation of the United Kingdom armed forces in the naval battles and aerial bombardments that have occurred on and around those islands in the last few days. I rose in response to a specific point made by Senator Sir John Carrick in response to Senator Chipp in the course of which Senator Sir John Carrick said:

SPEECH.PARA: Aggression cannot be allowed to go unhindered.

I rose also in response to the general tenor of the remarks by Senator Sir John Carrick and other Government spokesmen, which was to concentrate, as I saw it, on Argentina's failure to comply with the United Nations resolution passed, I think, on 2 May this year. No doubt the military junta in Argentina did engage in unjust aggression against the Falkland Islands and manifestly against the will of the inhabitants of those islands. To that extent I think all honourable senators agree with that part of the United Nations Security Council resolution which states:
Determining that there exists a breach of the peace in the region of the Falkland Islands,
2. Demands an immediate withdrawal of all Argentine forces from the Falkland Islands.

The mere fact that the Falkland Islands are only some four times the size of the Australian Capital Territory and are inhabited by only some 1,800 people is no reason not to be deeply concerned about the prospects of those islanders under one of the most repressive, dictatorial military juntas presently wreaking its will on the people over whom it has control. However, having said that, I believe-and I believed at Question Time-that it is incumbent upon the Australian Government to be even-handed. I think one need go no further than the United Nations Security Council's resolution to understand one of the bases of my question. The demand for an immediate withdrawal of all Argentine forces from the Falkland Islands was only one of three demands made by the Security Council in that resolution. The others included the demand that there be an immediate cessation of hostilities. The pertinent one is that the United Nations:
Calls on the Governments of Argentina and the United Kingdom to seek a diplomatic solution to their differences and to respect fully the purposes and principles of the Charter of the United Nations.

I believe that call for the seeking of a diplomatic solution is a call of equal weight to the demand that the Argentine forces withdraw from the Falkland Islands. I believe that call for a seeking of a diplomatic solution is crucial to an outcome which would minimise the loss of life. After all, that is the purpose of the Charter of the United Nations, regardless of whether one looks at Article 51 or Article 53. But my question went somewhat further and was triggered, as I have said, by Senator Sir John Carrick's response to Senator Chipp which was:
Aggression cannot be allowed to go unhindered.

It is true that aggression ought not to go unhindered, but I was trying to raise the question of whether there are any moral restraints on governments in resisting unjust aggression. Are there any moral restraints or does unjust aggression permit unbridled waging of war against the unjust aggressor? Really it is an argument about ends and means. It may well be conceded that, as Senator Sir John Carrick said, the end or goal in view is a peaceful society of free men and women. But my argument, and the argument of the tradition that I was calling on, is that the end does not justify every means and that the means must be in moral harmony with the end that is sought, namely, peaceful relationships between human beings.

I felt that Senator Sir John Carrick did not grasp what I was getting at when I spoke of the just war doctrine and its requirement that response to unjust oppression should be in proportion to the injury being suffered and should be undertaken as a last resort. In saying these things I do not want in any way to indicate any thought on my part that Senator Sir John Carrick is not absolutely sensitive to the needs for moral restraint in the actions of combatants one to another. I would imagine that his distinguished war service and the suffering he was forced to endure during the Second World War would not lead anyone to any conclusion of indifference on his part to the need for moral restraint in the waging of war. However, the just war doctrine does have a long lineage in Western civilisation. I went to the Parliamentary Library and found, for example , that in the Times editorial of 24 April, entitled 'The War Within', there is talk about the general nature of war and its place in Christians' thinking. It states that there are two respectable traditions, one of total pacifism and the other based on the doctrine of the just war, which perhaps could be more properly described as the justifiable war. Amongst other things it states:
Just war can only be just if it is caused by injustice-aggression; if its aims are the restoration of justice . . . and if its conduct is conditioned by the doctrine of minimum force.

When one considers what might be involved in the doctrine of minimum force, on turning to the New Catholic Encyclopedia, volume XIV one finds under the heading the 'Morality of War' that, indeed, the principles of the last resort and the principle of proportion are set out. To be morally justifiable war must be the last resort. Every other reasonable means must have been exhausted. On the principle of proportion, it is made very clear that a balance has to be sought between the devastation and the destruction of life caused in the resistance to unjust aggression and the suffering of that unjust agression. If the resistance is grossly out of proportion in the damage it wreaks to the suffering of the injustice, then indeed the injustice must be suffered. One need go no further than the Age of today's date to see that the front page column written by that newspaper's Argentina correspondent, Peter Cole Adams, starts by saying:
I think it can fairly be called overkill.
Some paragraphs later he goes on to state:
But when all that is said--
The 'that' refers to the unjust occupation of the Islands by the military junta-
Britain's response seems-at least from this admittedly peculiar vantage point- grossly out of proportion to the original offence.

I listened to PM this evening and to Mr Denis Healey, a former Minister for Defence in the British Government, a man therefore prepared to wage a just war if need be. He would have been in command of the military forces of the United Kingdom in themselves and as part of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation should it have been necessary to unleash them to resist unjust aggression, perhaps by the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics in Europe. In other words, he is a man who is certainly not a total pacifist. He said tonight on PM-I have not been able to get a transcript from the Library but I do not think I will do him an injustice-that in his view the point was being reached in the Falkland Islands crisis where the loss of life was out of proportion to the injury which had been done to the interests both of the United Kingdom and of the Falkland Islanders themselves. As I have said, a quick walk to the Library revealed those three or four sources which indicate and validate the basis of my question which raised the just war criteria.

The just war criteria, which, as I have said, have a lineage reaching back to St Augustine, outlaws certain responses to unjust aggression. For example, one obviously cannot destroy civilian centres of population. That raises a huge question-mark on the nuclear strategic doctrine of the super-powers but it modifies other responses. The doctrine of proportionality lays down that the violence and destruction of lives involved in remedying an unjust situation has to be in some proportion to what has been done. When one looks at the Falkland Islands situation one sees that the occupation of these islands amounted to a denial of the United Kingdom's sovereignty over them, but there is no evidence of slaughter of the civilian inhabitants. There is no evidence that the captured marines were subject to unjust treatment. In fact they were flown to a third country and then back home. One needs to ask whether, in carrying out naval engagements involving the loss of perhaps hundreds of lives and in carrying out an aerial bombardment of Port Stanley-we do not know the measurement of the loss of life of that bombardment at the moment-the loss of life involved in that response by the United Kingdom bears a proportionate relationship to the injuries suffered to the interests of the United Kingdom in reasserting its sovereignty over those islands or indeed any relationship to the injuries suffered by the inhabitants.

I refer now to the criterion of last resort. The taking of human life is such a tragic event in the history of nations that obviously it ought to be the very last step taken by a government. It has often been said in this chamber that it is wrong for a member of a union to withdraw his labour other than after having exhausted all possible avenues of negotiation and arbitration. That principle is even more applicable in the case in which there is the possibility that human lives will be lost. In sending this fleet into those icy and storm-tossed waters of the South Atlantic the British Government foreshortened the negotiating process. Once there, the fleet had to undertake the task of dislodging the invaders and/or render itself vulnerable to a first attack by the Argentine armed forces. Obviously it would respond in self-defence. In other words, the very arrival or presence of the fleet in those waters around the Falklands, in my view, signalled the end of the negotiating process. It seems to me that some more weeks at least ought to have been allowed to the negotiating process to enable a diplomatic solution, in accordance with the United Nations Security Council resolution, to be achieved, as indeed it will have to be in the next few days. Otherwise, as Denis Healey said on the PM program this evening, more lives will be lost than in fact are at stake on the island; if indeed any lives on the island are at stake.

As I said, to raise this matter is not to engage in subjective judgments-at least not entirely. The whole point of the just war doctrine is to introduce into the political process or the military conduct of war operations objective moral criteria of proportionality and last resort. Those criteria are objective in the sense that they are criteria from outside the political and military processes and stand in judgment against them. It is true that conclusions as to whether the facts cohere with adherence to those criteria is a matter of personal judgment. A personal judgment, of course, has to be undertaken, if it is to have integrity, with proper regard to whatever evidence is available. But that is not the same as engaging in purely subjective assessments which are no more than the expression of a personal whim or predisposition. If that were the case the just war theory would fail in its purpose which is to encourage sensible discussion among reasonable people as to the limits restraining the armed resistance to unjust aggression. That was the purpose of my question.

I hope that this further clarification may aid the process of discussion of the sensible moral limits to which the United Kingdom is entitled to go in seeking to repair the wrong done to the international community. It has, as I think Senator Sir John Carrick said in certain of his responses, far more implications than this isolated incident. An injury has been done, as the United Nations Security Council has recognised, to the international community's interest in the peaceful resolution of disputes as to sovereignty. But the question is: How far should the United Kingdom armed forces have gone and how soon should they have acted in trying to remedy the wrong that has been done? As I said, I was seeking to clarify my question. I reiterate, because of my respect for Senator Sir John Carrick's service in the armed forces of this country, that I want nothing which I said to carry any suggestion that in asking my question or making my remarks tonight I do not recognise that Senator Sir John Carrick has a very keen awareness of the need for moral restraints in the waging of warfare, particularly given the horrendous weapons of the modern age.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to refer to something the Minister said in this chamber today at Question Time when answering a Dorothy Dix question designed to discredit a recent newspaper article which obviously caused him some discomfort. That is not a matter for us to comment on because those events will spell themselves out when the long forecast reshuffle of the Ministry takes place. I refer to a statement the Minister made on 15 February 1982 at the official opening of the Vietnam veterans counselling centre at Parramatta. He said:
There have been calls by veterans for a judicial inquiry . . .

All of us on this side of the chamber have called for the same sort of judicial inquiry. Instead, an epidemiological inquiry was set up and subsequently discarded by this Government. The Minister went on to state:
There have been calls by veterans for a judicial inquiry and I have said often that the best advice available to me is that such an inquiry would fall down for want of scientific answers.
He then went on:
The Government welcomes the inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment.

On 8 July 1981 the Minister issued a Press statement on his return from the United States. That statement reads as follows:

Many American veterans seemed to be suffering delayed symptoms, attributed to service in a war which had divided the nation. All those persons he had spoken to-from Chairmen of Congressional Committees to Vietnam Veterans representatives -agreed that Agent Orange was not a key factor.
That is not true. On 9 July 1981, the following day, speaking on the Australian Broadcasting Commission program AM, the Minister said:
. . . there is no credible evidence at this stage of the game
Good Australian slang-
that indicates that there is any connection between Agent Orange and any disabilities.
He went on to state:

In fact in talking to Congressional leaders of both parties, talking to Vietnam Veterans, Bobby Muller for instance from the Vietnam Veterans of America, all those people said to me that this wasn't the issue. This was not the key factor. The key factor was the war experience.

Today further evidence has come to light to indicate that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs does not even know about this. I apologise to the Minister as he has now appeared in the chamber. I will quote from a telex of today's date which carried a story written by Laurie Oakes who is one of the better known political journalists around the gallery. It states:
A large pile of recently discovered documents on Australia's Vietnam war involvement could shed light on the issue of chemical spraying, according to a news report today.
The documents, some of which were classified, were mistakenly sent to the Annex of the Australian War Memorial in Canberra, the report said.
Political journalist Laurie Oakes, speaking on TV ( . . . Channel 10s Good Morning Australia), said the previously unexamined documents could embarrass the Federal Government.
Mr Acting Deputy President, can I wait until the Ministers have finished their conversation?

—I will give you such protection as is necessary. Will you please address the Chair.

SPEECH.PARA: . . . may show if senior Government Ministers, including Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser, knew of the dangers of chemical spraying and the involvement of Australian personnel.

TALK.START.PARA: —You must be joking.

—It is quite true that the Minister did not answer that part of my question. He can go back to Hansard and check it for himself. I am not saying that he evaded it but that he avoided it. —You should read the Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: This Parliament and the people of Australia are getting rather testy about the whole 'Spraygate' cover-up and the reasons for it. The present Prime Minister- honourable senators will be aware of this-was involved in decisions about the use of toxic chemicals in Vietnam. I invited the Prime Minister, because of his previous ministerial roles, to make a clear and frank statement to the Vietnam veterans who are suffering and for whom this Government cares nothing. Honourable senators will be aware that quite recently I sent a number of cases to the Minister's Department hoping that some finality could be reached on them. We continued to use those toxic chemicals in Vietnam long after the United States forces had stopped using them because they realised the dangers.

I suggest that with the release of these further documents, even if they have gone to the wrong place and are now being examined by 20-odd public servants who are trying to sift through them, perhaps at this point in history the Minister will help the ministerial reshuffle if he quietly resigns tonight and says: ' Well, I have failed.' There has been an obvious cover-up which my party has spent many months trying to point out to the Minister, the Prime Minister and to other Ministers of the Government. I clearly say that the 'Spraygate' cover-up is coming apart at the seams. This matter has reached a stage where, if the Prime Minister is involved, Government members should start to stand up for themselves and be counted. He is an ailing and failing Prime Minister who has fallen down not only on this job but also on everything he puts his finger to.

If the Minister is incapable of handling this hot potato, perhaps over bacon and eggs tomorrow morning or over coffee and crumpets tonight he will suggest to the Prime Minister that he be given a portfolio that is less dangerous for himself and his Government and of more benefit to the Vietnam veterans who are paying in many degrees-mentally, physically and every other way-for a war to which this Government forced them to go. It would not worry me if the Minister had a George Cross for his service in Vietnam or if the Prime Minister had a Victoria Cross for his service in Vietnam. Neither one of them has any intimate knowledge of what happened in those countries. Neither of them has any war service at all and is, therefore, able to have any feeling for veterans who have suffered these things.

It was this Government in all instances that decided that we should get involved in an undeclared war. If it had not been for the Labor Government of late 1972 to 1975, very few of those Vietnam veterans would have got any of the concessions to which all normal returned service people are entitled, most of which have now been withdrawn. My colleague, Senator Tate, talked about the involvement in the Falkland Islands. The Government has now sent people to the Sinai. If we still belonged to the old British Empire five minutes after the beloved Prime Minister of Britain had declared war on the Falklands the Government would have been doing the same thing and we would have been involved in that situation too. The Government is letting the British use the Invincible which will not be able to carry aeroplanes when it comes to this country but is able to carry aeroplanes now. No doubt if the situation continues it will end up with the Government involving us all directly or indirectly. Perhaps it will be able to get the Invincible back as a secondhand aircraft carrier, although it cannot be called an aircraft carrier because we have no aeroplanes to put on it. There is the story that Malcolm Fraser is setting up a model aeroplane club and these will be flown off the ship's deck. Those are facetious asides. I hope the Minister will take note of what has been said tonight instead of exposing his giggling countenance to the chamber. He obviously thinks that the whole Vietnam involvement was a joke. He thinks it is an even funnier joke that people are suffering as a result of it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to respond to Senator Tate's contribution tonight. I regret that I was not here for the earlier moment. I was not aware that the adjournment debate would commence a minute or two early. I am indebted to Senator Tate for his clarification. He expressed some concern earlier in the day . I have re-read the question and the answer. I want to assure him that at the time I accepted his question as a question put forward in good faith. My answer was meant to be an answer in good faith. One of the defects is that there may have been some misunderstanding on this matter. He will notice this when he looks at his own question. There is an inability at Question Time for honourable senators to expand on what they mean. The concentration on the British actions led to what I regard as a just response. I do not say this in any vexatious way, but I remind him that the substance of his question was:

SPEECH.PARA: Will the Government, in formulating its policy concerning the Falkland Islands crisis, not only take into account that part of the United Nations Security Council resolution calling on Argentina to withdraw its armed forces, but also give regard to and convey to the British Government the view that, firstly, the type of armed conflict being pursued by the United Kingdom with the destruction of human lives involved is out of all proportion to the injury to its sovereign interests said to be at stake and thus offends that aspect of the just war doctrine, and secondly, that such armed conflict was premature in that the steaming time for the war fleet set the time limits for a negotiated settlement rather than allowing the full exhaustion of non-violent means of resolving the conflict? Will the Government convey the view that the British Government has failed to justify the use of armed force . . .

At Question Time I responded, not in any offensive way, that I regarded that as a subjective value judgment. Let me say at the same time, without attempting in any way to be ingratiating, that I accept as a valuable addition to the debate Senator Tate's dialogue concerning the concept of a just war and the conduct of people seeking peace. I accept that; I think it is a valuable addition to the debate. Senator Tate made several points which suggested that Britain had over- reacted. First of all, he said that Britain's reaction was judged by steaming time and not by the length of negotiations. I put to the Senate and to Senator Tate that it was important that time should not be allowed for the aggressor to build up such a huge force of a defensive military nature that, if some reassertion of sovereignty were necessary, the scale of any such reassertion would lead to a conflict of greater magnitude than was necessary. In fairness, I suggest that the idea of a blockade being imposed as quickly as possible to stop the building up of a very large military force ought to be considered.

Secondly-here lies the great tragedy of the situation-the history of the United Nations, of which I am an eager supporter, is that it has shown itself to be virtually impotent to make decisions on such matters of sovereignty and to enforce those decisions. The history of the whole post-war period is that many nations now living in bondage previously had their sovereignty and seek sovereignty today. Senator Tate would know as well as anyone that the veto in the Security Council is the absolute destroyer of decision making of any real kind. The tragedy, therefore, is that nations find themselves either giving in to aggression, as the whole 30-year post-war period has indicated, or finding it necessary to take some action.

My response today was purely along the lines that I think it is a subjective judgment as to whether Britain acted faster than she need have done and whether more time could have been allowed. Equally, Senator Tate could say that my argument that a blockade was needed quickly to stop the building up of arms was a subjective judgment. Basically that is the only point of the dialogue. Since his question asked whether the Government would convey those views to the British Government, clearly my response was that they were views which needed to be tested, judged and evaluated. I think Senator Tate would agree with that. I think it would be a good thing if the kind of contribution that he made tonight could be developed in this forum because I think it added to this place. The principles of peacekeeping in this world ought to be debated and understood. Unfortunately I have to say that their ability to be used in this situation is very limited. I think we will need a longer telescope of history to decide the finer points of the justice of this situation. I hope, therefore, that none of us would sit in extreme value judgments. I do not say that Senator Tate has done so. The purpose of my contribution tonight has been to explain that. I thank him for his contribution tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate not to keep the Senate for any great length of time but to deal with the matters raised by Senator Keeffe in a most confused argument which covered a multitude of circumstances but which requires very little time to answer. First and foremost, I will refer to his reference to my visit to the United States of America last year. He raised the canard that I had not consulted any groups other than those representative of government. Some time after the question was asked in this place by Senator Keeffe on this point, I sought to provide a copy of the itinerary of my visit to the United States and the people I saw at that time. In brief, they covered congressional leaders from both parties within the United States, those veterans who operate counselling centres not only within the government organisation but also within organisations such as the Disabled Veterans of America and other groups in that country, and various health centres throughout the United States which are conducting studies on the health of Vietnam veterans, including the United States Air Force base at San Antonio in Texas, the Centre for Disease Control in Atlanta, Georgia, and a number of other centres.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite apart from that, the point which Senator Keeffe centred on in his question in August last year was whether I had dealt with a group known as Vietnam Veterans in Congress. That followed a letter which I received from that group drawing attention to the fact that I had not consulted it during my trip to the United States. How that letter came to be in the hands of Senator Keeffe is a matter for pure conjecture, but on page 324 of Senate Hansard for 26 August 1981 I incorporated a copy of a letter which I sent to that group. Unfortunately Senator Keeffe was not in the Senate that day; he was away on a family commitment. I will read that letter again for Senator Keeffe's benefit so that he may appreciate the problem. The letter is addressed to one Mr T. Daschle, Chairman of the Vietnam Veterans in Congress, 439 Cannon Building, Washington, D .C. 20515. It reads:
Dear Mr Daschle,

Thank you for your letter of 31 July 1981, signed jointly with Mr Panetta, concerning my visit to the United States earlier this year. It was unfortunate that we were unable to consult during the visit. My time in Washington was extremely limited, and some of the meetings with Government officials and veterans' organisations had to be fitted in during visits to other cities, as I needed to include in my schedule an examination of important research projects and practical programmes being conducted outside Washington to help veterans.
In the time available during my visit to Congress offices, I was able to have discussions with members of the Veterans' Affairs Committees of both the Senate and the House of Representatives.
I interpose to make the point that those committees are made up of people from both sides of the political fence in that country. To continue:

In requesting these meetings, the Australian Embassy made it clear to the staff directors of the two Committees that I would be pleased to meet any other Committee members who were in the position to join the meetings with the Chairmen.
Those who did attend the meetings were the Chairman of the Senate Committee and the Chairman and the ranking minority member of the House of Representatives Committee.
The Australian Ambassador endeavoured also to arrange for me to meet representatives of the Vietnam Veterans in Congress by inviting Mr Bonior and you--
That is Mr Daschle-
to join us at an evening function on 18 June.

There is one point on which I would like there to be no misunderstanding. While the Australian Government gives no undertaking to base decisions on the opinions of any particular body, it does endeavour to consider the widest possible range of views relevant to veterans' issues in determining its policies. In this context, I would be happy to examine any submission you care to make which you feel would be of value. The Government is glad to have available information relevant to this aspect of its policy-making, the aim of which is to contribute, within the Government's economic possibilities, to the well-being of Australian veterans.
Yours sincerely,

I make the further point that there was no letter of reply from that group, nor after some 10 months have I received any information or any submission along the lines invited at that time. I have formed views in my continuing connections with veterans' organisations and the veterans' administration in the United States of America on these points. I come now to some of the more particular matters that are contemporaneous with some of today's news reports.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a big word.

—It is a big word for me. There was a reference today in one Australian Associated Press report concerning, I understand, a television broadcast by Laurie Oakes and certain revelations of information that has not come to the fore at the Australian War Memorial. Over four or five weeks a study of Vietnam files provided by the Army has been undertaken at the War Memorial. That follows the original statement, made by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) at the time that this matter came to everybody's attention following some further so-called revelations of the use of agent blue in Vietnam, that there would be a further investigation of these matters. That investigation has been proceeding. An officer of my Department is involved in the investigation in which defence officials have been undertaking the major part of the work. There is no attempt by the Government to cover, as Senator Keeffe has suggested. We are endeavouring to investigate the matter further and to come to the right conclusions.

SPEECH.PARA: The particular interest of my Department follows the consistent line which I have followed since I became Minister for Veterans' Affairs; that is, to establish first and foremost to what degree Australian soldiers were exposed to herbicides in Vietnam. It is hoped that a continuing examination of files and information that becomes available to us will be helpful in finally forming a view on that point. That investigation is in progress and there is no difficulty about the Government facing up to its responsibilities in that regard. We are endeavouring, as we have been since 1980, to uncover all information, scientific or otherwise, in this area and make it available generally.

Another news report that surfaced today emanated from New York. It also is an AAP report concerning statements by two Australian Vietnam veterans who are currently in the United States undertaking their own examination of the problem. They claim that they have had discussions with one Bobby Muller, who is known to me as the National President of the Vietnam Veterans of America. However, Mr Muller's words were not quoted in the report that has been drawn to my attention but rather the words of one Mr McCarthy, who claims to be the President of an organisation known as Agent Orange Victims International. Not having been present at any meeting between the two Australian veterans and Mr Muller, he talks of certain words which have been reported to him by the Australian Vietnam Veterans Association to the effect that I somehow misquoted a conversation which I had with Mr Muller in New York in June, in claiming that Mr Muller had said that there was no connection between agent orange and the disability from which Vietnam veterans were suffering.

It is not Mr Muller who has been misquoted. I have been misquoted. I never said that. In fact, the latter part of the AAP report which I have seen makes that very point. Upon my return to Australia I said that I had had discussions with Mr Muller and that he had indicated to me that agent orange was not necessarily the key factor in the illnesses of Vietnam veterans. He said that the question of war neuroses and war experience was likely to be a very large and important factor in the welfare of Vietnam veterans. Senator Keeffe, in his saner moments, may acknowledge that that is the kind of point that I have been making since my return to Australia.

This has led to the Government adopting policies which are aimed at assisting Vietnam veterans who find themselves in unfortunate situations. The Government is offering free care in the repatriation general hospitals in cases of urgent need. It is providing care for Vietnam veterans and their families in country hospitals in cases of urgent need. It is establishing counselling centres throughout Australia which will employ not only experts outside the field of war services but also those who have worked in Vietnam, have some experience in this area and consequently have a feeling for those clients coming to them from the Vietnam veterans' community. These kinds of things are part of the Government's earnest in this regard. Clearly the Government is determined to help Vietnam veterans in this area. It has been my object and my policy since taking up my portfolio to adopt that approach and to try to find solutions to the very complex scientific questions which surround this whole matter and which have not been conclusively answered.

I have only one other thing to say. As I know that Senator Keeffe will be present at the meeting of the Australian Legion of Ex-servicemen and Women next Thursday afternoon in Brisbane when I will be present, I invite him to conduct a debate on this very issue before his peers in that organisation. I will be quite happy to meet any allegations that he might be prepared to make-allegations such as those he has made tonight in the Senate-publicly in open debate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Applicants who meet the eligibility and lending requirements for a Defence Service Homes loan to buy a new or previously occupied home are normally notified of loan approval within three to four weeks of lodgment of the application with the Defence Service Homes Corporation. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What will be the annual cost of maintaining an Australian commitment to the Sinai peacekeeping force in the Middle East, including the cost of troop movement and replacement during the course of a twelve-month period.
(2) Is the United States Government subsidising the Australian presence in any way.
(3) Will the force be withdrawn if hostilities resume on the Sinai Peninsula.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 16 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Were 'prolonged efforts' made to achieve a sufficient level of participation in offsets against the M198 program, and were the foreign government agencies involved 'pressed directly' to take up the shortfall of offsets.
(2) Was an industry program proposed to the United States foreign military sales agency but vetoed by the United States Department of Defence.

(3) Why was the clause regarding additional preference for Australian industry, especially for a depressed industry or area, contained in the above manual, not applied to the OFB for the M198 program.
(4) Why, if the M198 barrel is of such advanced metallurgical technology and is not likely to need replacement during the life of the gun, has this technology been transferred to Australian industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Prolonged efforts have been made, and are continuing, to achieve a sufficient level of Australian industry participation in this project. This involves maintaining continuous contact with appropriate United States Government procurement agencies.
(2) No single all embracing industry program was proposed by my Department to United States agencies and the question of a veto did not arise.
(3) I presume that the manual referred to in this question is the Defence Instructions (General) Admin 05-3.

The purchasing policies outlined in this Department of Defence instruction, which is currently being updated, applied when it was issued in mid-1977. However, the Government policy which allowed 'discretionary preference' in circumstances where the purchase of Australian made goods would assist a depressed industry or area within Australia, was superseded in late 1977, well before the Letter of Offer for the howitzers was accepted in November 1980. The new policy was separately promulgated pending the revision of DI (G) Admin 05-3.
Such policies are only part of the overall consideration which led to the decision to buy the guns overseas.

(4) Production of the barrels for the 105 mm light gun, which will be required in much larger quantities than the M198, was chosen as the vehicle for upgrading gun barrel manufacturing technology in the ordnance factories.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 16 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When does the Army expect to take delivery of the M198 howitzers on order from the United States.
(2) Has the delivery slipped until 1985.

(3) Does the contract with the United States Foreign Military Sales organization contain any provision for : (a) offset; (b) Australian industry participation; or (c) technological transfer; if so, what work will be undertaken in Australia as a result, and what will be the value of such work.

(4) Why was the Government's policy, as outlined in the Defence Instructions ( General) Instructions for the procurement of equipment and associated services DI(G) Admin 05-3, not applied if there is provision for offset, Australian industry participation or technological transfer.

(5) Has any United States government agency agreed to attempt to make up shortfalls against the offset target for the M198 program by purchasing items for their inventories from Australian defence contractors.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I expect deliveries to be completed by early 1984.

(3), (4) and (5) The Letter of Offer and Acceptance (LOA) for the M198 howitzers, which specifies the terms and conditions applying to this acquisition , requires the United States Government to make best endeavours to meet an offset objective of 25 per cent of the value of the M198 order. Pursuant to this objective United States orders on Australian industry for forgings and castings, to a value in excess of $1m, have so far been placed. A major area of technology transfer will be the establishment of a capacity to manufacture ammunition for the weapon.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 February (Hansard, page 232) Senator Crichton- Browne asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, a question without notice about various aspects of the mining, marketing and processing of diamonds by the Ashton Joint Venture.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following additional information to that provided at the time:

The Commonwealth Government recognises the sovereignty of the Western Australian Government in regard to development Agreements for major mining projects in Western Australia and does not intend to interfere in the comprehensive Agreement that had been entered into between the Western Australian Government and the Ashton Joint Venture partners. That Agreement provides, inter alia, for independent valuation and approval of marketing arrangements by the Western Australian Government but no proposals have yet been presented by the partners.

However, the Commonwealth Government has a responsibility to ensure that the national interest is protected and, in exercising that responsibility, must be able to take whatever action it considers necessary. This is why no firm undertaking can be given that control over the export of diamonds will not be introduced although I reiteriate that there is no present intention to do so.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 February (Hansard, page 477) Senator Tate asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, a question without notice about diamonds and I undertook to seek information on one aspect concerning the role of the proposed Commonwealth valuer.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Trade and Resources has supplied the following supplementary information:

As he has stated, he sees it as necessary, in order to carry out the Commonwealth Government's responsibility of ensuring that the national interest is safeguarded, that there should be a Commonwealth valuer who would periodically check the value of diamonds being exported. However, it is not possible to indicate what arrangements might be put in place, including the role of a Commonwealth valuer because the Ashton Joint Venture has not yet decided how Argyle diamonds will be marketed when production commences later this year.

With regard to the more general question about export controls which the honourable senator asked on 25 February, the purpose of the export controls on certain minerals is to safeguard Australia's national interests and, in particular, to ensure that Australia receives fair and reasonable returns for the export of those minerals. These objectives are being achieved although no specific example can be provided because the Government has undertaken to the mineral exporting companies concerned that all aspects of its consultations with them and of contract negotiations will be kept confidential.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 March 1982 (Hansard, page 693) Senator Elstob asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Education, a question without notice concerning tertiary education tuition fees.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

On 4 December 1981 I issued a media release indicating that tuition fees for second and higher tertiary qualifications would not be re-introduced in 1982. The media release was issued as a result of the Senate's rejection, on 24 November 1981, of the legislation which would have provided for the limited re- introduction of fees. The Senate's rejection of the legislation was given wide publicity at the time.

I have no evidence that the timing of the announcement on tuition fees for 1982 has discouraged potential students from undertaking courses. There was certainly no intention on the part of the Government that this should be so.
